The industrial revolution further changed sleep habits, making people work longer hours in lit buildings. Yet, in many non-western cultures, flexible sleep patterns still exist. People may sleep for a few hours, wake up, and then sleep again. In some tribal societies, constant noise and the need to stay alert make uninterrupted sleep difficult. It seems that people everywhere are struggling to get enough sleep.

We are talking about very expensive cowboy boots—really expensive ones. I stood in my 800-dollar designer cowboy boots on the rocks of an old formation in the Arizona desert. Money was not a problem. I wore a complete cowboy outfit, and if you have the outfit, you might look like a cowboy. But I wasn’t one. It just didn’t feel right. I squinted into the morning sun, looking at the Arizona mountains, and I had to admit that I didn’t belong there. 

I flew in from Denver just after dawn, thinking I might look like an old cowboy arriving from the sky. But that thought disappeared when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He was wearing a dirty t-shirt, needed a shave, and was picking up a worn canvas bag from the luggage belt. When he saw my new cowboy boots, he raised an eyebrow and walked out without saying a word. 

I thought there should be some clothes that an ex-racing driver could wear without feeling out of place. Something that would make me feel comfortable wherever I went, instead of feeling like everyone was speaking a different language and moving at a slower pace. I loved being a racing driver and driving racing cars. I was addicted to it, and it was all I knew. But I don’t do it anymore. I couldn’t even if I wanted to. 

I wondered what I should do now. A racing driver should have a backup plan for when he stops racing. I thought I had some ideas, but when I tried to reach for them, they vanished. I considered being a commentator at races, but there were already many former drivers doing that. I also thought about selling classic cars, but that didn’t work out either. It was a tough year for selling old Ferraris, and I decided to step back before I lost everything. 

Being an "ex" anything is hard. Who wants to hear about how I almost became World Champion? No one wants to hear a story that ends with "almost." Even if I had been the champion, you would probably only want to listen for a few minutes before getting bored. Last year’s champion is just that—last year. I don’t want sympathy, and I don’t get any. Why should I? I had a good career, made money, and saved enough. But I really miss the thrill of getting into that powerful racing car, feeling the speed of zero to one hundred fifty miles per hour in just 4.9 seconds. I even miss the danger of racing. 

I miss the exciting people and the reporters who acted like my words mattered. Being somewhat famous has its perks. Businessmen and politicians liked to brag that they knew me. Young boys would sneak under fences to get my autograph. But now that I don’t race anymore, things are different. Just last week, my phone rang twice. I have plenty of free time now. I looked up at the clear blue sky. There were no buzzards flying above. Maybe Arizona doesn’t have buzzards. But I noticed some little brown birds in a cactus nearby, and they seemed to be telling me to leave their nest alone. I never thought the desert had songbirds. It made me realize that a fake cowboy in fancy boots still has a lot to learn.

**Vancouver**

In the past ten years, many people from around the world have moved to Vancouver, a city in western Canada. In the evenings, residents enjoy walking through the streets, and if you join them, you will likely hear many different languages. People are attracted to Vancouver because of its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and mountains, clean and safe environment, and good educational and job opportunities. Although some locals complain about the rapid construction of new buildings, it is clear that the new residents and growing tourism have contributed to a vibrant city revival. Vancouver was once called 'Terminal City' because it served as a gateway to other places. While this name is less common now, Vancouver is still a major gateway.

**Putting Pen to Paper**

Journalists like me often struggle with writing letters. Some say this is because we dislike writing for free, but I think it is more about how we aim for the best effect in our work, which makes writing a letter feel less spontaneous. True creative artists, who may rewrite their work many times, do not face this issue. I believe that understanding the impact of their words is a key sign of a real artist. For example, when Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he likely did not think about how the use of longer words made them powerful and showed his talent.

**Supermarket Opening**

In Britain, the opening of a new supermarket used to be a big event. You could expect a celebrity, like a soap star or a member of the royal family, to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets seem to open every day, and celebrities are no longer needed. Why pay a famous person when anyone can do it for free? Last week, elderly people waiting for the opening of a new Superbuy store didn’t care who opened it, as long as they were at the front of the line. According to someone who knew an employee, the first five men to enter would receive a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get a bouquet of flowers. This news spread quickly among the crowd, making those at the front feel proud and causing envy among those who arrived later.

**Citizen Kane**

When the film *Citizen Kane* was released in 1941, it created a lot of excitement, but it was not a financial success. The release was delayed because the distributors were worried about the possible reactions of William Randolph Hearst, who was thought to be the inspiration for the main character. Despite the positive reviews, the film did not do well at the box office. It was only when it was shown on television that people started to appreciate it again. *Citizen Kane* is often seen as a film that has inspired many to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles believed that its success came from his lack of knowledge about the rules of filmmaking; he simply went ahead and created the film. He also had a talented team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to create a story about a newspaper tycoon who resembled Hearst, Welles realized he had found the perfect role for himself as both director and actor, and he approached the project with great enthusiasm.

**Dermot and Carmel**

That morning, Dermot thought Carmel seemed a bit strange. He had mentioned twice that he might be late and that he might stop by the golf club on his way home to chat with someone. Carmel had nodded politely, as if she didn’t really understand. Dermot asked her, “Will you be okay? What are your plans for today?” She smiled and replied, “It’s funny you ask. I was just thinking I have nothing to do today, so I’ll take a walk downtown and look at the shops. I feel like it’s almost a waste to spend the day doing nothing.” Dermot smiled back and said, “You deserve to enjoy yourself. And if I’m late, I won’t need any food, so don’t worry about it.” “That’s fine,” she replied.

**Title Race**

“Tea boy? Do you mind? I’m a mobile lukewarm beverage resource facilitator.” Human nature often leads to amusing situations. A recent study revealed that job titles are a major source of jealousy and dissatisfaction at work. A survey by a well-known recruitment firm found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees believe that job titles create divisions among coworkers. Surprisingly, 70% of office workers said they would give up a pay raise for a more appealing or professional job title. If our desire for recognition is so strong that it overshadows our basic need for money, we are in a troubling situation. In the early twenty-first century, no one wants to be called “subordinate.” The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just fancy words.

**The Vienna Assignment**

I was in Vienna to take photographs, which was usually why I traveled. Photography was not just my job; it was a big part of my life. I was always inspired by how light fell on different surfaces. I believed that a single photograph could capture the essence of a moment, a place, or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect shot, as long as I had film in my camera. My approach was simple: finish one roll, load another, and keep my eyes open. This had been my way of working for a long time.

Once, I got lucky when a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well became very popular, appearing in newspapers and magazines worldwide. It was a brief moment of fame, but I knew that you create your own luck, both good and bad. After that, I decided to work as a freelance photographer, which seemed like a smart choice. However, life took some unexpected turns, and the mid-nineties were not as successful as I had hoped, especially after my photo made the cover of Time magazine. That’s why I found myself in Vienna instead of somewhere more exciting. But I was still taking photographs and getting paid for it, which I thought was good.

This assignment came about by chance. I had taken photos for a coffee-table book called *Four Cities in Four Seasons*, which featured London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. I had received a nice payment for capturing my city in different seasons. I had my own unique style, showing the beauty of daffodils in Hyde Park and the heat haze in Piccadilly. I accepted that some of my best work would be overlooked since it was just a picture book, not meant to challenge anyone’s views.

After a cold snap over Christmas, I submitted my winter photos of London and learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left his job in Vienna for reasons I wasn’t told. Instead of hiring someone new, they offered me the job. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, unlike the French and Italian photographers. I was eager to go because things at home were not going well. A week in snowy Vienna sounded like a great opportunity.

They arranged for me to stay at the Europa hotel in the old city. My last visit to Vienna had been a busy summer trip with my wife, where we rushed through many palaces and museums. It was hot and chaotic, and I hadn’t taken many photos. This time, being alone in the cold January weather would be different. I felt excited as soon as I arrived and saw the beautiful light over the snow-covered roofs. I was ready to take some amazing pictures.

On my first day, I didn’t rush to take photos. Instead, I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, getting on and off to experience the city’s atmosphere. The weather was cold and still, reflecting the grand history of the city. I hadn’t seen what Schussner had captured in the other seasons, and I didn’t want to. This was going to be my Vienna, and I was determined to let it reveal itself to me. 

A photograph captures a moment, but you have to wait for the right moment to come. So, I took my time, observing everything until I felt ready. The next morning, I woke up early. The overnight snow made Stephansplatz beautifully white and almost empty. I struggled to find a way to photograph the cathedral, which towered high into the grey sky but appeared massive at ground level. I realized I might have to focus on just part of it. In that weather and at that time, it could still be magical.

Photography has always had a sense of magic. Even the early photographers felt this before they fully understood the chemistry behind it. You can watch a blank sheet of paper turn into a photograph in a dark room, and even when you know how it works, the mystery remains. Perhaps that’s why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn’t surprise me in a strange way.

**Kinetic Art**

Exciting news: London's Hayward Gallery has changed from a serious space into one full of wonder. This transformation is not due to a big-budget show, but rather a unique exploration of a lesser-known part of the last 60 years. A new exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art, which is art that involves movement, throughout the twentieth century. It shows that creating art that moves on its own or explores the idea of movement has been a consistent, though often overlooked, theme in some of the most interesting creative work of this century. 

Curator Guy Brett, who has studied this subject for many years, has gathered a wonderful collection of paintings, drawings, documents, and films about kinetic art. These are mostly presented without much text, allowing visitors to enjoy discovering and connecting ideas on their own.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney's art attracts many people who might not usually be interested in art. This could be because his work is figurative and easy to understand, or because it offers an escape from daily life with its themes of leisure and relaxation. Some people might even be drawn to Hockney's lively personality and humor, which make him popular in the media. However, this raises the question: does this popularity mean his art lacks depth? 

Some critics believe Hockney is an overrated artist. In response, one could argue that his popularity today might be seen as a negative rather than a reflection of his artistic value. Hockney himself is aware of his limitations and believes it is not fair to judge his work based on an abstract idea of greatness. He does not claim to be a great artist and understands that only future generations can truly judge his importance.

**Window-shopping - An Art Exhibition**

In recent years, I have attended many contemporary art exhibitions, some brilliant and others mediocre. What frustrates me are shows that seem to push a specific agenda, suggesting a common viewpoint among certain artists. Sometimes this approach works, revealing new trends in seemingly unrelated works. More often, it highlights a questionable angle or a forced concept. 

As a curator, I wanted to create a show that opposed this trend. Along with seven artists, I took over an empty warehouse space for an exhibition called "Window-shopping." This was meant to showcase individual artworks that connected only by being labeled as art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats chased each other on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley filmed a video camera, opening it up and poking around until it broke, creating a flickering display on a monitor. 

These works did not fit into a specific theme and would not usually be shown together, but I believe they complemented each other through their differences. While I did not make grand statements about contemporary art, I think it is important to recognize that art is often an individual activity where artists set their own rules.

**Art History**

People who enjoy paintings sometimes hesitate to analyze them, fearing it will ruin their enjoyment. Some believe that art historians, who focus on theory rather than practice, overlook the joy of viewing art and the special act of creating it. This idea is similar to thinking that knowing a recipe and cooking method takes away from the taste of a dish. 

Understanding the importance of enjoyment does not mean we cannot also have a deep knowledge of what we are experiencing. In fact, knowing more about an artwork can enhance our pleasure. Additionally, our enjoyment is complex. How we respond to art is influenced by our senses and is shaped by the values of the society we live in. 

While it is essential to appreciate our instinctive reactions to art, the belief that intellectual understanding diminishes enjoyment comes from a past view that saw art as separate from thought.

**Metals**  
Stone Age people may have been interested in metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. While sitting by a river, waiting for fish, one of our early ancestors might have found a shiny yellow stone and picked it up. This stone felt different from regular stones and was very attractive. This could be how gold first became important to early humans. Because gold is easy to shape, it quickly became a popular material. Copper might have also been discovered by chance, and once people realized how useful copper tools were, they actively searched for copper ores and ways to extract the metal. This led to the development of metalworking, which improved the lives of our ancestors.

**St Ives**  
We walked quietly down the narrow, cobbled street that led to the center of St Ives, struggling against the strong wind and trying to avoid the cold waves crashing over the walkway. The streets were empty, and all the windows of the houses by the water were tightly shut against the storm. We had seen the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on a small train. With the dark clouds gathering, visiting Cornwall in the off-season without a car didn’t seem like a good idea anymore. I had convinced my friend to come with me by promising beautiful walks along the Cornish coast and cozy evenings by the fire.

**Computer Modelling**  
Studying the past is challenging because it is gone. The people who lived during peaceful times or faced hardships are no longer alive. The reasons they settled in certain places or formed families and communities have been forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we cannot test our ideas with experiments on past cultures. We cannot go back in time to see what happened. However, computer modelling allows us to recreate ancient landscapes and environments, filling them with virtual communities that have some of the needs and abilities of real humans. We can set rules for these communities and simulate social groups. Then, we can change the weather or increase the population and observe how these digital societies and their artificial people respond.

**Vervet Monkeys**  
Cheney and Seyfarth studied a group of vervet monkeys and observed an interesting event. One day, the dominant male noticed a strange male monkey nearby, who seemed interested in joining their group. If the stranger succeeded, the current dominant male could lose his position. To keep the stranger away, the dominant male cleverly made an alarm call that vervet monkeys use to warn of a leopard. This made the stranger retreat back into the trees. The dominant male repeated this tactic whenever the stranger approached. However, he made a mistake when he called out the alarm while walking across the open ground himself.

**What Cats Catch**  
In a survey conducted in the village of Felmersham, 70 cats were observed over a year, and they caught over 1,000 prey items. An American professor estimated that this means cats in Britain could be killing around 100 million birds and small mammals each year. However, this number is misleading. Most cats live in towns and catch fewer animals than those in the survey. The important question is whether these numbers are sustainable. The answer seems to be yes. In winter, many people feed birds, and gardens provide nesting sites, which helps keep bird populations above natural levels. The survey showed that while cats are significant predators, they are not destroying Britain's bird population.

**Buffalo's Day**  
Buffaloes are very important to the marshmen, and they are treated with great care. Each morning, the buffaloes, who often sleep near their owners, slowly leave their resting place to go to the reed beds beyond the water. They take their time, groaning about the tiring day ahead, until the leader finally steps forward and enters the water. Once in the water, they seem to forget their purpose and relax, making low sounds of complaint. Their movements away from the house are so slow that they go almost unnoticed, but eventually, they are swimming, barely keeping their noses above the water. They spend the day among the reeds, grazing on whatever green shoots they can find.

**Picasso, Pablo**  
In early spring 1940, while staying in the fishing port of Royan, Picasso painted several still lifes of fish. One painting shows a fishmonger’s slab with a crab and some soles on scales. Despite being on the slab, the fish appear alive. The painting is complex, with overlapping transparent shapes and delicate colors that create a calm underwater scene. However, there is tension in the painting, as the fish seem to be preparing for a fight with the crab. The sharp shapes and the chain around one fish add a sense of danger, suggesting an underlying violence in the scene.

**Photography**

Over the last 150 years, photography has been used to capture all parts of human life and activities. In this relatively short time, photography has improved its ability to record moments in time and space, allowing us to see both large and small details. It has given us images from faraway places, distant parts of the solar system, and the complex social issues of modern life. Photography has become one of the most important ways to express what it means to be human.

However, the idea of recording events visually has a much longer history. The first pictorial records date back to the Upper Paleolithic period, around 35,000 years ago. We cannot be sure why early cave paintings were created. They might have recorded actual hunting events, served as magic to help with hunting, acted as religious symbols, or simply brightened daily life. Nevertheless, visual images are deeply connected to human culture.

Throughout history, people have questioned how accurate visual images are and what role they play in society. The saying "seeing is believing" has always given special importance to visual images. When photography was invented in the mid-1800s, it seemed to promise a truthful visual record. It was seen as the peak of Western visual representation, with the camera working like the human eye to create fixed images that closely resembled what we see. The chemical process used to fix images allowed for the capture of what we consider natural phenomena.

At the same time, photography was viewed as a sophisticated cultural achievement, producing images that artists had struggled for centuries to create. Ironically, because photography seemed so realistic, it was thought that everyone could easily understand photographs. This led to the idea that photography might be a "universal language." For instance, in 1933, photographer August Sander suggested that even the most isolated person could understand a photograph of the sky, whether it showed the sun, moon, or stars.

However, as global communication increased in the late twentieth century, we must consider how well photographic images can cross cultural differences. Is photography as influenced by cultural norms as other forms of communication, like language? Has our familiarity with photographs made us overlook the complex ways they convey vivid impressions of reality?

Photography is often seen as providing convincing evidence, making it seem like a clear window into reality. For example, it is common for someone to show a photograph and say, "This is my grandson." Since its invention in 1839, photography and the attitudes of those who use it have changed significantly. This change may be partly because photography has moved into what we might call "mythic time." Its original role as a record-keeper has evolved, and photographs, once closely tied to the photographer and subject, have become historical documents. These images often reveal as much about the people and society that created them as they do about their subjects.

I want to show that the camera is not just a silent recorder of events. Photography does not merely reflect culture; it can also inspire social and political change. For example, it is hard to imagine the cultural shifts of the Italian Renaissance without recognizing how the development of perspective changed visual representation. Similarly, photography has played a significant role in shaping the media culture of our time, while also bringing the harsh realities of the world into our everyday lives.

**How to Write Poetry**

Teaching people how to write poetry can be tricky. While creativity is important, making one mistake can lead to confusion. I believe that for beginners, the best advice is to read a lot, write often, and let your imagination flow freely, as long as it doesn’t lead to chaos. Some people need a stable life to write poetry, while others find inspiration in their struggles. Some writers follow a schedule, while others wait for a moment of inspiration. All approaches are valid, as long as they don’t follow strict rules. The key is to find your own voice, nurture it, and let it grow until it can stand on its own.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, it’s important not to overcrowd it with too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be brief and only used when necessary to clarify a point. One effective way to include a flashback is through a character’s memory, which can help move the story forward without slowing it down. Dialogue is also very useful; it can show different perspectives quickly and keep the reader engaged. Avoiding excessive writing is crucial, but being concise doesn’t mean the story should feel incomplete. A short story should maintain conflict and action just like a novel, but every word must be meaningful in a limited space.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay is similar to playing chess. Most players make moves without knowing exactly what will happen next. They might see a few moves ahead, but often they play without a clear plan. As players gain experience, they learn that chess is more about long-term strategy than short-term moves. They start to see the game as a whole, recognizing patterns and strategies. The same applies to screenplay writing; the more you practice, the more you understand its complexities.

**Looking at Writing**

Humans naturally communicate, as seen in how children talk. However, no child instinctively knows how to write. Charles Darwin noted that while language is a natural human instinct, writing is not. All societies have language, and while languages evolve, they do not necessarily become better. Children learn to speak without formal lessons, and when they lack a common language, they create their own. In contrast, writing systems have been developed only a few times in history and often started as simple codes. Until recently, many children did not learn to read or write, and even today, some struggle with it. Children are naturally inclined to speak, but learning to write is a skill that requires effort and instruction. We need to understand how writing works and how to help children learn it effectively.

I have never started a novel with so much uncertainty. If I call it a novel, it is only because I don’t know what else to call it. I have a small story to tell, and I do not end it with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader hanging. This book is about my memories of a man I met only occasionally, and I know little about what happened to him in between our meetings. I could invent details to make my story more complete, but I do not want to do that. I just want to share what I know.

To protect the privacy of living people, I have given the characters in this story names I made up, and I have taken care to ensure that no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous, and he may never be. When his life ends, he might leave no more mark on the world than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water's surface. If my book is read, it will be for its own interest. However, it is possible that his way of life and the unique qualities of his character may influence others, and long after he is gone, people may realize that a remarkable person lived in this time. Then it will be clear who I am writing about, and those who want to know about his early life may find something useful in my book.

I believe my book, despite its limitations, will be a helpful source for my friend’s biographers. I do not claim that the conversations I recorded are exact. I never took notes during our talks, but I remember well what matters to me. Although I have put these conversations in my own words, I believe they accurately reflect what was said. I mentioned earlier that I have invented nothing, but I have taken the liberty that historians do by putting words into the mouths of my characters that I did not hear. I did this to make the scenes more lively and believable, as they would be dull if simply told. I want my book to be engaging, and I think I am justified in making it readable. A thoughtful reader will easily see where I have used this technique and can choose to ignore it.

Another reason I feel nervous about this work is that the people I write about come from a different culture. It is hard to truly know people, and I believe we can only really know those from our own country. People are shaped not only by who they are but also by where they were born, the places they grew up, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they attended, the sports they followed, and the poets they read. These experiences shape who they are, and you cannot understand them just by hearing about them; you must live them. You can only know them if you are one of them. Because you can only understand people from a different nation through observation, it is challenging to portray them convincingly in a book. I have never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I have done so in short stories, it is because those allow for a more general approach. You can give broad descriptions and let the reader fill in the details. In this book, I do not claim that my characters see themselves as they truly are; they are seen through my own perspective, just like my main character.

**POETRY RECITALS**

Throughout history, the world of literature often seems confusing to those experiencing it. However, future generations can see clear patterns and important figures in literature. Today, the poetry scene is particularly complex, with many different styles, groups, and opinions about how poetry should be presented, criticized, and taught. 

A major discussion in contemporary poetry is the tension between serious 'literary' poets, who write poems meant to be read on the page, and 'popular' poets, who prefer to perform their work in front of an audience. This division is not strict. Over the last twenty years, public poetry readings have become more common in various forms. Small literary groups in towns hold readings in community centers or members' homes. Schools and colleges invite poets to speak to students, and arts festivals often feature readings by well-known poets.

The impact of these events, where poets often have to perform publicly, is complex and can have uncertain benefits. For 'pop' poets, who write specifically for live audiences, public performance is beneficial. Their poems are usually simple and can be understood easily in one hearing. However, when these poems are read on the page, their weaknesses in thought and creativity may become apparent.

On the other hand, dedicated poets, who strive to create deep and meaningful work, may not be appreciated by audiences who are hearing their poems for the first time. The risk is that these poets might choose to read only their simplest work to connect quickly with the audience, which may not represent their best writing.

Attending poetry readings cannot replace reading poetry from a book, but it can be a fun and educational experience. Hearing skilled poets read their work, even if they are not great speakers, helps the audience understand where to focus their attention. It is best if the audience has the text in front of them or knows the poems beforehand.

The main reason for popular poetry recitals, sometimes combined with music, is to help audiences enjoy poetry and see it as an art form for everyone, not just a select few.

**Oral History**  
Historians are increasingly using oral evidence, but this approach has its challenges. It is overly simplistic to think that a person's testimony is a clear reflection of their past experiences. During an interview, both the historian and the informant influence each other. The historian chooses who to interview and what topics to discuss. Even if the historian only listens, their presence can change how the informant remembers and talks about their past. The final account is shaped by the historian's social position and their understanding of history, which may also affect the informant's responses. Therefore, historians must acknowledge their role in creating new evidence. The challenges continue even after the historian leaves. The informant's memories are not direct connections to the past; they can be influenced by other sources, like the media, or colored by nostalgia or feelings of loss from their childhood. The emotions expressed can make the testimony seem convincing, but they may actually reflect later experiences rather than the time being discussed.

**Animal Science**  
Animal science has two main approaches: physiological and whole animal. Physiologists focus on how the body functions, including how nerves, muscles, and senses work together to create complex behaviors. Those who study the whole animal look at the behavior of animals in their natural state and the factors that influence it. Within this approach, there are psychologists and ethologists. Psychologists often conduct experiments in labs with a few species, like rats and pigeons, while ethologists study natural behaviors in wild animals. Although these two fields have different focuses, they are increasingly working together. Physiologists often claim that their methods are more fundamental, but understanding behavior also requires studying it at a behavioral level. Behavior has its own structure and elements that need to be examined. For example, trying to explain how a bird builds a nest by only looking at individual nerve cells would be like trying to read a book with a microscope.

**The Social Sciences**  
Students studying social sciences for the first time face a dual challenge. They need to learn both the content of their new subject and the methods used to study it. This means they must understand not only the knowledge found in textbooks but also how that knowledge is gathered and organized. These two aspects are closely connected. While we all have experiences in social life that may make social sciences seem like common sense, each discipline goes beyond this basic understanding. Each field focuses on specific aspects of social life, uses different research methods, and has its own concepts. These fundamental ideas form the "logical basis" of the subject, allowing social scientists to move beyond everyday understanding and differentiate one discipline from another.

**Classical Architecture**  
In the classical world of Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. According to the Roman architect Vitruvius, architecture involves Order, Arrangement, Proportion, Symmetry, Propriety, and Distribution. He also provided Greek equivalents for some of these terms, likely based on earlier Greek sources that are now lost. While utility and function are not part of his initial definition, Vitruvius later discusses the best designs for different types of buildings. At its core, his definition emphasizes the artistic aspect of architecture. The origins of classical architecture are complex, with a long history of simple structures in Greece and Italy that did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. Although these early buildings were not artistic, they contributed important elements that influenced later architectural ideas. Despite its elaborate appearance, the classical temple essentially resembles a simple, single-room hut.

The two sisters kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the gardens and the railway, even going over a small bridge with all four wheels in the air, which was her only mistake. After that, they would pass the gasworks, where there was a strong smell of sulphur. Surprisingly, Chen found it funny that Lily was driving without telling him. "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" he said. Mui thought it was strange that her brother-in-law was not upset. Instead, he was excited and made plans with Lily for a trip. They decided to go on a Monday at the start of next month, the quietest day of the week, leaving early and returning by noon to avoid losing customers. Meanwhile, Lily would practice driving around the gardens. Despite her doubts, Mui bought a road map and got a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen, although Lily felt a bit insulted by Mui's lack of trust in her navigation skills.

Within an hour of leaving home, they were looking at the English Channel. Lily drove very well. Even Mui, who was in the back seat ready to give directions, had to admit this. Lily even overtook a couple of slow cars with great skill, making Mui hold back her concerns. Chen even applauded her. After passing the gasworks and the lagoon with its small boats, they drove smoothly along the empty promenade. Lily parked in a quiet street with many empty spaces. She was unsure about the road signs and preferred to pay for parking rather than risk getting a ticket. She thought this might ease Mui's worries. 

While driving, Lily noticed her sister's tense face in the mirror. She decided not to add to Mui's worries. Lily carefully locked all the van doors and checked each one. "Don't worry," Chen joked. "No one will want that old thing." The sisters were annoyed. Lily accused Chen of being ungrateful, and Mui scolded him for being too easily fooled by appearances. Surprised, Chen took Man Kee to look at the grey sea. He held his son close and felt a strong bond with him. Man Kee, warm and responsive, placed his tiny hand on Chen's sleeve. In that moment, Chen decided to raise his son in his own way, giving him a good education in business, which was Chen's own weakness.

As Chen looked at the sea, he felt a mix of sadness and hope while planning Man Kee's future. He noticed smoke on the horizon and then saw a ship shining in the sunlight. He put a coin in a telescope and tried to find the ship. At first, he struggled, but then he spotted it—a large, rusty tramp steamer. He lifted Man Kee to the telescope. "Do you see the ship, Son?" he asked gently. "It's a special ship for people like us. It's small and old, but we know it will take us back home when we are done here. It will take you to your homeland, which you have never seen." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. 

Lily and Mui joined them, and Lily put her arm around Chen's shoulders. "The little old ship," Chen said. "Let your mother see, Son." Man Kee didn't want to let go of the telescope, and when he finally did, the view was just a blurry circle of light. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship had disappeared over the horizon, leaving Lily watching seagulls searching for food in the water.

**THE WELL**

I once read that if you dig deep enough, you can see the stars on a clear day. I convinced you to help me with my idea. You watched, surprised, as I pulled up the well bucket, balanced it on the wall, and then climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn’t consider how heavy the bucket would be or that you might not want to just let things happen. You held the handle, helping me as I pushed the bucket away from the well's edge. As soon as it was free, I fell. You screamed and tried to stop it, but then you let go. I fell into the well and hit my head. At that moment, I didn’t realize I had achieved part of my plan. I saw strange lights, confusing and odd. Later, I connected these lights to the cartoon stars I had seen when characters got hit on the head. At first, I was dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall and worried about what Mother would say. 

You called down to check if I was okay. I opened my mouth to shout, but then I heard panic in your voice, and I couldn’t speak. I lay still, peeking at you through my eyelashes. You disappeared, calling for help. I waited a moment, then quickly climbed back up and pulled myself over the edge, landing on the courtyard stones. I heard alarmed voices coming from the castle's main door. I ran the other way, down to the passage leading to the moat bridge, and hid in the shadows. Mother and Father appeared with you and old Arthur; Mother was screaming and waving her hands. Father shouted for Arthur to pull on the winch handle. You stood back, looking pale and shocked. I crouched in the shadows, feeling a rush of excitement. 

Then I noticed the drops of water I had left from the well to where I stood. I looked in horror at the dark spots of dirty water on the dry stones. At my feet, the water had formed a small pool. I looked back into the courtyard, where Father was shining a flashlight down into the well. The drops sparkled in the sunlight. I couldn’t believe no one had seen them. Mother was now screaming loudly, a sound I had never heard before. It shook me deeply. What was I supposed to do? I had gotten back at you, but now things were more serious than I expected. What started as a fun prank quickly turned into a situation that would lead to serious punishment, likely for me. I regretted not thinking this through. 

Suddenly, an idea came to me like a lifeline. I gathered my courage and left my hiding place, staggering out and blinking. I called out softly, one hand on my forehead, then yelled louder when no one responded. I stumbled a bit further and then dramatically collapsed on the stones. Sitting up, comforted by my crying mother, I sighed and said, "Oh dear," smiling bravely. I claimed that I had found a secret tunnel from the bottom of the well to the moat, and that I crawled and swam through it until I got out and climbed up the bridge. I thought I was almost getting away with it until Father squatted in front of me. He made me repeat my story. I hesitated. His eyes narrowed. Thinking I was filling in gaps, I said the secret passage had collapsed after me; there was no point in sending someone to look for it. I insisted the well was dangerous and that I had barely escaped with my life. 

Looking into my father's eyes felt like staring into a dark tunnel with no light at the end. It was as if he was seeing me for the first time, and I was seeing the world from an adult's perspective. My words got stuck in my throat. "Don't be ridiculous, boy," he said, his tone full of contempt. He stood up and walked away. Arthur looked down at me, his expression sad and troubled. He seemed to want to shake his head, not because I had a scary adventure and was unfairly disbelieved by my father, but because he could see through my desperate lie. He worried about the character and future of a child who lied so easily. His pity felt like a harsh rebuke, even more painful than my father's words. It made me realize that this was the mature judgment of my actions, and it affected me deeply.

**REMOVAL DAY**

Now that her children are grown, Susan, who is a widow, must leave her family home. The moving van had the words 'Removers of Distinction' on it, and indeed, everything that made the house special was being taken away. Fred, the removal man, carefully packed all the fragile items, while his helpers were not as gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-story house that overlooked a small harbor. The memories of her children growing up there lingered in the air, like dust.

When they first bought the house, her son Robert, who was five at the time, had asked, "Mum, how do you get a house home?" It was easy to miss the little boy he used to be, especially now that he was an adult helping with the move. He was particularly focused on making sure Susan didn’t forget about the piano. Francesca, their daughter, was also there, helping in her usual bossy way, convinced that only she could take care of the valuable Steinway piano.

Fred noticed Susan was not crying and commented, "That's something." Curious, Susan asked if people usually cried during moves. Fred replied, "You'd be surprised. They seem happy while packing, but then they cry in an empty room. They feel fine once they reach the new place; it’s just hard to see everything taken apart."

Susan could understand that feeling. If she had been alone, she would have warned the movers about the piano before agreeing to the move. But Robert insisted it was the movers' responsibility to notice any issues. The piano stood alone in the upstairs sitting room, the best room in the house, and they planned to move it last.

Sitting on the bottom stair, with all the chairs gone, Susan remembered the day they moved in. Today felt like that day played in reverse—the piano had been the first item brought in, but it got stuck on the stairs. The movers struggled for nearly two hours, trying to get it up. Little Robert watched in fascination while Francesca cried, "We can't live in a house without a piano! We can't! I'd rather die!" They had to find a way to get it inside, especially since Francesca was destined to be a concert pianist.

Peter, her late husband, had come home to help solve the problem. They left the piano outside while bringing in the other furniture. The next day, a builder was hired to remove the first-floor window. A crane was borrowed from the quay below, and with the help of a local farmer's tractor, they managed to lift the piano through the window. The children were overjoyed to see it finally inside. However, the whole process was expensive, and it took months before they could afford to have the piano tuned.

"That's that," Peter had said. "That's there forever." But forever is a long time. The children became too busy to visit on weekends, and Susan found it harder to move around the house. She was out of breath climbing the stairs. The thought of the stairs reminded her that the banister rails had never been perfectly fixed after the move. She should have warned the movers about the piano, but now it was too late. Any moment now, they would discover it.

"Are you all right, love?" Fred asked. "Just the piano left, and then we'll be on our way." Susan moved away from the stairs, her heart racing. Robert and Francesca appeared in the hallway to watch. "No tears then?" Fred asked casually. Truthfully, she was close to crying. It was strange how moving things made them feel so important. Chairs, cups, and countless other items that seemed unimportant while they were in place now felt full of emotion, begging for care. She felt she might cry at any moment.

Just then, the piano appeared, being carefully moved down the stairs by Fred and another mover. "Easy does it!" Fred called out as they brought it down and out the front door, placing it behind the van. Robert was the first to laugh, and soon they were all laughing, relieved that it was over. They leaned against each other, gasping for breath and laughing uncontrollably. "What's the joke?" Fred asked, but his question only made them laugh more. As they walked down the path for the last time, the only tears Susan shed were tears of laughter.

**Online Literary Criticism for Everyone: Is DIY Literary Criticism Just Fun?**

From the beginning, one of the main ideas behind the Internet was that it should be open to everyone. In theory, anyone could publish their thoughts or share music online. However, in the early days, some technical skills were needed. Still, one area that became accessible to many was literary criticism. By visiting Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could try writing book reviews. 

Amazon allowed anyone to share their opinions about books and give them up to five stars. This seemed like a great idea because it meant that readers could see what others thought about a book, rather than just relying on the publisher's description or professional critics. Other online bookstores also offered similar features, but Amazon was the largest, controlling over 80% of the online market. This popularity led to some problems, as many reviews were submitted each day, making it hard to check them all. 

Amazon had a team of editors who ensured that reviews followed certain rules. For example, one-word reviews or personal attacks on authors were not allowed. Reviews that contained bad language, revealed the ending of a book, or referenced other reviews were also banned. However, since reviewers could remain anonymous, it was easy for some to misuse the system. For instance, authors could write positive reviews of their own books. 

One author, Lev Grossman, was upset by the negative reviews of his first novel, so he wrote some positive ones under a fake name to balance things out. His trick worked until he wrote an article about it, and then Amazon removed the fake reviews. Authors could also comment on their own books through a special link, but Amazon did not always verify that these comments were genuinely from the authors. 

In one case, a lesser-known writer pretended to be famous author John Updike in a comment, but it was quickly identified as fake and removed. The real drama often came from readers, not authors. For example, when James McElroy's book about a cheerleading team was published, it received good reviews from the press, but many people mentioned in the book felt hurt and expressed their anger through negative reviews on Amazon. These reviews often disappeared after a few days. 

Despite these issues, Amazon saw the large number of reviews as beneficial for business. They wanted reviews to be a place for discussing books, not just casual chatting. Therefore, they monitored bestselling books closely to ensure that all reviews followed the rules. This meant that silly reviews were more likely to appear on pages for less popular books. 

One classic children's book, *The Story about Ping*, inspired humorous reviews because "ping" is also a term used in technology. One long review compared the book's story to Internet architecture, humorously suggesting it offered a good overview of networking concepts. However, such silliness was rare. Most reviews on Amazon were taken seriously by their writers and provided a good indication of whether a book was worth buying. 

The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books made it hard to have genuine feelings about them. This highlights the importance of allowing everyone to participate in the review process.

**Art in Modern Times**

In recent years, especially over the last two hundred years, we often think that every artist must challenge the art of their time. Art is celebrated for being unique, revolutionary, and sometimes shocking. We enjoy admiring artists whose work was not valued in the past. However, when it comes to contemporary art, we often hesitate and claim that some artists have gone too far, suggesting that their work is no longer art. The media often expresses these views for us, and we tend to agree because we expect art to constantly surprise us. This expectation makes us overlook the traditional themes, methods, and qualities that are still present in today’s art.

We expect artists to be different from ordinary people, possessing special talents and energy that break free from conventions. In the past, people commissioned artists for specific purposes, and art was a part of everyday life. Today, we leave artists to work independently and often become frustrated if they try to connect with us.

**Picture This**

I will describe a situation and then ask an important question. An artist selects a piece of text from an art book that discusses the variety of pictures. The text asks, "What are they all about?" and concludes, "There is no end to the different kinds of pictures." This language may seem childish, but bear with me. 

After choosing the text, the artist asks someone to prepare a canvas and then to take it to a sign painter. He instructs the sign painter to write the text on the canvas in simple black letters without any fancy designs. The sign painter follows these instructions. The question is: is the final product a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery in London, there is an unspoken rule for painters: once you find success in one style, you should stick to it. Collectors expect artists to continue producing similar work, and if they try something new, it can lead to disappointment among the public. I’m not sure why this is the case. Gallery owners prefer safe choices, and perhaps art buyers feel more secure with familiar styles. However, some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, successfully break this pattern. 

Eric Rimmington is another artist who is trying something different. His new exhibition replaces the still lifes that made him famous with paintings inspired by the London Underground. Rimmington finds a unique charm in railways. His earlier drawings of King's Cross Station led him to explore the underground world. This has resulted in "Underground Encounters," an exhibition of 40 paintings and drawings that capture the fascinating atmosphere of this hidden world designed for people on the move.

**Extract from a Novel**

I have come to this island with a few books. I use the word "escape" because the villagers jokingly say that only a sick person would choose such a remote place to recover. So, I have come here to heal myself, if you want to see it that way. Besides an old peasant who comes daily on her mule to clean, I am quite alone. I feel neither happy nor sad; I am suspended in a mix of memories.

I mentioned the uselessness of art but did not speak about its comforts. The true comfort of my work as an artist lies in the fact that, in the quiet moments of painting or writing, reality can be reshaped and revealed in a meaningful way. Our everyday actions often hide the deeper meaning of life. For artists, art offers a joyful way to confront the pain and struggles of daily life, allowing us to fulfill our true potential through imagination. Otherwise, why would we hurt one another?

**Family Business**

"Listen, this isn't good!" my dad said. We were driving back to London after I had just finished my time at a fancy girls' school. My father, along with my brother Maurice, had picked me up and I had received awards for Latin and for being the top student in my exams. After a long talk with my headteacher, we were now heading home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, although I had a feeling I knew what he was thinking. Usually, my dad was very talkative, but he was quiet now. "You can't trick me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you might get a scholarship to Oxford."

"So?" I replied, trying to act tough. "Isn't that useful?" 

"I also heard," he continued, and I knew a serious conversation was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister!" My dad knew a lot about lawyers and the law. 

"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else!" 

"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality. You can quickly understand complex information, you’re good at speaking, and you enjoy performing." 

"I’m not sure about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV dramas." 

"Regardless," he said, gathering himself, "I feel like your heart isn't in the family business. You’ll go to Oxford, and after that, I doubt you’ll want to join us." 

The truth was, like many children in family businesses, I felt trapped by my father's expectations. I saw many career options for myself and wanted to explore them. But, like a coward, I didn’t want to upset my dad. I wasn’t as scared of him as Maurice was—I was the favorite—but I still found him intimidating. 

"It's too early to know," I said weakly. 

"I tell you, you won’t want to join us," my father said, who often turned out to be right about such things. "It’s a shame because you have the talent—the intelligence, the courage, the vision." 

"There's still Maurice," I said, feeling down. My father scoffed. We both knew Maurice disliked the business. 

"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a consultant." My mother had passed away when I was young, and my father had raised me and Maurice. I was two years older than Maurice, and I had taken care of him since we lost our mother. It wasn’t hard; I loved him. 

Because the business was successful, we lived comfortably—in a large house in London, attended good schools, wore nice clothes, and enjoyed parties, theaters, and operas. My father knew many interesting people—politicians, actors, and business leaders—and our home was always lively with great conversations.

"I have an idea," my father said. "You can help us during the holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you want to leave, you can. It will give you some pocket money and really help me." 

"Okay," I said, relieved to avoid making immediate choices and especially to avoid the sadness my father would feel if I disagreed with him. This was how he controlled us. 

So, that’s what happened. In my last term at school and during university breaks, I helped out, but only a couple of times a year and always with easier tasks. I became one of the top students, had a small house, a nice car, designer clothes, and a black dress from Paris that I planned to wear for my final exams.

In my last term, my father visited me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. With only a few weeks left, my tutor predicted I would earn a First Class degree in Law. I felt ready and focused. 

Then my father told me that he needed me to do one last important task for the family business, the biggest one they had ever attempted, and he promised it would be worth my while. 

"But Dad," I protested, "I have my final exams coming up, and I need to focus on that. It’s really important for me to do well, and I don’t want to think about anything else right now." 

I could tell my father didn’t understand the pressure I was under (or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him), and he would see my refusal as a betrayal. As he explained the task, I realized more than ever how determined he was—the clarity and skill with which he approached his work, his energy, and his self-control. In his own way, he was a genius, and I admired that in him. It made my own dreams seem less significant. 

"Okay," I said. "I’ll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with Lois. Owning something that requires strict budgeting is often not worth it. At the time, however, it seemed like a smart and desirable choice. Simon had been winning cases regularly, and Lois had returned to her job at the advertising agency just two months after giving birth to their twins, receiving a salary increase to thirty-five thousand. Lois strongly pushed for the move, and Simon did not resist her arguments, which seemed convincing at the time: their flat was not suitable for a family, they needed more space, a garden, and separate accommodation for an au pair. They could have found these in a suburb or a less trendy part of London, but Lois wanted more than just extra space. Mornington Mansions was not a suitable address for a rising barrister and a successful businesswoman. Even saying the name made her feel like it lowered her social and economic status.

Lois decided that one of them should save money by using public transport, and it was clear that Simon would be the one to do so since her office was on the other side of London. The crowded tube ride became a frustrating thirty minutes of thinking about his dissatisfaction. He often remembered his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he stayed as a boy, the smell of dinner cooking, and his grandmother's care for the tired breadwinner returning from work. She had been a supportive lawyer's wife, always involved in legal causes and content with her life. But that world was gone. Lois had made it clear before they married that her career was just as important as his. This was a modern marriage, and both of their jobs were crucial for their lifestyle, which depended on two incomes. Now, their hard work could be threatened by Venetia, who had come to their office in a bad mood after court. 

Venetia confronted Simon with intense anger, accusing him of wrongdoing. He regretted not leaving his room earlier, thinking that if he had, she might have calmed down overnight. He remembered her accusations clearly: she claimed that a client, Brian Cartwright, said Simon knew about jury bribery four years ago and did nothing. Simon denied it instinctively, but his denial felt unconvincing even to him. He felt guilty and ashamed, recalling the fear of punishment from his school days. When he looked into Venetia's eyes, he saw her disbelief. He wished he had said, "Cartwright told me after the trial, but I didn't believe him then or now." Instead, he had told a more dangerous lie, and she recognized it. 

He wondered why Venetia was so angry and if she had the right to judge him. Was her own behavior in court always perfect? Did she have the right to ruin his career? He was uncertain about what she could do, but if rumors spread, it could destroy him.

I chose to live in this place because I thought I could be anonymous among people who didn’t mind if their rented homes were falling apart or if their gardens were messy. I was wrong. The shopkeepers, who are living their real lives, soon start to recognize me, even if I try to stay hidden. The beautiful roses from my neighbor’s garden remind me that gardens can be loved. Usually, I stay inside to forget about the summer outside, but tonight I am watching the swifts flying between the trees and roofs. I have trimmed some herbs to make space for a chair, and my arms are stinging from scratches. 

It’s a small London garden where plants have to grow tall or spread out to survive. My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of her window and comments on my gardening. She is a writer with several unpublished works, and I sometimes help her with them as an English teacher. I have her latest manuscript with me. “How’s the writing going, Jaz?” I ask. She complains about how people constantly ask her about her work. “I have something to drink in the fridge. I’ll bring it down,” she says. I don’t want her in the garden, and I realize it looks messy. Jaz knocks on my door. 

“So, you’re on holiday now, lucky you,” she says as she sits in the chair while I drop a cushion onto what used to be a small lawn. “Cheers,” she says, pretending to be young. “I should’ve gone into teaching – writers don’t get holidays. But you know what they say, those who can, do; those who can’t, teach.” And then there are those who can do neither. “What are your plans for the holidays?” she asks. I feel overwhelmed by the empty days ahead. 

“Actually, I’m going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed my cats?” I ask. My heart races as I speak. “Of course,” Jaz replies, knowing she will be around. “Where will you stay? A fancy B and B?” “No, I’ll be with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We’ve known each other since we were kids.” This isn’t true, but I often deal with fiction. 

“Going back to your roots. What do you think of my manuscript?” Jaz asks about her work, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I haven’t read much of. I like the title and tell her so. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing gifts to other houses while delivering her rejected manuscripts. I decide to be honest for once. “Let me give you a little tip,” I say. “What?” she asks, looking offended. “Try writing about nice people for a change, those who want to be good: a bit less self-centeredness, more fiction…” 

“Teachers!” Jaz responds like a rebellious student. “I keep a journal where I write something good about each day,” I say, sounding a bit old-fashioned. “Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.” Oh, I have a life. I work, go out sometimes, and read on the tube. When we finally go inside, my calm kitchen gives me a moment of comfort, but suddenly I remember my old geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now. She once winked at us and said, “I’ve had my moments.” We were shocked.

**Heritage**

Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to their past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage, knowing about our grandparents and hearing stories about their lives. However, there is also a broader need to understand our history to help us shape our future, both individually and nationally. Heritage represents a desire for continuity; knowing about the past helps us feel secure about the future. Just as we inherit our genes, we also inherit a culture that has been passed down through generations. While there may be aspects of our national heritage that we do not like, it is still a part of us, and it is comforting to belong to something larger. Heritage teaches us a lot and is essential for our well-being, influencing everything from traditions to material culture. 

In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories and legends from our ancestors. However, modern society has disrupted many communities and families, leading to a loss of this oral tradition. Now, we often rely on places and buildings to remind us of our past. It is crucial to preserve these connections as a tribute to our ancestors' identities.

**The Fens**

Some time ago, I started writing a novel called *Waterland*, where the landscape of a region in England known as the Fens became very important. After the book was published, people often asked why I, a Londoner with no personal ties to the area, chose to write about it. The simple answer is that I found the Fens interesting because they seemed like a blank canvas for my story. However, I soon realized that the Fens are not just flat and empty; they are rich and strangely beautiful. It is surprising that in the heart of England, there is a place that many English people find unfamiliar, especially since many other unique areas of Britain have become part of the national culture. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated yet wild, seemingly simple but deeply mysterious. 

While writing my novel, I did not explore the Fens extensively; I have not yet visited places like Wisbech or Prickwillow. As a fiction writer, I prefer to create imagined worlds rather than seek strict evidence. However, trying to envision the Fens has its own logic, as they are not just a landscape but also a state of mind.

**Museums**

Museums need to make their collections easy to access. In the past, this meant simply putting items in display cases with long descriptions that were hard for most people to understand. Today, accessibility should involve more than that. Displays can be engaging and use creative techniques to attract visitors and evoke emotions. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, some museums provide loan boxes of objects for teachers and have started offering similar materials for elderly people with memory loss. 

Museums focus on real artifacts and specimens, not replicas. They exist to provide an authentic experience, showcasing items that have historical significance. This authenticity is what sets them apart from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and digital media. Museums that embrace this challenge and create exciting displays and outreach programs will find that their competitors in "virtual history" can actually help spark interest in the real experiences that museums uniquely offer.

**Architecture and Environment**

The desire to preserve our surroundings is not new, but changes in our towns happen so quickly and on such a large scale that they affect everyone. This rapid change can make some people very protective of what they want to keep, while it encourages others to think more deeply about the nature of our towns and their future. It can be argued that people who have lived through significant events, like world wars, are more inclined to value preservation because stability becomes important to them. If there is a psychological need for preservation, planners must consider it. Change is not necessarily bad if we learn how to manage it. Changes in our towns reflect social changes, including shifts in population, welfare, and needs.

**Einstein**

If you stop someone on the street and ask them to name a scientist, they will likely say Albert Einstein. His image is often used to promote products that suggest intelligence, like computers and encyclopedias. Most people know little about Einstein's work, except that he created complex theories called 'relativity', which are known for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that seem to go against common sense. Einstein was part of a major change in scientific thought, a revolution that led to the development of modern science in the twentieth century. Physicists and mathematicians were trying to create a new, clearer understanding of the universe by examining the relationships between matter and natural forces. Einstein made significant contributions by rethinking the basics: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, scientists followed Isaac Newton's idea of a universe where stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, arguing that time and space are not fixed but relative.

**Young Readers**

As children, Lydia and I often distrusted any book that won awards because we thought it would be boring. Our mother disapproved of our attitude, while our father would give us small coins as rewards for reading certain books. He sometimes included a few better books in our Christmas and birthday gifts, marked with a note saying, 'This Book is NOT Literature'. Although we often dismissed his choices as 'boys' books', he did introduce us to some shorter, good fiction and, once, to a famous collection of poetry.

**Language**

Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851 that the origin of human language is both secret and amazing. This mystery has led to many strange ideas. For example, Charles Caller suggested in 1928 that early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they sensed danger. This sound is sad and reflects the fear of early humans living in dangerous environments. Some words in languages, like 'malaria' meaning "fever" or the Latin 'mors' meaning "death", echo this ancient fear. Because of such odd theories, many people avoided discussing the topic, seeing it as a place for odd ideas. However, recently, the study of how language began and evolved has become an important area of research. Language likely developed in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. Initially, speech was mainly used for friendly communication and played a key role in power struggles. Sharing information was probably not the main purpose of early language, which goes against the ideas of philosopher John Locke, who viewed language as a major way to share knowledge.

**Writing Reviews**

Frank Kermode looks at the art of writing reviews from the perspective of someone who does it. Most reviews are created and shared in ways that limit their lifespan. They often have strict deadlines and length restrictions, and once published, they only stay relevant for a short time—usually a day, a week, or at most a month. Because of this, the literary value of reviews is often seen as low. Many people, including the writers themselves, believe that reviewing is something people do only for specific reasons, like needing money or because they cannot spend all their time on a novel or serious book. However, writing reviews is a skilled and complex task.

Writing a concise review of six to eight hundred words for a newspaper is different from writing a longer piece of six to eight thousand words for an international journal. A review of fifteen hundred words in a weekly magazine combines challenges from both short and long formats. Length is not the only factor to consider. Reviewers must think about their audience, which can range from casual readers to those deeply interested in the subject. Additionally, a reviewer needs to have knowledge about various topics and must write in a way that intelligent readers can understand and enjoy.

It is common for reviewers to also write other types of work. For example, American novelist John Updike, who is not very fond of criticism, still enjoys writing reviews between his novel projects. He collects all his reviews, no matter how short, into books with modest titles. While some may think that less prominent writers should accept the temporary nature of their reviews, it is understandable that they want some lasting recognition, especially if they believe their best writing is hidden in those reviews.

I feel this way about my own work. My main focus has been academic writing, and my serious books are typically academic in nature, which is what professors are expected to produce. However, in the English-speaking world, there is no strict separation between reviewing and literary study, so it is common for the same people to do both. The time has passed when academics criticized reviewer-professors for showing off or wasting time. Complaints from non-professors about professors taking opportunities away from them are also less frequent, partly because there are more reviewing opportunities now, and partly because the rewards are often small.

I believe this situation benefits both readers and professors. Readers can trust that reviewers have some expertise, and for professors, reviewing helps maintain their sanity. It also serves as a reminder that they should communicate clearly with non-professors. While they may enjoy using complex language among themselves, they need to ensure they are understandable when speaking to a broader audience. Ultimately, despite its value, reviewing is usually a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also engaged in another primary occupation.

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and, as he stepped into the dark, quiet hallway, he felt a brief sense of ownership. Even after three years, this feeling sometimes hit him when he returned home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he would come home excited and curious, wondering what had happened in his absence. The flat felt like a welcoming place, a space where he could focus without distractions. He thought he should worry about possible intruders or broken pipes, but his flat always seemed to wait for him, either looking independent or neglected, depending on how tidy he had left it.

Over time, he began to see it as an extension of himself, a place where his thoughts and feelings overflowed. He grew frustrated with its inability to change. There was often a small pile of letters by the door and the answering machine would sometimes blink to life when he returned. He was thankful that his windows were intact and that nothing had been violently disturbed, though he often wondered what the flat would look like if that happened.

From his dull office on the third floor, Ralph looked forward to his few quiet evenings at home each week. After leaving the busy office, he felt a sense of himself returning during his bus ride home. However, he often found himself craving solitude, wanting time alone with his belongings. Yet, once he escaped, he felt drained and waited in vain for a sense of identity to return. Instead, he felt a deep emptiness, making him suspect that the unfulfilling work he did had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was.

As the night went on, he would read or listen to music, but he began to question for whom or what he was doing these things. His sense of direction in life had faded, and his thoughts would come and go without finding a clear path. He remembered a time when he felt more in control, when he might have recognized his own worth and found a way out. But he had been so eager to improve his life that he followed the first opportunity that came his way, as if it was meant to be.

After university, he had tried to create a plan for a better future, but he was not surprised to find that his true desire was simply to get by. He applied for jobs he learned about from his friends, following their lead as they rushed toward their goals, unable to imagine that he could find a job that would also make him happy. He attended one interview with gratitude, not thinking to evaluate the job itself—a vague editorial position at a local free newspaper. He felt relieved after a pleasant conversation with Neil, his potential boss, and did not consider the long-term implications of the job he was now facing. Neil offered him the job on the spot, telling him he was the only graduate who had applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**

I was about to see goat racing on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I pushed my way through ice-cream vans, large crowds, food stalls, and loud music. Although everyone was moving towards the racecourse, I tried to find a good spot to watch. An area was blocked off to create a course for the goats. It wasn’t as fancy as regular racecourses, but the idea was similar: spectators lined both sides of a stretch of ground where the goats would run. Keeping a few selected goats in line was not easy, especially since goats are known for eating almost anything they find.

**Canoe Trip**

As the day ended, I began to worry about the night ahead. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, there was nowhere to stop, and we hadn’t seen any villages or huts since early morning. In the dim moonlight, we could barely see the cliffs. Our torch batteries were dying, so we replaced them, but the new ones didn’t work. Clearly, we wouldn’t be able to find a place to camp. A few miles later, Lesley shouted that she saw a distant flickering light, and we felt hopeful. However, the light turned out to be moonlight reflecting on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud sound of rushing water, but we couldn’t see what was happening. Time seemed to stop as we continued on.

**How to be Presentation Perfect**

I am not naturally good at making presentations, but as managing director, I often need to present to my colleagues and major shareholders. How can I improve my presentation skills and confidence? You are not alone in this. Presenting requires different skills than running a company, yet many senior executives are expected to be good at it. To convince your audience, you must first believe in what you are saying. Show your belief through the passion and enthusiasm you bring to your presentation. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas beforehand and ask colleagues to help identify the tough questions your audience might ask. You should also create a positive atmosphere from the start. Begin with something everyone can relate to and gradually lead to the conclusion you want to reach.

Some activities cannot be rushed; they take the time they need. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient with mayonnaise and add the oil too quickly, it will spoil. If you pull on a tangled fishing line in frustration, the knot will only get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some tasks are done very quickly, while others take seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. Some tasks can be sped up, like solving crossword puzzles or doing math.
