She loves her father's racing pigeons and, when he leaves to find work, she takes charge of the pigeons and continues to win prizes, despite conflicts with her stressed mother. This engaging story conveys the message that "There are different kinds of cleverness," which is a positive lesson. Thoughtful readers will find it satisfying.

**Yaxley's Cat** by Robert Westall  
In this chilling story, Robert Westall tells the tale from the perspective of a mature woman. Rose rents a cottage from Sepp Yaxley to escape her materialistic life and her self-satisfied husband, bringing her two children with her. A fierce cat and strange items in the cottage reveal the mystery of Yaxley's disappearance. However, their presence causes local hostility, putting their lives in danger. By the end, while the violence is contained, Rose is troubled by her son's cold behavior. The story is completely gripping.

**Someone's Mother is Missing** by Harry Mazer  
Sam is a chubby, talkative boy who admires his cool cousin, Lisa, from the wealthy side of the family. When Lisa's privileged life falls apart, Sam helps her regain her balance, and they both learn the importance of family. Although the story moves slowly at times, it has gentle humor and convincingly portrays the growing bond between the two teenagers. It appeals to both boys and girls, which is quite rare.

**Stanley's Aquarium** by Barry Faville  
Barry Faville writes with confidence and humor, vividly depicting New Zealand and creating a relatable first-person narrator. Robbie takes a job gardening for an elderly man named Stanley, finding him interesting at first but later disturbing. When Robbie discovers what Stanley keeps in his aquarium and his plans for them, the story takes a thrilling turn while still providing deep insights into character and relationships. It is unique and compelling.

**Dodger** by Libby Gleeson  
This is a painful and sad story that explores Mick's troubled relationships and difficult school life through a mix of flashbacks, letters from a teacher to a friend, and Mick's own notes. He learns to cope with the negative expectations of others and his low self-esteem through a role in a school play and the support of a caring first-year teacher. This book is highly recommended, even though it is a truly agonizing read, especially towards the end.

**Science Defying Gravity**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are using weightlessness to test their ideas. From the outside, the aircraft looked like any other. The pilot informed the 13 students from Europe and America that it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964 and based on the Boeing 707 passenger plane. However, the inside was very different. It was a long white tunnel with few windows, lit by lights along the padded walls. Most of the seats were removed, leaving only a few at the back where the nervous young scientists sat, feeling anxious. 

For a year, they had competed with other students to earn a spot on this flight, which was organized by the European Space Agency. The challenge was to come up with creative experiments to conduct in weightless conditions. Those with the best ideas were chosen for this unique flight, which felt like an extraordinary roller-coaster ride. 

For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly in a way that felt like a giant bird soaring up and then diving down. The goal was to create a moment of weightlessness at the top of each curve. When the pilot cut the engines at 3,000 meters, the aircraft would rise higher due to its own speed before gravity pulled it back down. During the brief moments between rising and falling, everything inside the aircraft would become weightless, making the students feel as if they were closer to the moon than to Earth.

The flight took off smoothly, but any thoughts of a regular passenger flight vanished when the pilot put the Boeing into a steep climb for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and we were thrown around the cabin. Then, the engines stopped, and we quickly experienced weightlessness. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence, as if the floor had turned into a trampoline. One step could send us flying to the ceiling. We floated without direction; up or down, left or right, lost their meaning. Only gravity helps us understand where we are.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the aircraft out of its dive. The return of gravity was sudden, causing some students to land hard. After completing the first curve, some students felt uneasy about the 29 more to come. Thirty curves allowed for ten minutes of "space time" for experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to find out how cats always land on their feet. They released a device to investigate this, which floated upside down, and one student managed to turn it right side up using a remote control. 

However, during the next curve, another student accidentally landed on the device, nearly damaging it. Meanwhile, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joints are affected by the lack of gravity, which is important for building future space stations. Another group from Utah State University worked on creating solar sails from thin liquid films hardened by ultraviolet sunlight. They believe that once perfected, these sails could help satellites use the sun's energy like a yacht uses wind.

After two hours of flying between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unstable, but the main feeling was excitement, not sickness. This thrilling experience would stay with us for a long time. "It was unforgettable," said one student. "I already wanted to be an astronaut, but now I want it even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**

**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*. 

I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t experience any summers. I traveled to New Zealand every summer, which was actually winter there, so I had nine consecutive winters. I enjoyed this because I like winter. My parents had the idea to buy a small piece of land for my siblings and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you can plant trees on it, then it’s yours.” The goal was for us to always have a connection to New Zealand, which is special because my father grew up there. They found a plot of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land is not very good, but it is suitable for planting trees. 

I have always been passionate about land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing various farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees excited me. I think my family became enthusiastic as we went along. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, the three of us had planted the entire 70 acres. In New Zealand in 1968, it was one of those rainy winters. It rained a lot, almost every day we were planting. It seems strange to remember that time as happy since I was often wet and cold. Each morning was a challenge: getting ready for planting while coming out of the Land Rover, which was warm and dry, into the rain, with my jacket still damp from the day before and my boots soaked. 

During that first year, I worked with an experienced tree-planter, which was very helpful since I had never planted trees seriously before. I wore a planting bag around my neck, filling it with as many trees as I could. When the bag was full, it was heavy, but it became easier as it got lighter. The hardest part was keeping the lines straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then set up three poles in a straight line to guide you. Once you are aligned, you plant all the way down the line, turn around, and come back. 

I enjoy hard physical work, and it kept me fit. After a while, planting trees became almost automatic. You develop a rhythm and use the fewest movements needed to dig a hole. This rhythm is important in many agricultural jobs; you train your body to perform standard movements, making the work much easier. You create a regular process: taking a tree from the bag, digging a hole, placing it in the ground, stamping it down, and moving on. 

Mentally, it was fascinating. My mind began to wander, allowing me to think about many ideas and reflections on life. A lot of my thoughts about nature and our place in it started during those days. I have returned to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which has been very rewarding since I planted them and feel a connection to their success. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such headlines make me anxious. However, everything turned out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy. 

I should add that I took a break from teaching and returned to New Zealand in 1984 for three months, completely alone. I wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*, there. There is a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I wrote; in the afternoons, I pruned the trees; and in the evenings, I did research. My connection to that area is still very strong. In many ways, it is the place I feel most connected to in terms of the bond between people and the earth. It is a powerful connection.

**Bringing Up Badgers**

"What now?" was my first thought when one of my helpers brought a cardboard box to me. My husband Derek and I have run an open dairy farm in Somerset for six years, and we are known for caring for orphaned animals. However, the noise coming from the box—a mix of a cackle and a bark—was unfamiliar. Curious, I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their soft coats were covered in fleas, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between mid-January and mid-March and spend their early lives underground. If they are orphaned, they often starve and are never found. These three were brought to us by construction workers who accidentally disturbed their sett while laying drain pipes. Their mother was found dead, with her babies still suckling her. Although the cubs were healthy, they were cold and whimpering. After removing the fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them beside the stove for warmth. There were two females, named Primrose and Bluebell, and a male named Willow. 

At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe each cub with a warm cloth to mimic the feeling of their mother licking them. This helped them to relieve themselves. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. Within a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started moving around, though a bit unsteadily. They seemed happy with each other and a heated pad as a substitute for their mother. However, three weeks later, I noticed that Willow seemed weak, even though he was still eating normally. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t realize how serious it was. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet's examination showed that he had died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding animals, it is important not to let them drink too quickly, as liquid can enter the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that would have been hard to treat, even with antibiotics, because he was so small. 

Feeling sad about my loss, I continued to care for the other cubs. Then, six days later, a local farmer, who had heard about our cubs, came to see me. He had found another male cub, abandoned by its mother. He knew she would not return because the area had been disturbed, and the cub was cold and hungry. I named him Willow II. At six weeks old, he was about two weeks younger than the females. I soon discovered why his mother had left him; he was very difficult to feed. I had to keep moving the bottle's teat around and squeezing it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn’t eaten all day. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and anything else I offered. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle but struggled to eat without making a mess. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly learned to chew and eat. After a week of sausages, he was ready for more variety. 

At nearly five months old, all the cubs were eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Normally, badgers eat 60% earthworms, along with beetles, baby rabbits, mice, and even plant roots. My badgers were better off than others that year because the summer was very hot, making it hard to find earthworms. By August, my cubs had started to become nocturnal, going for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where they would get excited, fluff up their fur, and chase each other's tails. As "human badgers," we joined in their fun. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, sometimes got caught and ended up with colorful bruises. 

During two late-night walks in a dry period, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely expanding their territory to find food, even though badgers are very territorial and will fight off others that enter their area. We were warned that they might come into our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we put sheet metal over the gate to keep it secure. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and the response was so positive that we started a campaign to build a sett for the badgers on our farm. With help from others, we designed a new home for them. My son Daniel drew the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate that faced their usual walking path. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside from a darkened area. As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they became more interested in the tunnels and bedding than in walking. 

The building costs were higher than we expected, but a local bus company called Badgerline sponsored part of the project, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted to help the badgers have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I quietly returned to check on them and saw three badgers curled up in their chambers, sound asleep. Nowadays, I don’t walk with them as often, especially since they don’t wake up until midnight. We see Primrose only occasionally because she has joined a nearby sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to greet me before they dash off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have happily accepted.

**In Search of True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet**

Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow in the footsteps of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.

Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, during his time, one of his most important achievements was mapping the "variations of the compass" using calculations from his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called "declination," refer to the angle between magnetic north and true geographical north. Understanding this was crucial for sailors to correct their compasses and navigate accurately.

Halley, one of only two people in England paid to do scientific research at that time, set out for the Cape Verde Islands to chart declination in the North and South Atlantic. His first trip was cut short due to crew problems, but he later sailed again. This journey took him to Rio de Janeiro, past South Georgia, up to Newfoundland, and back to England. From these travels, Halley published a chart in 1701 showing compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. More advanced charts based on his work helped sailors for over a century until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made them less accurate.

Dr. Clark plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's journey by retracing the Paramore's route. He needs to raise £70,000 before starting, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley during his two years at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about the scientist's life. "Halley led a remarkable life," Dr. Clark says. "He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer; he also researched geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped stars and worked on other projects."

During this time, Halley invented a diving bell and advised Sir Isaac Newton while he wrote *Principia Mathematica*, a key work in physics. Dr. Clark believes that recreating Halley's voyage will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also have scientific value. It will involve taking measurements similar to Halley's but with much more accurate instruments. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is constantly changing. The data collected will help improve the current model of the Earth's magnetic field, known as the international geomagnetic reference field.

"It is common to measure the strength but not the direction of the magnetic field," Dr. Clark explains. "You need to know true north to measure the direction. On our expedition, we can use global positioning satellites to find that." The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements globally. Dr. Clark hopes his measurements will fill in any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean, and having ground-based measurements will be useful for comparison.

Halley's Atlantic journey was significant as it was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he was the first civilian appointed as a naval captain to pursue his interest in declination. Does Dr. Clark have the qualifications to make his journey successful? He has spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed the 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.

Does he share Halley's obsessive nature? "I am willing to give up my life for eight months to do this, so some might think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**POWER DRESSING**

Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tail feathers to the critical eyes of the peahens. This behavior raises a question that puzzled Charles Darwin: how could birds develop such extravagant features in a world where survival is so competitive? How do they manage to thrive with such a burden?

Zoologist Marion Petrie and her team from the Open University are studying the peacocks at Whipsnade, a century after Darwin's death, to find answers. Darwin believed that living beings evolved through natural selection, where the strongest and most suited individuals survive and reproduce. However, he thought that the peacock's tail was a disadvantage, so he introduced the idea of "sexual selection," suggesting that females are attracted to beauty for its own sake.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different view. He believed that if peahens preferred males with the most impressive tails, there must be some hidden quality that made those males more fit for survival. According to Wallace, the tail was not just for show; it indicated something important about the male's ability to survive.

Today, researchers still debate these ideas. Studying the natural behavior of peafowl is challenging, but the 200 birds at Whipsnade, which live in a semi-wild environment and are accustomed to humans, provide a unique opportunity for research. Petrie and her team are focusing on two main questions: Do peahens really prefer males with the most impressive tails? And do these males have any real advantages, as Wallace suggested, or is it just for show, as Darwin believed?

Observations show that the peahens do seem to prefer the males with the most eye-spots on their tails, which are linked to tail length. Males with more eye-spots attract more mates. However, it is still unclear if these attractive males are better in other ways.

William Hamilton from Oxford University proposed that showy male birds might be less affected by parasites, and their bright feathers could signal their health. There is some evidence for this in other bird species, but Petrie and her team have not yet been able to study the internal health of the peacocks at Whipsnade.

This year, Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive males with those of less attractive ones. Are the offspring of the attractive males healthier and growing faster? If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that female choice is based on practical benefits.

There is also an interesting theory from mathematician and biologist R.A. Fisher, known as "Fisher's Runaway." This theory suggests that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, her sons will inherit that trait, and her daughters will inherit her preference for long tails. Over generations, this could lead to males with increasingly long tails, reinforcing the idea that females are selecting for beauty.

In conclusion, this ongoing research may ultimately support both Darwin's and Wallace's theories, showing that beauty can have both practical and aesthetic value in the animal kingdom.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should mix traditional and modern elements. He applied this idea to his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London showcases many beautiful yachts filled with new technology. Most of these boats are descendants of a major design change that happened 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat rests quietly in a tidal creek on the south coast. Although she was designed last year, her appearance might make you think she is 100 years old, leading you to believe her owner is a romantic. Perhaps I am, but I’m not sure.

This boat benefits from the charm of classic design, but modern technology has made the process easier. However, it is important to note that advanced technology often separates sailors from the true challenges of life at sea. These challenges are often what they wanted to experience by going sailing in the first place. I am not suggesting that sailors should face every difficulty. I believe it is essential for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable sleeping areas. But why go sailing if every sail operates automatically? Dealing with a flapping sail is part of being a sailor.

Why should we give up common sense and move our steering positions from the safe back of the boat to a less secure spot near the front? Unfortunately, this change creates a cabin that resembles an ocean liner, with a bed larger than one at home. For me, a boat should always feel like a boat, not a house on the water. When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race series, the previous owner noted that she had all the comforts but no luxuries. Over my time with her, I learned how true that was. Hirta had heavy sails, no pumped water, little electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest and kindest boat I have ever sailed.

However, classic boats like hers require a lot of maintenance. After injuring my back, I realized I could no longer care for her. I looked for a younger boat but found none that met my needs, so I decided to build a new one from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett are skilled with computer design programs, Irens first sketched this boat on a paper napkin before moving to the computer. After creating a basic design, he carved a model, just like boat builders did in the past. We then refined the design using technology, and by the final version, it was perfect.

The completed boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She has a timeless look, moves beautifully in the water, and her interior, made from reclaimed pitch pine, creates a peaceful atmosphere. This may be because she was designed solely as a sailing boat, without considering any furniture. This traditional approach has proven effective. In her calm presence, she shows that it is not necessary to follow modern trends to find happiness, and that sometimes, it is wise to learn from history. Built with wood treated to resist water, she combines the advantages of a fiberglass boat while still looking, feeling, and sailing like a true classic.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was excited to spend six days at Henlow Grange because I was tired and needed to unwind. My room in the large 18th-century house was extremely comfortable, and I felt relaxed right away. On the first day, I did nothing but sleep. Starting on the second day, I joined body conditioning classes and tried as many activities as I could, like yoga and stretching. The instructors are very skilled, and I was surprised at how flexible I became during the week. They offer many treatments, including aromatherapy (which helped me relax), seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment, which lasts an hour, truly makes you feel rejuvenated. The staff in the treatment rooms were friendly, kind, and professional. The atmosphere was full of energy and enthusiasm. Henlow plans to renovate this year, adding a half-size Olympic swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. Bicycles are available for riding around the grounds. If you prefer a quieter time and the weather is nice, you can read a magazine or take a peaceful walk in the garden. During my stay, I felt happier and had a better appetite. I left feeling wonderful and full of energy, which lasted a long time. I definitely want to return. This is the perfect getaway for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me!  
*Marcella D'Argy Smith*

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
The peaceful atmosphere of this stately home was clear as soon as I walked up the grand staircase into the reception area. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and plenty of space, so you can avoid talking to others if you wish. Upon arrival, everyone receives a medical check-up, which includes an examination and a review of weight and blood pressure. We were all called patients, which felt a bit strange since I am healthy. However, I was impressed that a shoulder issue found during the exam was quickly addressed by the fitness instructor, and we worked on it in group workshops and individual sessions. Each guest follows a specific diet. I lost weight without starving, but I was still hungry enough to get a bad headache on the second day. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and a mix of exotic fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you are not on a light diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is delicious and well-presented, so you won’t feel deprived! You receive a massage or water therapy every other day. All extra treatments are reasonably priced.  
*Liz Gregory*

**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys is not a health farm and does not pretend to be one. It is a charming old manor with cozy log fires and a spacious lounge. If you are counting calories, you might want to skip the gourmet food. The French chef prepares rich sauces and delightful creamy desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a fully-equipped gym and a soft-water pool, so I could work off some of the tempting dishes. (You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you want to lose weight.) There is a spa bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A major attraction is the sports injury clinic. I received expert advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is both comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside nearby.  
*Beverly D'Silva*

**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats its guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a well-equipped gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and much more. There are beautiful woodland walks and gardens on the 376-acre National Trust estate. Waldo's, a highly-rated restaurant, serves dishes that are absolutely delicious. It took me half an hour to read the dinner menu because there were so many choices. The meal was fantastic, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed feeling very happy! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym using exercise equipment to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. I thought about all the other reports my fellow journalists would write about fitness assessments, workouts, and beauty treatments to tone the body. Cliveden has all these options if you want to use them before treating yourself at Waldo's.  
*Kay Letch*

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. The best because it is the most delicious I have ever tasted. The worst because it has 360 calories, which can be a setback if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the amazing aromatherapy massage. I chose a relaxing oil blend and fell asleep twice during the massage. I returned to my room and had the best night’s sleep in years. The facilities are modern and well-organized, with luxurious bedrooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, making it easy to schedule appointments. A variety of treatments are available, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. The guests are a diverse group, including football teams, mothers and daughters, best friends, and singles. Ideally, I would take a break here about once a month.  
*Eve Cameron*

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not developed many differences; genetically, we are still over 98% similar to chimps. This means that the traits that make us different from animals are quite recent. Our biological history suggests that our ability to create art and other unique human traits come from just a small part of our genes. This is a significant responsibility for a limited number of genes. 

Recent studies of animal behavior have shown that many traits once thought to be unique to humans are now seen as differences in degree rather than kind. For instance, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools; chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Regarding language, monkeys have simple warning calls for different predators like leopards, eagles, and snakes. These findings suggest that aside from art, there are not many absolute differences between humans and animals.

However, if human art comes from a unique genetic trait, it is curious that our ancestors did not create art for almost 6.9 million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. We only have clear evidence of human art, such as cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments, starting around 35,000 years ago with the Cro-Magnons.

If we argue that our recent artistic explosion makes us unique, we must consider how our art differs from that of animals. Three main differences are often suggested: human art is not practical, it is created for beauty, and it is learned rather than instinctive. 

First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." A biologist might interpret this to mean that human art does not help us survive or reproduce, unlike most animal behaviors. While some human art communicates ideas to others, this is not the same as passing on genes. In contrast, birdsong serves clear purposes, like defending territory or attracting mates, which helps them pass on their genes. By this standard, human art does seem different.

The second claim is that human art is motivated by a desire for beauty. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mainly sing during mating season, suggesting they do not sing just for pleasure. Again, this makes human art seem unique.

The third claim is that human art is learned rather than instinctive. Different human groups have their own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are easily distinguishable. However, these styles are not genetically inherited. People from different cultures can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' specific songs, even if they have never heard them before.

The role of learning in human art is also evident in how quickly our art styles change. For instance, geese have made the same sounds for 2,000 years, but human art evolves rapidly. Even casual museum visitors can tell that a twentieth-century painting is more recent than the Mona Lisa. Art experts can often identify when and who painted a work, but they might confuse two mid-twentieth-century artists named Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo created up to 33 paintings in one day for his own enjoyment and became upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show of their paintings in 1957 in London, and many of their works sold, which is something many human artists cannot claim.

These paintings by our closest relatives blur the lines between human art and animal behavior. Like human art, the paintings made by apes did not serve practical purposes; they were created for the satisfaction of the painter. One might argue that human art is different because most human artists intend to communicate with others, while the apes did not care about sharing their work. However, this argument is not entirely convincing, as some famous human art was also created for personal satisfaction rather than communication.

**An Awfully Big Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth and also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell his story. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. In the past, children's stories featured brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes squinting at distant horizons on their journeys into the unknown. Nowadays, such characters are rare in fiction and even rarer in real life. That was my belief until I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's great adventure was leading an expedition across the Taklamakan Desert, known locally as the Desert of Death. He shared the dangers and excitement of that incredible journey while sitting calmly at home with his family. His team included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts on the area, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have endangered everyone’s lives and the success of the expedition.

This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the world's harshest deserts, and Charles Blackmore wrote a captivating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to discover who he really was outside the Army. "I had always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I had been offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who Charles Blackmore really was. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn’t come back since no one had ever completed that route; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was surprisingly kind to us."

Anyone reading his remarkable account will be surprised by the word "kind." The team faced terrible hardships: dysentery, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and losing part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We didn’t experience the Taklamakan’s famous sandstorms, and we avoided the freezing desert cold that could have stopped us completely. That doesn’t mean we didn’t face challenges all the time. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. Climbing the high dunes was torture for us and the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us."

"What motivated me most was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn’t allow for one. No aircraft flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared about my physical ability. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to start now!' At that moment, I was very scared."

If it was tough at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking 1,000 kilometers, you’re not going to give up. You’ve endured so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but also very strong despite our exhaustion. My body was well-toned, and my legs felt powerful. I could walk over anything."

Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon and thinking of his family. How aware was he of the struggle it must have been for them? "Inside me, there’s someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the image of the desert and remember that we managed to complete that journey. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I’ve done. Yet, when I think of my life’s achievements, I think of my family and the happiness we share — by that measure, the desert doesn’t compare."

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge — for the open spaces — and the determination it brings. We were motivated by a sense of purpose. Now, I find it hard to fit into the sameness of modern life."

**Text: Life Without Technology**

Susan Harr decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy manual work. Many people love technology because it provides us with amazing devices that make life easier and give us more free time. However, we have been led to believe that technology is essential, and this idea is everywhere. Using our hands does not harm the environment, unlike machines that consume energy.

Recently, I had a frustrating experience with a broken word processor, which cost me a lot to fix. This made me question whether gadgets are really worth the money and hassle. Am I as dependent on technology as I think? Gradually, I have stopped using some household gadgets as they break down. This makes me wonder what "extra time" technology actually gives us. Is it just time to buy more gadgets? If that’s the case, then the marketing experts are tricking us.

When my broken gadget started making strange noises, I left it outside, where it now sits quietly. I enjoy working with my hands instead of being tied to a noisy machine. I can take my sewing with me wherever I go. There are some gadgets I still appreciate, like my washing machine, which I found very useful after a year without one. However, losing some gadgets has brought me unexpected joy. 

To avoid spending too much time in front of the television, I returned our rented color TV and switched back to a small black-and-white one. This change has helped us spend more time walking the dog, reading, talking, and enjoying other hobbies. I have also stopped using my old sewing machine, which now serves as a plant table. I can’t afford to replace it, so I have started sewing by hand.

We often think we cannot live without our gadgets, but many people in the past worked hard without them. Computers now do many tasks for us, but I find that hand sewing is enjoyable and relaxing. I can listen to the radio or talk with family while I sew. If the task is simple, I can even watch my favorite TV shows without feeling guilty, as I am also being productive.

I used to think that sewing by hand was tedious and tiring, but I have discovered that it is soothing and satisfying. I enjoy seeing my work become neater and more confident. I find that things get done quickly, and I can slow down my pace of life. I also enjoy washing dishes by hand, allowing my mind to wander while I do it.

Now, I look around my home and wonder if we really need all our gadgets, like the freezer, microwave, or electric lawnmower. In fact, we could save a lot of money by living without electric lights!

**Text: The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst**

Charles Hurst is a skilled cabinet-maker who creates beautifully crafted furniture. Joanna Watt meets him in his workshop, located under a railway arch in East London. When I arrive, he greets me with a quick handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" It’s hard to tell if he is genuinely in a hurry or just acting tough. However, looking around his workshop, it is clear that he is very busy. The space is filled with unfinished furniture and wooden planks in many natural colors.

Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has built a strong reputation. His order book is always full for months ahead, even though he does not actively promote himself. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the right choice. 

Finding a furniture-maker is not difficult, as the craft is still alive in the countryside. However, it is harder to find a cabinet-maker who focuses on creating well-made furniture with clean, simple designs. Hurst notes, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many call themselves furniture-makers." As someone who holds high standards, he often feels disappointed by modern furniture. He expresses his frustration with poorly made, mass-produced items and craftsmen who produce low-quality work. This pursuit of perfection is a big part of Hurst's success, along with his talent. He is confident in his skills, stating, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." 

Hurst is self-taught. When asked how he learned his craft, he replies, "I asked the right questions and picked it all up." Most of his work comes from private clients, and some return for more projects. He enjoys the satisfaction of working on an entire house for a client. However, he admits that not all client relationships are easy. "The most frustrating clients are those who don’t know what they want and change their minds too late. My favorite clients are the exacting ones."

While Hurst has every reason to be proud, he also acknowledges the skills of others. He humbly says, "There are people far better than me. I can admire other people." He criticizes craftsmen who try to be artists and take too long to finish a piece. He also finds degree shows, where students showcase their work while trying to make fashion statements, to be pretentious. "A piece of furniture is not about making a statement. It has to be something people can really use."

Despite his confidence and straightforward manner, Hurst is not pretentious. As I leave, he reminds me, "After all, I am only making furniture."

**Three Theories About Sleep**

People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This suggests that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.

The first and most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our physical health. It suggests that while we sleep, our bodies work to repair any damage from the day and to help us recover so we can function well.

The second theory focuses on the benefits of sleep for learning. It argues that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. According to this theory, without sleep, we would not be able to learn effectively.

The third theory is about energy. It claims that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we have enough for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and does not follow the accepted norms of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most of us have our own quirks and peculiarities. It could be a love for entering newspaper contests, a habit of collecting beer mats, or a tendency to write angry letters to the press about various topics. Eccentricity is a way of expressing our individuality. 

Inside us, there is often a struggle between two opposing forces. It’s like having two trains on the same track, pushing against each other. One train represents individualism, and the other represents conformity. For many people, conformity is stronger. The desire to be accepted, loved, and appreciated often outweighs the desire to stand out and be unique.

People with unusual hobbies, strong opinions, or unconventional behavior often come together. They form clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to discuss their shared interests or issues. The key word here is 'shared.' They seek others who understand what their friends and family might see as odd. Being part of a group, even a small one, can be comforting.

Most of us feel a tension between individualism and conformity. While we may follow the crowd, we often dislike being told that we are doing so. We feel a need to express our individuality, like when a man at a bar declares, "I say what I think," or when a new acquaintance insists, "You must take me as I am. I don’t follow rules."

At any moment, we can choose to embrace our individuality. Many people succeed in their careers by doing just that. For example, Bob Dylan, the American singer, has said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing and pursue it with determination, you will surprise many people." However, this assertion of individuality is not the same as eccentricity, especially in the beginning. 

When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these behaviors until they become a part of who they are, then they may be considered eccentric. The key aspect of eccentricity is its naturalness. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are.

A true eccentric is not focused on what others think. They act according to their true selves. This sets them apart from enthusiasts, practical jokers, clever criminals, attention-seekers, and recluses. These individuals are aware of the world around them and often react to it. Some want to impress society, while others want to escape from it. In contrast, eccentrics live their lives freely, without concern for societal expectations.

**Natural Books**

We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have had the chance to meet some of the most important thinkers in this field. Among them, Barbara Ward stands out. She has been at the center of environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from various environmental movements into a powerful philosophy. When I was a young journalist, her insights helped me understand these complex topics. Choosing her book was more difficult. I considered "Only One Earth" and "Progress for a Small Planet," but I believe "The Home of Man" is her most significant work. It discusses the rapid growth of cities while addressing the larger themes she cared about. It is a passionate call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none compare to it.

**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of their droppings in the sun. This book beautifully explains the fascinating world of animal communication through words and pictures. After reading it, if you watch a gull colony, you will see that their chaotic activity is actually a well-organized social structure. You can identify which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a respected behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His collaboration with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and interesting for anyone who loves nature. Ennion's paintings, created from years of observing birds, show how one gull can be aggressive while another is calm. This is the work of a true naturalist.

**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband and a fulfilling career in conservation, but it also deepened my love for the natural world. I was studying animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. After two years of challenges, opening this book made my world brighter. It beautifully connects animals, people, joy, and beauty, showing a world worth saving. Many people believe humans are the worst because of the harm we have caused to other species. However, I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, viewing all living beings as a family, regardless of their nature. This idea is important for all of us to understand.

**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I discovered "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library shortly after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially the 48 colorful bird illustrations by Eric Ennion. These images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds, which inspired me to start sketching them. However, "The Shell Bird Book" offered much more. Along with the beautiful illustrations, it included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music, literature, and art. The wide range of information and exciting images encouraged me to appreciate birds and nature more broadly. The book showed me that my emotional and creative connection to nature is just as valid as a scientific one. Since art was my stronger subject compared to math or physics, I began to see new possibilities for myself.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five major British publishers about how book reviews affect sales. Here is what they said.

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers; they are the first thing we look at in newspapers. A study by the Book Marketing Council showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers are usually more accepting of bad reviews. They believe that any mention in the press can help sales, as readers want to form their own opinions. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own views about a book since they often read it first.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed, ideally in a positive way. Book reviews today are more varied and accessible than they were 40 years ago. However, there is still a tendency to overlook paperbacks, which many people read. Weekly summaries of books are often not enough, and even original paperbacks rarely get serious attention. Still, publishers need reviews because they are a cost-effective way to promote a book and its author. A good review from a respected source can significantly boost sales, especially if there are multiple positive reviews.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing; without them, we would struggle. Our books are usually not by well-known authors, and we rarely advertise, so we rely on literary editors to give our books space. Positive reviews are much more valuable than ads because they are seen as unbiased. Publishers often say they care more about the length of reviews than their content. The impact of reviews on sales is complex. Good reviews can launch a book and a career, but they need to be supported by other factors like recommendations from readers, strong responses from booksellers, and smart marketing.

**Publisher D**  
I wish I understood the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain! In the U.S., a single review from the New York Times can make or break a book. Here, booksellers often ignore reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of great reviews for a good writer to gain readers. Interestingly, some poorly received books or those without reviews can still sell very well. The situation is unpredictable, although non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer’s knowledge than on the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews, but do they actually lead to sales? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it didn’t sell well because people felt they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the reviewer’s name matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers praised a book, people paid attention. Today, it can also be the unexpected reviewer or the creativity of the review that encourages people to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**

The craft of making weathervanes is very old, dating back to ancient Egypt. Today, this skill is still practiced in the workshop of Graham Smith, one of the few people in the country who makes hand-cut weathervanes. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. He says, "This way, I can make a special item just for them." Many of his customers are women looking for unique gifts for their husbands, often reflecting their interests in work or hobbies.

Graham's work is quite different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. The first weathervane he made was not a cockerel, but a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. "I realized that there are endless possibilities for designs," he explains. 

Graham decided to focus on his weathervane business after working for 15 years as a precision engineer. Five years ago, he and his wife, Liz, switched roles: she became the main breadwinner while he took care of their children and built the business. He has no regrets about this change. "My previous job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic," he says. He has now created over 100 original designs and pays great attention to detail, always getting customer approval on the design before he starts cutting.

Graham also keeps traditional designs available because they are still popular. "People like handmade items," he says. "They enjoy having something a little different." He does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People appreciate the uniqueness, and I love transforming a simple shape into something almost lifelike," he explains.

For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction. Nowadays, as more people move to the countryside, they want to add special touches to their homes, which has helped crafts like Graham's. He has become busier, supplying weathervanes to customers around the world, especially in America and Denmark. "The price depends on how detailed the design is," he says. His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was already the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans made him a lot of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success.

The beginning of the year was tough for Nicholas Evans, who was a screenwriter, producer, and hoping to be a director. Things started badly when a film project he had been working on, called *Life and Limb*, fell apart almost overnight. He felt disappointed and worried because it had been two years since he earned any money, and that film was his only hope to calm an angry bank manager.

A sensible person in Evans' situation would have found a job. He could have returned to being a television executive or started a television project that was on hold. Instead, he made a decision that many, including himself, thought was crazy. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching for his first novel. Although it was an impulsive choice, the idea for the story had been in his mind for a while. He had met a farrier on Dartmoor who told him about a gentle horse that suddenly became aggressive for no reason. The owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These people were known as "horse whisperers." This story captured Evans' imagination.

He began to research the topic, initially planning to write a screenplay since he was a filmmaker. However, after losing hope in the film industry due to the failure of *Life and Limb*, he decided to write the story as a book. Throughout the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he recalls. "I was observing people, but I felt very alone and like my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was deeply in debt, worried about how to support my children, and questioning if it was all a mistake."

By the end of August, after returning home and writing the first half of the book, he felt the pressure from the bank manager. He needed to know if it was worth continuing. He bravely showed the manuscript to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent read it and said it was "fine." When asked for more feedback, he suggested that Evans might receive $30,000 as an advance for the book. Evans thought about how much he needed to pay off some debts, and $30,000 was not enough. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer*, with at least two more months of work ahead. He was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.

In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the novel, along with the summary, to seven UK publishers just before they left for the famous Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. "You what?" Evans replied, surprised. The agent explained, "It's okay, I just feel something big is happening."

What happened next became a significant moment in publishing history. Within a week of competitive bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were in shock. We had never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans said. They also didn't send it to Hollywood, but soon major studios were competing for the film rights. "My UK agent wisely involved an agent in the US, and when he called to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief." 

As they agreed on this amount, the studios each wanted to present their case to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four prominent filmmakers called one after another, eager to pay $3 million for an unfinished novel. Evans shared this story with me over coffee on his wooden verandah overlooking his garden. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's all been like a fairy tale so far. I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very challenging, and I don't want to become just an employee of these people I like who have paid me so much. I would hate to write a draft and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but now we’ll bring in someone else.'"

He said he would stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new support for *Life and Limb*, but he was unsure if he wanted to pursue it. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he concluded.

**Young Masters**

Bobby Fischer is facing challenges as he tries to return to the world of chess. Chess has become more of a young person's game. After being away for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. He won the first game impressively, but later games revealed that he is not the same player he was in 1972. Now 49 years old, he is out of practice and not in great shape. Spassky is even older.

The game of chess has changed significantly in the last two decades. Fischer helped make chess popular, leading to a new era of professionalism. Today, winning is the main goal for chess players. In international chess, a player’s mental strength and endurance are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high, with a chess clock ensuring players make their moves in a set time. If they fail to do so, they lose immediately. Now, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks, increasing the pressure on players. 

In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the last. Currently, eight of the ten highest-ranked players are under 30. The way chess is played has also evolved. Much of modern chess preparation happens off the board. Players must prepare thoroughly before matches, especially since computers can store millions of chess games and provide quick access to information about opponents. In recent matches, players have used large teams to analyze each other’s strategies continuously. The opening moves of a game are now studied in great detail, and being well-prepared can be crucial.

Today, there are more top players than ever before, with many grandmasters competing for modest prizes worldwide. Success in chess requires both mental and physical effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and during this time, players must maintain focus. A moment of distraction can lead to losing the game. The chess clock adds to the stress, especially during the final moments when players have only seconds to make their moves. In these intense situations, players must act quickly and decisively, resembling athletes in their coordination.

At the highest level of chess, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress. However, one victory is not enough to win a tournament; players must be ready for the next challenge. Most chess tournaments last 9 to 11 days, with games played every day, and there are competitions throughout the year. World championship matches can be even more demanding. For example, the 1984 match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to be stopped after several months due to exhaustion, with Karpov losing about 10 kg.

Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This makes his long absence from the game puzzling. However, it also adds to his legacy. If he has returned for financial reasons, he is likely to succeed, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. But if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player in the world, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

**Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones interviews some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are rising to fame.

**A** Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, *Peaches*, into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." What is remarkable about Nick is that before writing *Peaches*, he had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed," he explains. "It's set in a car. I probably wouldn't do that now because I understand the challenges involved. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After completing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of its rhythm and rhyme," he says. "Suddenly, I was surrounded by people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational setting. It was very inspiring."

**B** Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a demanding tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even during his time at Bristol, he was practicing his comedy in clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a traditional actor; I was always more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it really isn't. If you have courage and good material, it's wonderful to make people laugh." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but his partnership with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed I was imitating him," Simon admits.

**C** Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became well-known when he starred in the series *The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star*. The response was very positive, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says with a smile. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare and comfortable position, especially since he has just graduated. Looking back at his early career, it's clear that such success was likely. Encouraged by his mother, he moved from leading roles in school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he spent four years. "I was basically using acting as an excuse to avoid homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided I wanted to pursue it seriously because I had a talent and passion for it." Now, he is waiting for the praise to come in, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about earning respect for doing good work."

**D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single, *Chimera*, is released soon. "The record company's idea of good sales is very different from mine," he says. "They want a hit, but I have no idea. For me, if two people buy it, I'll be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music industry ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I had been performing at student gigs for eight years and was starting to feel discouraged. Just when I was about to give up, I met Rick Brown, who had connections at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have come at a better time. There were moments when I felt very down, and I was in some terrible bands, but hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E** Poet and author Stephen Richards is 27 years old and has won more awards and honors than many people twice his age. He is already well-known in the poetry community, where he has been touring and giving readings several times a week for the past six years. His first novel, *Hidden*, will be published in March. "It's a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but became disillusioned with education later. "I chose not to go to university, but I realized I needed to after I got bored stuffing envelopes at a theater." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer; they always thought I would just be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry receiving much praise, moving into novels is a brave step. "My poetry has a structure, and there's less chance of making a big mistake," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more opportunities to write poorly. My main goal is to avoid falling into a routine where I just produce work without caring about its quality."

A. Isabel, the main character in this quirky novel, believes she looks good in jeans but rarely wears them because she wants to avoid the wrong crowd. At 31, she is an art student who loves historical romances and is searching for Mr. Right, worried that her knobbly knees might ruin her chances. Despite her concerns, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a style reminiscent of early silent films, with chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired."

B. This story celebrates the rise and near-fall of a local radio station in America. It offers a humorous perspective on radio, seen through the eyes of a clever but shy child named Francis With. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, created by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station soon broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, and announcers. The small-town setting allows the author to showcase his dry humor and skillful writing, taking readers back to the simpler times of the 1940s and 1950s, filled with dime stores and old cars.

C. In the author's world, it is normal for a second husband to chat with his wife's first husband. When professor Richard Vaisey falls for a beautiful Russian poet, he shares his feelings with his wife's ex. The poet writes poor poetry, which bothers Richard, and she seeks his help for her wrongly imprisoned brother. However, the way the author unravels these issues is even more interesting. He moves the story forward with a sense of humor and carefully examines relationships, making it a delightful and clever read.

D. In 1960s London, two sets of best friends—two women and two men—become intertwined in life and death for 25 years. At the beginning of this lengthy novel, James Hudson, a mysterious American businessman, is launching a newspaper with his friend Richard Blake as the editor. The launch is important, but so is the fact that they both loved a woman who was killed years earlier. The story includes themes of murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, all written well. This book allows readers to deeply connect with the characters.

E. This touching and funny story, written by a top American author, follows Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about a past mistake. To make amends, he becomes a 'father' to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is slowly becoming an eccentric bachelor while managing everyday life. The story explores deep emotions and highlights the special bond Ian forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book that perfectly balances sadness and humor.

**Volunteer Tourism**

Four academic writers discuss international voluntary work. 

A. It is difficult to say that volunteer work significantly helps development. While volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, they usually pay a large fee to participate. This money, if given directly to a local community, could pay for more labor than the individual volunteer could provide. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often lack the necessary skills or experience. Many studies raise the question of whether gap year volunteering is mainly driven by a desire to help others or if young people are more interested in gaining experiences that will benefit their careers. However, these projects may help develop individuals who will act ethically in their future careers and lives.

B. Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, and increased participation in global issues through civic organizations. It can also help create international social networks among ordinary people. In this way, the overall impact can be greater than the individual contributions, benefiting both volunteers and host communities, and contributing to the global good. However, if volunteering is mostly done by wealthy individuals, it may provide them with a broader perspective and career advantages, but it will not significantly help those in communities that lack access to such opportunities. Volunteers may continue to benefit personally while using host organizations and communities to advance their own goals.

C. At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of imperialism or self-serving charity from wealthy Westerners. At its best, it can provide benefits and challenges to both volunteers and the organizations they work with, allowing for the exchange of skills, knowledge, and cultural experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness and foster a lifelong commitment to addressing issues of inequality, poverty, and unsustainable development.

D. Volunteer tourism aligns with the growing trend of personal strategies to help others. These limited strategies, focused on making a small difference, can seem positive in a time when political engagement is low. The personal aspect appears appealing as it avoids large government and business involvement. However, it also neglects the need for democratic representation and reduces development to individual acts of charity, often failing to address the deeper issues faced by poor rural communities. While skepticism about volunteering is often misplaced, volunteer tourism can sometimes be just simple charity. However, when it is promoted as sustainable development and merges with the marketing of gap-year companies, it reflects a decline in the understanding of development issues. The politics of volunteer tourism can distract from recognizing global inequalities and the poverty experienced by many in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm**

Stuart Harris reports that many people listen to the radio in the morning and need something to help them get out of bed. This is why clock radios are popular. But how do you choose a good one? A panel, including myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models currently available.

One model has a 'dual alarm function,' which I initially thought would let you wake up to a buzzer, snooze for a bit, and then get up. However, the instruction booklet suggests using this feature to set two different wake-up times: one for weekdays and one for weekends. But who really schedules their life like that? This model costs about the same as another we tested, but it includes a cassette player, allowing you to fall asleep to your favorite tapes and wake up without news. We all agreed that the radio quality was excellent, but the size was an issue—it’s as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges mentioned that any clock radio he buys must leave enough space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also said he always books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails.

This model was voted the best in terms of design and overall performance. Paul Bridges said he was 'in love with it,' even though the clock he tested kept getting stuck at 16:00. I found the digital display appealing, with its stylish grey numbers on a soft green background. The wide snooze bar allows you to tap it without opening your eyes. However, the smooth buttons, which felt nice to touch, distracted me when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup power feature, so you don’t have to reset it if someone accidentally unplugs it. Everyone liked this feature, but we found it complicated to set up. Still, mastering it made us feel sophisticated.

Tom Granger criticized another model with a built-in lamp, calling it 'unbelievably tacky.' He had to read the instructions twice to get it to work because the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The lamp was difficult to position and was not bright enough to read by, as it only lit up the clock, which was already illuminated. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea amusing but agreed that tuning the radio was challenging. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine, making me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. Aimed at young people, its bright colors appealed to both Tom Granger and me. Tom said he would choose this one because it stands out more than the others. In fact, its traditional controls were the only ones we could set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm has a funny 20-minute error margin, meaning it might go off 10 minutes earlier or later than set. Paul Bridges laughed at this idea, calling the model 'terribly fiddly' and 'completely useless.'

The simplest and cheapest model we tested scored points with Tom Granger because it was 'very standard and took up little space,' plus it had old-fashioned dial tuning. He said it was easier to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you can never be sure if you pressed the buttons correctly, which makes it hard to trust that it will work. However, he acknowledged that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I found the tuning a bit rough, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed that the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs

A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines that cover its body. They are found in many parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. All hedgehog species can roll into a tight ball when threatened, with their spines pointing outward for protection. The effectiveness of this defense depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have adapted to their environment and have fewer spines, making them more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up, using that ability only as a last option.

Hedgehogs are mainly active at night and sleep during most of the day, often hiding under bushes or in burrows. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. In suitable conditions, some hedgehogs may stay awake throughout the year.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in any sport is challenging, even for men, but women often face even greater difficulties. Training and competing leave little time for a normal life, requiring many sacrifices.
