Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and setting new records. Here, we highlight some remarkable British sportswomen who are achieving their dreams.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**  
"It's an amazing feeling to soar through the air and land safely, but it can also be frightening. Sometimes I don’t feel well, or the weather is bad, but I push through. Having a career outside of skiing is tough because we train for ten months each year. I have to give up a lot of my social life and friends, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team, and we all compete on the same courses and receive equal treatment—it's a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race and surprisingly won because I cycled faster than everyone else, even though I had never cycled before! I earn a good salary as a professional cyclist, and there are many opportunities for sponsorship. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks rather than my skills. So, I focus on cycling instead of making money. I train for at least four hours every day, along with stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands the commitment required."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is difficult for girls to start because very few schools offer it. Most girls begin at 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Additionally, coaches often change frequently, leading to a lack of stability in the women's team. Despite these challenges, I enjoy rowing and staying fit, and I appreciate the social aspect of the sport."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not realizing how vast it is! I found Britain too small and safe. I was very determined and disliked being controlled. Each walk has been unique. My walk across Australia was the most painful experience, covering 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters. But I set a record! I had to succeed because my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Some men believe women are more likely to fail, making them hesitant to sponsor us."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when driving, which you can see on the roads. When I perform well, they often ignore me. Being a woman in racing has its challenges. When I approach a corner, men think they must beat me, which has led to many tough moments. You need to be competitive and aggressive. It's hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into the sport. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It's encouraging to see more women joining the sport each year. For me, the thrill of saloon car racing comes from striving for perfection."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I either cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There’s a lot of pressure before races, and I really push myself during competitions. I often wonder why I do this, and I realize it’s because a) I feel happier when I’m fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t push myself, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the media, 90% of the focus is on the men's events, with only 10% mentioning the women's results. The prize money is also less for women. However, we have now established an International Triathlon Women's Commission to address these issues."

**The Day I Met Picasso**

Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 78 years old. Even from a distance, he could easily recognize Picasso, who was having lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old, unreliable van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of my time drawing and was lucky to have my sketchbook with me when I saw the famous artist.

Picasso was known to be a private person who usually stayed away from others while he worked in the hills. So, I was surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. Without my friend's encouragement, I would never have approached him to ask for his signature. I was nervous, but when I introduced myself and offered my sketchbook, he kindly agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added a lively drawing below. Even though Picasso's art was often abstract, it usually connected to real things, so his lines might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.

I thanked him and started a hesitant conversation. Since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was even worse, an American woman at the table helped translate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak freely. Still, I managed to tell Picasso how much I loved art and admired his work. After a while, I went back to my boat to show my friend what I had done. He noticed that Picasso was still having lunch and asked, "Is that all?" He encouraged me to go back and take advantage of the opportunity, suggesting I could draw Picasso's portrait.

With my sketchbook in hand, I returned to Picasso's table. I decided not to ask if I could draw him, as I feared he might say no. Instead, I stood by the table, set up my pad, took out a crayon, and began to draw. When Picasso saw me, he smiled mischievously and made it hard for me to draw by acting out funny expressions. He rolled his eyes, stuck out his tongue, and made silly shapes with his hands. Although it was tempting to give up, his playful spirit felt like a challenge. I sensed he wanted to see how determined I was.

Eventually, Picasso settled down and allowed me to study him without distractions. He looked strong and alert, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed much younger than his age, with bright, dark eyes that were full of life. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he appeared to be in his own world, quietly focused on his thoughts.

When the American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my portrait, I felt embarrassed and said it wasn't good enough. However, he insisted, and when I showed him my drawing, he nodded approvingly. To my surprise, he then asked for my crayon. He quickly drew a bearded face on the paper, finishing in just a few seconds. His drawing was lively and different from my careful work. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with a single, joyful line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks.

I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. The American woman explained that he said I already had his signature. So, there were limits to his generosity! Looking back, I feel incredibly lucky. Meeting Picasso and receiving his attention meant a great deal to me.

**Talking Shop**

Have you ever gone into a store and ended up buying more than you planned? This article explains the techniques that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.

**A. The Image of Freshness**  
Supermarkets know that customers value fresh food. To create this impression, they often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They might also have a bakery that fills the air with the smell of fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, are chosen because they remind people of fresh produce. However, most items sold in supermarkets, like frozen foods and cleaning products, do not fit this fresh image.

**B. Displaying to Advantage**  
The placement of products in a store is crucial for sales. Supermarkets use computer systems to find out which areas attract the most shoppers. They place high-profit items in these spots, while also using eye-level shelves to catch attention. Special offer bins are placed strategically to attract bargain hunters. Another tactic is to place related items together, like desserts near ice cream.

**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost essentials like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers must walk past more expensive items to reach them. Chain stores also position popular products away from the entrance, hoping that loyal customers will search for them and encounter other tempting products along the way.

**D. Less Sells More**  
In recent years, chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from a crowded display style to a more boutique-like approach, showcasing limited fashion items. This gives the impression of exclusivity, even though the clothing is still mass-produced. Their success comes from both good design and appealing clothing.

**E. Tempting Totals**  
Food shoppers often focus more on the total cost of their shopping rather than the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with higher-priced items to attract customers. They may even sell some staples at a loss to bring people in, a strategy known as "loss leaders." They achieve low prices by buying in bulk and negotiating discounts with manufacturers.

**F. The All-Important Price Tag**  
Shoppers in chain stores tend to buy fewer items and pay more attention to individual prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This pricing strategy also helps reduce theft, as employees must ring up sales to give change.

**G. Lighting to Effect**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully consider lighting. Chain stores aim for lighting that resembles natural daylight, helping customers see the true colors of clothing. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to make fresh produce look more appealing.

**H. Walk This Way**  
Many chain stores use different carpet patterns to guide shoppers through the store. These paths, known as the "Yellow Brick Road," encourage customers to explore. Some stores, like Marks and Spencer, use more inviting carpets in sales areas to draw shoppers in.

**I. In-Store Promotion**  
As you enter a supermarket, you are often greeted by large, colorful images of delicious food, which can be hard to resist if you are hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that display advertisements as you shop. These trolleys aim to attract impulse buyers and claim to increase sales by about 30%.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**

Chris Bonnington, aged 58, is famous for reaching the top of Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, who is 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England.

Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, documenting their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while I was working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sail, where I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first experience on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to shore to practice climbing. The route was challenging, but I was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. He moved quietly and confidently.

Eventually, we reached a steep drop. I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before, and he said he hadn’t, so I showed him how. After I finished, Robin politely asked if he could descend using the ropes from his boat. He was used to using his arms, while I wanted him to use his legs. I was a bit worried, but he managed to lower himself safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I formed a strong friendship. His suggestion to combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural progression from our Skye adventure.

I was very impressed by Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin always consulted the crew first. Most of the time, no one dared to give him advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making. Honestly, I found sailing quite challenging and boring. The moments of crisis were easier to handle because they got my adrenaline pumping. However, spending day after day in the middle of the ocean was tough for me. I prefer being on land and am not very handy. In contrast, Robin is a natural sailor who enjoys fixing the engine and repairing the toilet. I realized that Robin didn’t really need my help, which sometimes made me feel useless.

The crew was also cramped, with six people on a 32-foot yacht designed for four. At least on a mountain expedition, you can get some space from each other. When we arrived in Greenland and it was my turn to lead the expedition, I found it hard to take responsibility for Robin’s safety. There were many times while climbing when if Robin fell, he could have pulled me down with him. I had to be very careful about that. I also underestimated how difficult the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. The first time we tried to reach the top, we were climbing for 24 hours straight. On the way down, we were so tired that we almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin faced many challenges, but he completely trusted me and just followed my lead. When it became too difficult and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted my decision. I knew he was also worried about the boat and whether it would be safe in the ice, but he still wanted to try climbing the mountain again.

The only time we had a serious issue was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns keeping watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me, thinking he could handle it alone. The night before, I had almost fallen asleep. I felt he didn’t trust me, which made me insecure, and I expressed my feelings. Robin quickly reassured me that I was misunderstanding the situation. While we enjoyed our trip to Skye, we didn’t truly get to know each other until the end of the Greenland expedition. I discovered that beneath his tough exterior, Robin is a kind-hearted and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been part of human life since ancient times, appearing in many colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this rich heritage.

**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
Humans have eaten apples since prehistoric times. In neolithic Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, people left apple remains near their homes by lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these areas and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient humans even stored dried apple halves for winter. These apples were wild crab apples, small and shriveled, known in Ancient Britain as "windings." They were very different from the apples we eat today.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned advanced fruit-growing techniques from the Romans, which were further developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including how to make cider, was brought to Britain during Roman times. One dessert apple, called Decio, was likely introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, many Roman apple varieties did not thrive in Britain, and Norman varieties soon became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new apple varieties, which are the ancestors of most Western apples today.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
By the thirteenth century, several apple types were well-established in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, noted in 1204 for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a popular cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century, giving rise to the term "costermonger," meaning a street seller of fruits and vegetables. However, the country faced challenges like droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, leading to fewer apples being produced and more being imported. This trend continued until the sixteenth century when King Henry VIII sent his chief fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple cultivation. Harris returned with many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and established the first modern-style orchard in Teynham, Kent.

**Settler Treasures (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them, considering them precious. Captain Bligh of the Bounty brought the first apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers carried them to America. In North America, the most famous apple planter was John Chapman, known as "Johnny Appleseed." Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. Native Americans saw him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees, unique clothing, and religious beliefs led to many folktales about him, including stories of him sleeping with bears.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time in Iowa, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt discovered a new apple tree growing from the roots of a dead tree. He named this apple "Hawkey." After sending it to a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed, "Delicious!" In 1895, this apple was introduced to the market as "Delicious" and became one of the most widely grown apples in the world.

**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. The daughter of convicts, Maria was independent and rejected her parents' criminal past. She worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales, and was known as "Granny Smith" for managing the family farm and orchard. In 1868, she found a small tree growing among discarded fruit, transplanted it, and soon harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. When asked about the tree's origin, she said, "Well, it's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish," referring to both the fruit and her own background.

**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown globally, from Himachal Pradesh in India to luxury orchards in Africa. However, most apples are commercially grown and come from only a few varieties, often chosen for their red skin or ability to travel well, rather than for their taste. This trend of uniformity is dulling our taste and reducing genetic diversity. While amateur gardeners in the UK have preserved many old apple varieties, the US has lost most of its apples from a century ago. Fortunately, consumers are starting to demand more variety. We cannot rely solely on amateur gardeners to save apple diversity or any other food. We must advocate for a world that values and protects natural diversity for everyone's benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups Leave Few Footprints**

We travel in small, informal groups, usually averaging 16 people, led by experienced guides. This setup allows you to discover more about the places we visit and connect with local cultures. It creates a stimulating experience for all travelers.

Our travelers are interesting people who are ready to face new challenges and enjoy unique adventures. Most are from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. It’s hard to define Explore Worldwide because each trip is unique. We categorize our adventures into 8 groups, highlighting key activities and interests. Each category showcases special features of a tour, but many other factors contribute to the overall success of our trips, such as unique places, cultural encounters, and personal involvement.

Most trips have a strong cultural aspect, with some focusing primarily on local cultures and historical sites. Destinations of cultural interest include Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Yemen, Turkey, Greece, India, Bhutan, Thailand, China, Peru, Bolivia, Guatemala, and Belize. Our wildlife safaris take you to some of the best game parks in the world, allowing thrilling encounters with animals in their natural habitats. In Africa, you might have the chance to explore the wild on foot, tracking animals like the rare silver-back mountain gorilla or going on bush walks with local guides. Exploring remote wilderness areas is an exciting adventure. These places, like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert, offer unique experiences for adventurous travelers.

Richard Nerurkar, a long-distance runner and one of Britain's best 10,000-metre athletes, visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. Located ten miles south of the equator, a sunny mountain path leads from a quiet road in Nairobi. This path begins the journey up Mount Kenya, the country’s highest peak, which is covered in glaciers. This beautiful but remote place is called Nanyuki, and for the past three years, it has been my base for winter training in Kenya's Central Highlands. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners until my fourth winter training trip to Kenya. 

On this trip, I decided to break my routine. I participated in my first race in Kenya, where the air has less oxygen, and I stayed at the national team training camp, where the best runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I was invited by the national team coach after I finished fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. This was an opportunity I could not miss. Training at high altitude helps produce more red blood cells, which improves the body’s ability to carry oxygen. This has been proven by the success of many Kenyan runners.

My first race in Africa, which took place before my time at the training camp, was also significant because it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent. It was a humbling experience for me, as 41 runners finished ahead of me, and all but three were Kenyan. I felt I had run well, but I know that Kenyan success is not only due to the altitude. Kenyan runners are also known for their straightforward approach to running. Their running style looks effortless, their diet is simple, and they seem to enjoy competing.

One important aspect of Kenyan success that is often overlooked is their training. My time at the training camp revealed how they train. The camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mount Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and tropical plants. The facilities are basic, with athletes living among regular students in shared dormitories. 

Each day at the camp includes three workouts: a relaxed morning run, interval training in the late morning, and a steady run in the afternoon. The daily schedule starts at six in the morning. We would wake up and gather for instructions from the coaches before the morning run. The coach reminded us, "Run easy, you have a hard job today." We covered about 40 kilometers each day, which is just under a marathon distance. Sundays were different, with only one run of 20 kilometers, which was a nice break from the usual routine.

Life at the camp was simple. A splash of water on the face and brushing teeth were enough for morning preparations. Breakfast included tea, bread, and boiled eggs in a small dining area. Lunch and dinner were similar, featuring ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, we would drive to one of the streams from Mount Kenya's melting glaciers to wash properly.

By the end of my stay, I had a deeper appreciation for Kenyan success. It cannot be explained by genetics, upbringing, or altitude alone. I began to think that the simplicity of life in the mountains, the tough training, and the passion for success might be the true reasons behind Kenya's dominance in long-distance running.

**The Challenges of Mass Marketing**

Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This decline started in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The problems with advertising are deeper and are happening all over the world. The sad truth is that advertising has not kept up with the fast changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large audiences and mass media, but as more brands and media options have appeared, target markets have become smaller and more specific. Even campaigns for well-known brands should focus on smaller audiences, but they usually do not. This is a major reason why advertising is not working well.

Think about your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only buy a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you are unlikely to buy more than a few hundred different brands. For durable goods, you might buy about a dozen a year, and for cars, you typically buy one every three years. You may not buy many clothes either, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Even if you consider all the different products and services you buy, it is likely that you do not purchase more than 400 different brands in a year. 

In contrast, there are about 32,500 branded goods and services that are advertised. If we ignore the 23,000 brands that spend less than £50,000 a year on advertising, we can focus on the 9,500 brands that are individually listed and analyzed. The average consumer buys only 400 of these 9,500 brands, and not all of these purchases are due to advertising. This means that only about 4 percent of the advertised brands are actually bought by consumers. 

You might think that you are different and not influenced by advertising, but most people feel the same way. The reality is that most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. There is always waste in advertising because not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. People only remember a small number of ads and ignore the rest, so some waste is unavoidable. However, this does not mean that advertising is not effective. Many advertisements have shown that it can work. Advertisers need to reach a large audience to connect with the smaller group that will actually respond, as they cannot know in advance who will be interested.

Even with careful targeting, advertisers can reduce waste but can never completely eliminate it. For example, even the best direct mail campaigns do not get a 100 percent response rate. This is a key difference between advertising through media and selling directly to customers. A salesperson might succeed with every potential client they meet, but this is not possible with media advertising. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would communicate with them directly instead of using mass media.

Any advertiser who can gain one million new customers, which is about 2 percent of the adult population, is considered successful. For popular products like soap powder, the top brands would be thrilled to gain a million extra customers. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can attract more than 2 percent of the population is seen as very successful, even though this is still a small part of the total audience. To revive advertising, its messages will need to be more carefully targeted than ever before.

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Visits Britain's Most Eco-Friendly Home**

Charles Clover explores one of the most environmentally-friendly homes in Britain, located in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This area has some interesting features. First, it is home to Southwell Minster, an ancient cathedral that is not well-known. Writers who care about the environment appreciate the pagan 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen in the cathedral's thirteenth-century chapter house. 

The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. This house is designed to be very green. The Vales collect rainwater for drinking and washing, recycle sewage into compost for their garden, and use waste heat from their electrical appliances and their own body heat to warm the house. This includes heat from their three teenage children and their two cats, Edison and Faraday. 

The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the burnt-orange brick of the town's nineteenth-century buildings and received approval from planners, even though it is in a conservation area. When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will notice complete silence. The house is very well-insulated, with special triple-glazed windows that keep out noise. 

Once inside, you must take off your shoes, as Robert insists. The atmosphere is calm and quiet. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it circulates through the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow, as the house is designed to be draught-proof. Even the cats have their own air-locked door.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have cared about the environment for many years. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s called *The Autonomous House*. They aimed to create a building that produced no carbon dioxide and eventually decided to eliminate the need for mains water as well. They designed composting toilets, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep drinking water clean, filtering it before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher because they believe it is wrong to use strong detergents.

Robert explains, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is much better for the environment without living in darkness. It doesn’t have to be medieval." The only medieval feature is the hall, which includes the fireplace and staircase, stretching the full height of the house. 

The Vales do not pay water bills, and last winter, their house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use for heating. Soon, they will install solar water heating panels and equipment in the garden, which will allow the house to generate more electricity than it needs. Eventually, they hope to have enough electricity to charge an electric car. 

The only source of heating is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which they claim to use only during the coldest winter days. When I visited in February, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than what is usually expected, but he found it comfortable because there were no draughts and everything felt the same temperature. 

Robert points out that a woman from the early 1900s felt comfortable at 12.5°C because of her warm clothing. He suggests that people living in houses built before 1900 should return to that way of living, although this idea may not be popular. 

The secret to the house's success is its low-tech design, which means there is little that can go wrong. Most materials were sourced from local builders and installed by local craftsmen, making the house affordable to build—costing the same per square meter as low-cost rental housing. Unsurprisingly, commercial building companies are not keen on this idea.

Text: 'The Camera Never Lies

Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, saw himself as a rational and scientific person. However, in 1920, he came across photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real evidence of these tiny creatures. He published these photos with an article where he accepted fairies as supernatural beings. It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out images of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos are undeniably beautiful, but the simplicity of the trick challenges a common belief about photography: that the camera cannot lie. In reality, it can, and it always has. Nowadays, we often use computer software to edit our digital images, and it is a misconception that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the very beginning, when cameras started capturing images, those images were being changed.'

**Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has captured human imagination, and blacksmiths, who work with it, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were respected like doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral, and the elegant metal designs in French and Belgian Art Nouveau architecture were crafted by talented blacksmiths.

However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased. Heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used the beautiful wrought iron that blacksmiths created. In the last ten years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and a more creative approach to interior design. Still, much of the work produced looks quite traditional, with manufacturers of gates and balconies often labeling their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find trendy design stores filled with rusty candlesticks and similar items.

Fortunately, there are new opportunities for blacksmiths, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote their craft. The first event is an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), which opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, believes we might be entering a new "Iron Age," as both the public and blacksmiths are becoming more aware of the craft. 

Modern power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, twist, and weld it with less effort. Dawson explains, "These artists now have a material that lets them express themselves." The exhibition features about 250 pieces, including bookends and a spiral staircase, with prices starting at £90 and going up to several thousand pounds. Most of the money will go to the individual artists, but a portion of each sale will support the Association's efforts to promote quality ironwork.

Dawson has created an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a hand-blown glass shade. He describes his style as letting steel bend and flow into shape when it is hot, comparing it to drawing with metal in space. Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike other metals that are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a trained jeweler, finds it magical because it is soft when hot but becomes hard and unyielding when it cools.

Ann Catrin Evans creates mild steel door knockers and handles inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, while another resembles a Celtic cross. She appreciates the cold, hard nature of steel and how it feels permanent. No other metal has provided as much visual pleasure or a sense of security. It seems likely that iron will continue to be used decoratively for many years to come, as long as we can avoid more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Gave Up Smoking**

I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. She shouted, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was a bit annoying, even for me. 

The stop-smoking session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I hadn’t planned to quit, and I didn’t really want to. I felt pressured by anti-smoking groups, which I still resent. Plus, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than friends who lived healthier lives.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of "The Easy Way to Stop Smoking" to write an article about others trying to quit. I said, "I won’t be trying to stop; I’m here to write, not to quit, so it wouldn’t be fair to expect your method to work on me." I thought I was being reasonable because I really enjoyed smoking. It gave me pleasure.

The counsellor seemed to understand me. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. I think the messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of quitting began to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling that didn’t involve anyone else. Could I also achieve other things?

In many ways, quitting was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, disappeared after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be the hardest part without cigarettes, but it turned out to be fine. I had believed I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was just relaxing at home on weekend mornings, and it still is. 

I’ve come to realize that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity in itself. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to adjust to—like eating out, waiting for a flight, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre break. These are all moments when I would have previously smoked.

**Dorothy Who?**

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, yet many people in Britain do not know her name. For the past four years, I have been testing my friends and acquaintances on their knowledge of her. When I tell them I am writing her biography, I watch their reactions. If they seem excited and say things like, "Surely there's already a biography?" they pass the test. 

Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? The fact that she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize should be enough. Anyone else with such an achievement in literature would be famous. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person, as complex as the crystals she studied. Her life reflects significant changes in the 20th century, including the progress of women's education and the globalization of science.

When I started my research, I wanted to read some scientific biographies. A friend of Hodgkin suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a close friend and worked in the same field. I went to the main bookstore in my university town, but I found no biographies of Pauling. I was surprised that he was not considered interesting enough for British readers, even though he was a highly influential chemist and a Nobel Prize winner in both chemistry and peace.

Even scientists have questioned the value of scientific biographies. Peter Medawar, a Nobel laureate, once said that the lives of scientists are often dull. If scientists think this way, it is not surprising that publishers and booksellers do too. This attitude shows the divide between the arts and sciences, where only the most famous scientists get biographies. 

It is not true that scientists lead less interesting lives than artists, writers, or politicians. Some scientists are very careful about their public image. For example, a leading geneticist told me he would be happy to discuss his work but did not want to be quoted or photographed because he did not want to seem like he was promoting himself. This reluctance to share personal stories can create a false impression of science and may discourage young people from pursuing it.

Fortunately, things are changing. Today, scientists often appear in public in ways other than just scientific interviews. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins presents awards on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car commercials. These activities help make scientists more relatable to the public.

The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be dry and overly respectful, often ignoring the personal lives of scientists. This changed with Richard Feynman's book, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", which is both funny and touching. Recently, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie have been portrayed with their flaws. Readers find it interesting to see how creative geniuses deal with personal challenges, even if those challenges seem unrelated to their scientific work.

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her science. She made significant discoveries, including the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, for which she won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964, and insulin, which her team solved in 1969. She pushed scientific techniques to new levels of complexity. However, she also raised three children and was married to a husband who was often away due to his work as a historian. While her personal life may not directly relate to her scientific achievements, it shows her ability to balance different aspects of her life.

There is much in Hodgkin's life that is interesting to everyone, but it is also important to recognize her scientific contributions. Scientific inquiry was her passion, as it must be for any successful scientist. The challenge for biographers is to convey this passion. Most readers may not have the scientific background to understand complex ideas without detailed explanations. However, understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort.

It is unfortunate that educated people, who would feel embarrassed not to recognize a famous literary or artistic figure, often remain unaware of the rich legacy of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

**Margaret and Her Water Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a "sixth sense." She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Farmers whose wells have dried up are increasingly seeking her help. Along with her husband, Margaret runs a well-drilling business that uses modern tools like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, she relies only on her hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.

This ability to locate water, minerals, and lost items underground is known as dowsing. There are many theories about how dowsing works, ranging from scientific ideas like magnetism to spiritual beliefs. One of the most believable theories suggests that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. It is thought that dowsers can sense these vibrations while standing on the ground. Some dowsers claim they can "feel" water, while others say they can "smell" it, as smell is a very strong sense.

In recent years, due to droughts, Margaret has been very busy, with a waiting list of almost six weeks at one point. Most of her clients are farmers with dry wells. She explains, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other clients include owners of remote cottages or barns that have become holiday homes, where running water pipes over long distances is too expensive. There are also golf course developers who need water for their clubhouses.

Margaret typically looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She emphasizes that wells cannot be drilled where there is a risk of contamination from waste. The water she finds is usually in cracks in solid rock, and if it is brought up properly, it should be clean. However, in Cornwall, where they work, there are many minerals, so they must be careful about iron in the water. 

Another important factor is electricity to power the pump. It is costly to run electricity over long distances, so it is best if the well is close to existing power sources. Once she considers all these factors, Margaret begins her search for water. 

For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum still and moves it over the map. It will swing when she is above a water source. After identifying possible locations on the map, she walks over the fields with her hazel stick, which is forked and equal in size on both sides. 

"When I am above water, I feel a strange sensation; I sway a little. When that feeling goes away, I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill." She holds the two forks of the stick with both hands and pulls them slightly apart to create tension. "When water is directly below, the straight part of the stick rises. It is crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If we drill even a little off, we might miss the water completely."

Margaret's husband also dowse the same area. Usually, but not always, they agree on the exact drilling spot. If they disagree, they will not drill until they find a consensus.

Margaret Wilkins is not alone in her unique skill; many anthropologists and writers have been intrigued by this mysterious intuition. She describes it as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this "sixth sense," it would be hard to understand how her family could continue to thrive in their well-drilling business year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It might be exciting to try something completely different. We arranged this for four people - here’s what happened.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda, 23, is a young mother with two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, 30, who works as a waitress in a fancy London restaurant. 

Amanda had never been in a place like that before. It was dark, loud, and crowded, which was very different from her hometown. She felt nervous about her new job. Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was a whole new challenge! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when Amanda tried, the drinks slipped off the tray and spilled everywhere. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and reassured her that everyone makes mistakes at first.

By 11:30 am, a line of customers was waiting outside, and Amanda felt even more anxious. Luckily, the ordering system was automated, so she didn’t have to memorize everything. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she struggled to hear customers over the loud music. She often had to ask them to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was exhausted and just wanted to soak her feet in hot water. One waitress told her it had been a "quiet" day, which surprised Amanda. She realized that waitressing is much harder than she thought. She used to think it was an easy job, but it actually requires a lot of energy and a friendly attitude, especially during busy times. Amanda felt relieved to return to her children, as being a mother seemed much easier after her day as a waitress.

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy, who is 30, was nervous about being a mother for a day, but she was also excited. She had heard that Amanda's daughters could be a handful, but she thought she could manage. 

After Amanda left for the restaurant, Cindy had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, she thought she would have some quiet time. But she was wrong! A note from Amanda reminded her that she still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry. 

At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, went shopping, and then took her home for lunch. When she brought Sophie home from school, things got chaotic. The girls turned the couch into a trampoline and played a loud game. Cindy thought they would tire out soon, but they didn’t. She tried to get them to take a nap by 8 pm, but then the girls kept asking for water, just to come downstairs and watch TV. 

Cindy realized that taking care of two small children was very tiring. There was no time for herself, and the responsibility felt overwhelming. However, she enjoyed the day overall.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary, 42, runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, 30, a primary school teacher. 

On the farm, Rosemary usually wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 am felt like a treat! She was unsure how to dress for school, wanting to look appropriate instead of in her farm clothes. 

At school, she faced about 400 students during assembly and hoped she wouldn’t stand out. In math class, the children worked in small groups, which was different from her own school experience. She also helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, she was tired and looked forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. 

After lunch, she attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. The day included a silent reading lesson and a fun French lesson where the children practiced speaking with her. Finally, they had Physical Education, and by then, Rosemary was exhausted, while the children still had lots of energy. Speaking in front of the class was the hardest part for her. Although teachers have more holidays, she decided she preferred farming.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary arrived at Rosemary's farm at 8:30 am, only to find that Rosemary had already been working for three hours! Rosemary's farm is large, with many cows and sheep. 

Hilary spent most of the morning in the ice-cream shop, filling milk containers and making ice cream. She had to resist the temptation to taste everything! At lunchtime, she checked on the sheep and helped a ewe that had fallen over. If sheep are not checked regularly, they can die, which is especially difficult in winter. 

After feeding the calves, Hilary started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year! Hilary found the day lonely and missed being around children, as animals don’t talk back. The hardest part of farming is that there is no time off; cows need to be milked twice daily, making it hard to plan vacations. Although farming seems romantic, the reality is quite different. The income can be unstable, and Hilary wouldn’t want to rely on the weather.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It is interesting how many successful musicians come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in a rural area of southern Sweden, has become a unique trumpet player at the age of 30. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new pieces. When you meet him, he looks youthful and has a bright personality, much like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London’s top concert halls, and a television feature was made about his work, filmed in both London and Sweden.

Hardenberger was born near Malmo and began his musical journey with a Christmas gift when he was eight years old. His father, who did not play music but enjoyed Louis Armstrong, decided to give his son a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played constantly. His mother arranged for him to take lessons from the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson, who recognized Hardenberger's natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a dedicated teacher from the beginning, someone who was passionate about the trumpet and always looking for ways to improve.

Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to create a perfect one. There will always be some imperfections, and no two mouthpieces are exactly alike. He believes it is important to understand these imperfections and learn to work with them. From the start, he had a talent for finding the right balance and forming a connection with the instrument. He notes that even as a child, his unique sound was already noticeable, which was the first thing he developed.

Unlike John Wallace, a prominent British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger has always seen himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also focused on solo performances. His parents supported his ambition to pursue a career in trumpet playing and provided him with opportunities to practice. At 15, it was time to decide where he would study. Although Bo Nilsson suggested America, it was considered too far and dangerous, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud discouraged him from joining an orchestra, saying that playing in one is like doing hard labor.

Hardenberger was aware that he played better than many of his peers, but it was only after entering a competition at 17 that he realized he had a special ability to connect with the audience. Thibaud encouraged him to participate for experience. Hardenberger prepared only for the first round but advanced to the second round, where he was familiar with most of the pieces. However, in the final round, he faced a concerto that intimidated him. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance and realized that even though he felt he played poorly, people were still listening.

Hardenberger's honest view of his work might seem arrogant, but that is not the case. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing his gift of communication, believing that trying to explain it could ruin it. He feels that the true power of music lies in its ability to move people.

**New In Paperback**

A. The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a remarkable tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insights. It is a challenging but rewarding read.

B. Harriet is a composed middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who had always been a good student and never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe physically recovers but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him takes over her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unexpected friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures the mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her son.

C. This book, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, vividly imagined through the daydreams of the young main character, Throfinn Ragnarson. He suddenly disappears in the story but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

D. After his recent successful book, the author has written a sequel filled with the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life that made the first book so enjoyable. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is approaching her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's outlook on life remains a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, while Rosie supports her in her entertaining manipulation of friends and suitors. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness that lies beneath the ordinary moments of life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright spots of human experience.

E. Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences as they prepare to return home, their spirits uplifted by life at sea. The author employs striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which can be both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who share their experiences in different professions, discussing the positives, negatives, and their daily routines.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7:00 am, and arrive at work by 8:00 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries last about three hours, but some can take all day. There have been times when I’ve worked for ten hours straight without a break. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. While I don’t feel stressed during surgery, I sometimes worry about my next day’s work. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it is incredibly rewarding, even if there are failures. From 10:00 am to 1:00 pm, I run an out-patients' clinic where I explain the surgeries to patients. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to them, but time pressure can make it hard to comfort them if they get upset. I usually leave work between 6:00 pm and 8:00 pm. I am on call some nights and weekends, and I always carry my pager. When I’m on holiday, I often worry about my patients for the first few days and sometimes dream about operating."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our projects and any issues. I work in a team of three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. My work is mostly about production, with only 10-15% being actual design. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they approve, we create estimates and budgets, and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also coordinate with printers to ensure everything is done on time. Managing multiple projects can be very stressful, and deadlines are always tight. Lunch is at 1:00 pm for an hour, and we often go to a pub. If the client is happy with my designs, it feels great, but it’s disappointing when a project gets rejected. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but it can be much later. I find it hard to relax after a busy day."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7:00 am, but on some days, I have to get up between 4:30 am and 5:00 am for long-haul flights. At around 10:30 or 11:00 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I need to be careful about my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snack throughout the day. Clients often ask for recommendations for restaurants or shops, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, which allows me to plan my routes. While most passengers are polite, some can be rude. However, I have built good relationships with my regular clients. I sometimes hear private conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I must be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11:00 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7:00 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and start my first job. My assistant and I mainly maintain gardens we have designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each location. Around 11:00 am, we take a break for a big breakfast at a local café. In summer, I might work until 10:00 pm, and in winter until 4:30 pm. I run the business from home, so when I return, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants a new garden, I usually schedule a consultation in the evening. We focus on using old materials to create gardens that look historic. Sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren’t great, but it’s very satisfying to see a garden we’ve designed bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone ringing. I sleep well because my job is physically demanding, and I’m always tired at the end of the day."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. As the assistant resident engineer, I oversee the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I check that the contractors are following the schedule and safety guidelines while minimizing environmental impact. I help coordinate the site professionals and solve any problems. The contractors start work at 6:00 am, so my first task is to find out what happened since I left the night before. The rest of my day depends on what I learn from the clerk of works. I usually have paperwork to review or design questions to answer. Lunch is typically from 2:00 pm to 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. Since we monitor the contractors' work, it can create tension, so we need to maintain a good relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but I act quickly if something urgent arises. I usually leave the site around 6:00 pm and am on call all the time."

**Careers: Six People Discuss Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and reach the office by 7:30 am. My job involves managing customer development programs for our credit card users. I am responsible for launching and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I need to stay in touch with current card users, attract new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I oversee advertising for the membership program across Europe, which means I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies to create strategies and plan future projects. I have meetings throughout the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week to address any issues. When I’m in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and start by reviewing the mail, which includes ten to twenty demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices from musicians and studios. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know that these represent people's hard work, so I try to provide helpful feedback. I can tell if the sound fits our record label. Once I sign a band, we begin working on their first album, selecting songs, a producer, and additional musicians. I also communicate my vision for the album to the marketing team. I manage budgets and expenses as well. I usually leave work by 7:00 pm, and most evenings I attend concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new bands in one night. I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to a record to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I check the mail and my schedule to see if we have any client meetings that day. I enjoy showing customers around the showroom and love making sales, knowing the furniture will go to a good home. We sell antiques priced between £1,000 and £6,000, sourcing them from auctions, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work closely with our full-time restorer and other specialists. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while enjoying coffee to stay updated on the industry, and I often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I handle the accounts once a month and do tax returns every three months. I leave work at 5:30 pm, and it usually takes me about an hour to relax after work.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set shift schedule. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am and start my shift at 7:00 am, taking over from the night shift. I work at one of four control positions in the tower, rotating every hour and a half. The air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and the watch manager work closely together to manage aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing me to read about new air traffic regulations between 12:00 am and 4:00 am. This job is quite stressful, and I take sick days seriously if I feel unwell. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually the general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. My first task is to start the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is watching the register and coordinate lunch breaks for staff. In the morning, I assist customers in finding and ordering books. I enjoy helping customers, although it can be frustrating when they come in with reviews and expect me to gather many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm on weekdays, publishers' representatives visit, and I discuss upcoming titles with them. I need to estimate how many copies of a new title we might sell and ensure timely delivery. My early shift ends at 5:45 pm. On two days a week, I work a late shift, during which I close the computer system, lock up, and go home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about events in my region. My job is to assess financial risks for multinational companies operating abroad, warning clients about potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss the stories I will follow. My first executive preview must be online by 10:00 am, and my second by 11:00 am, so I work quickly to gather information. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events and stay updated. I usually leave work around 6:00 pm, but it can be hard to relax, and I often find myself awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

**A. What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others, brings about change, and guides people towards a common goal. Leadership is not about physical traits like height, nor is it just about being smart. According to Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is crucial, and a good leader should express it clearly and confidently. Dixon emphasizes the importance of saying "I believe" instead of "I think."

**B. Recognizing Leadership Potential**  
John van Maurik, who directs a Leadership in Management course, believes that most people have more leadership potential than they realize. Becoming a leader involves recognizing and developing your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it’s easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. However, leadership is now seen as essential for effective management.

**C. Comparing Bosses**  
Think about the best and worst boss you’ve had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? A good leader motivates and supports you, while a bad leader makes you feel unimportant and blames you when things go wrong. The first one leads well; the second one just manages poorly.

**D. Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers prefer to work within set limits, while leaders create new possibilities. Micheal Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, states that a good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can change a discouraged organization, whether it’s a business, a sports team, or a country.

**E. Improving Your Leadership Skills**  
Whether you are a boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons to consider:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Discover your passions and act on them when you feel inspired.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is an important part of who you are.  
- Collaboration is valuable, but sometimes strong leadership is necessary. Try different leadership styles. If you usually negotiate, take the lead instead, and see how it changes the results.  
- Set goals and strive to exceed them. Identify areas in your job where being a leader can improve your effectiveness and career opportunities.

**F. Developing Leadership Skills**  
- Leadership doesn’t just happen; it develops through taking charge, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and provide feedback.  
- Don’t assume your leadership style will be immediately accepted. It might even push people away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t need to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to those who matter. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your input is essential and how you can help others become leaders.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Film Critic Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before "Titanic," director James Cameron created this tense Cold War thriller about oil workers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The friendly banter and brave attitude of foreman Bud and his team remind us of similar heroes in films by Howard Hawks. The production design and special effects are very impressive, but the dialogue and character development are lacking. Despite the skill in filmmaking, the story feels like typical B-movie material.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal, directed by Andrew Marton, offers a different perspective compared to Terrence Malick's recent film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's film is more traditional, focusing on a single soldier and his difficult relationship with his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has its strong moments, especially in a flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife, which is portrayed more harshly than Malick's softer imagery.

**C. On Guard**  
This entertaining swashbuckler, loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, stands out among musketeer adventures. Fabrice Luchini plays a cunning villain who secretly causes chaos. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, though his role is short. Daniel Auteuil, while perhaps too serious for a fun film, also shines as an acrobat-turned-swordsman. The filmmakers use familiar costume-drama clichés with such humor and charm that it doesn’t feel like a problem.

**D. Character**  
Set in early 20th-century Rotterdam, this film tells a serious story but looks overly detailed, resembling a museum exhibit. Jan Decleir plays the grim bailiff Dreverhaven, who is harsh when evicting tenants. His troubled relationship with his son is central to the plot, but the filmmakers focus too much on historical details, neglecting the dark and powerful story.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This newly remastered video release highlights director Leone's skill, especially in sound editing, where every sound is clear. The storytelling is harsh, and whenever there is a quiet moment, Morricone's powerful music brings excitement. Morally, there is little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Eli Wallach), as they all act unscrupulously in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
Promoted as featuring "forty-eight international stars," this three-hour war epic by Darryl Zanuck has four directors and 23,000 extras, making it feel overly complicated. The early scenes, where battle-hardened veterans wait for news about the invasion, drag on for both the audience and the soldiers. While it is an impressive logistical achievement, it is best experienced on the big screen. Watching it on video diminishes the experience.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is truly engaging. The story follows a lawyer who is trying to start a new practice after leaving a powerful law firm. He unexpectedly has to defend his boss's wife, who is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, with the outcome uncertain until the very end, and there is a surprising twist in the final pages. This is a strong debut in a popular genre.

**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a bang and follows the charming Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the Italian Renaissance aristocracy. He gets caught up in a mix of politics, church intrigue, and serious murder, but we are confident he will uncover the guilty parties. The plot is complex, and the book is a bit long, but it is still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, created by first-time author Sarah Lacey. Leah is a tax inspector who finds herself in a unique position to investigate when a strange man collapses at her feet. Despite facing criticism and the disapproval of a handsome local detective, Leah is brave and resourceful, making her a compelling character.

**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a smart private investigator, who helps his friend Hawk remove drug dealers from a troubled neighborhood in Boston. The dialogue is quick and sharp, and while there are fewer deaths than usual, the story includes more philosophical themes. As always, Parker delivers high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann features her regular detectives, Pete Decker and Marge Dunn, as they investigate a burglary and attack at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's straightforward writing style and keen observation of unusual human behavior make this an enjoyable mystery.

**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by the husband-and-wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but the action takes place outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. The book skillfully combines elements of romance, money, and violence to create a gripping suspense novel.

**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw presents actor Philip Fletcher as the intended victim. A funny group of characters comes together to film a Robin Hood story, but Philip feels that this is not the right direction for his career. While Simon Shaw usually entertains, this shift from dark comedy to farce does not quite meet his usual high standards.

**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best work in a while. It follows Canadian police as they search for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The slow and skillful build-up of tension, along with the portrayal of the intelligent but troubled robber, elevates this story above the typical detective novel.

I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age have decided to take this leap. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent out my flat to travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old and feeling nervous. I have traveled before; after university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America. When I returned, I promised myself I would do it again someday. But then life happened—I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning a salary. Gradually, I realized I was sacrificing my own happiness for my salary. When I handed in my resignation, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. 

Now, I have no ties. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn’t trade places with me, they envy my freedom. I’m no longer in a relationship and don’t have strong career ambitions. I feel I should make the most of this freedom, if only for my friends’ sake! But why am I so nervous? First, I need to make all the necessary arrangements. How can I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize the rental? And I still need to decide where to go. I tend to procrastinate and am already behind my planned schedule. I thought, “I might as well enjoy the summer in England,” and then, “Why not wait for the start of the football season?” 

Letting go of emotional ties makes it even harder. I’m delaying because I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I be able to adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among younger backpackers? Maybe not. I’ve noticed that more Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to break free from their established lives and travel abroad. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says there is a growing realization that adventure is available: “People who always say, ‘I wish I had that opportunity’ are realizing they can have it anytime they want. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.”

For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, this trip is a chance to enjoy life before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says, “I’m willing to give up job security for this trip. There’s always a worry that I won’t move up the career ladder and will return to the same position, but I think it’s a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a symbolic act of defiance!” 

For Matt, who just left the Army, his year of travel was a time of change. “In the military, there’s a strict way of doing things. I needed to break free from that to live a normal life as a civilian.” While there are many reasons for traveling at this age, some common factors exist.
