Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says, “Today’s workforce is more flexible. Many people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.” Larger companies are even creating career-break policies, knowing that if they invest in training someone, it’s good to have them return rather than go to a competitor.

Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, a company that publishes stories of ordinary travelers, notes that more thirty-somethings are reassessing their lives. “If you’re not happy with your job—and many people aren’t—it’s no longer just about sticking it out. People now realize that opportunities exist and that a job isn’t for life anymore. Travel allows you to step back and think about your life.” 

Is giving in to wanderlust just another sign that my generation struggles with adulthood? Jennifer Cox disagrees. “It shows a better-educated, more stable society where we care less about just paying bills and more about living a balanced life. We’re taking the time to ask, ‘Is this what I want?’” Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, doesn’t think he’s running away. “It’s more about running towards something. I want to grab the things I desire.” However, he does feel some anxiety. “I’ll miss my comfortable routine—going to the office every day, saying ‘hi’ to everyone, and having my morning coffee.” 

I share Ben’s concerns about leaving behind a structured life with few challenges, and I’m not sure I would be making this journey if I hadn’t found my boss so unbearable. As Jennifer Cox points out, “This is common. There’s often a trigger, like a breakup or job loss, that pushes people to travel.” It may have taken a nudge to get me moving, but I’m now looking forward to the next 12 months with growing excitement. No matter what happens, I’ll take pride in having embraced life. I believe many of us older backpackers feel the same way.

**Plugging in the Home**

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from journalism and felt disconnected from the changes in technology. In this passage, she shares how she turned her home into an efficient workplace.

The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized that if I wanted to restart my journalism career, I needed to act fast. I felt like my skills were outdated, stuck in the 1980s when typewriters were the norm. I worried that no one would trust me to use a computer in a newsroom. Many job ads required experience in desktop publishing, which I didn’t have. I thought I would have a better chance of hosting a seminar on nuclear physics than learning to design a page on a computer. I was known in my family as the technophobe; even basic calculators confused me, and I still couldn’t figure out how to use the timer on the video.

I knew I had to change quickly. I thought leaving home before my children would be difficult, but then I entered a competition in a local newspaper. To my surprise, my family won a computer package. We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world, and terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing became part of our everyday language. We started chatting online with strangers from around the world. The children stopped watching TV, and I set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, a fax machine, a CD-ROM, and a modem connecting me to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home while still taking the kids to school.

My children were already comfortable with computers from school, but I was nervous, fearing I would lose my work by pressing the wrong button. I was wrong. Although I wasn’t very skilled, I learned the basics. It turned out to be logical and straightforward. With practice, I improved a little each day. I recently started freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I feel proud to have the best of both worlds.

How has the computer helped me? Since school, my desk has always been a chaotic mess, and I often lost important papers. The computer has made me more organized, especially with office tasks. Spreadsheets help me track income and expenses, and ready-made invoices and letterheads save me a lot of time. For a journalist, being online allows me to research stories, ask for information in journalism forums, and discuss working from home with people worldwide.

However, there are downsides to working from home. I can feel isolated without physical contact with others. There are also distractions, like household chores, and when the kids are home, we sometimes argue over who gets to use the computer. Still, many people are buying multimedia PCs, not just for education and entertainment, but also for the convenience of avoiding daily commutes to the city.

As we move into the next century, what defines home workers? A report called "PC Usage in UK Homes" describes the typical computer user as 38 years old and well-educated. Most own a personal computer, and many have a CD-ROM, laser printer, and modem. Considering this, I feel I am ahead of the game. Who knows, one day I might be emailing a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publishing my own magazine from home. It seems that the possibilities are endless in this digital age.

**The Tartan Museum**

The modern buildings of Scotland's national museum stand out in historic Edinburgh. But are the exhibits just as impressive? Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened.

You can't miss the new Museum of Scotland, located at the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh. It features a large yellow sandstone tower and unique, wedge-shaped buildings topped with a hanging garden. Last winter, the building received mixed reactions: some called it a "masterpiece" or "stunning," while others were more critical. Now, as the inside prepares for opening, the exhibitions may face similar opinions.

Forget debates about whether the museum tells a national story or follows a timeline. The answer is yes; it presents a rich collection of stories linked to important historical objects. There is a timeline to help visitors navigate, but it does not restrict the displays. The museum does not let its national treasures, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels and Holyrood chapel silver, be overshadowed by national pride.

The main concern is whether visitors will find the museum interesting enough to return. Dr. David Clarke, the head of exhibitions, believes that a visit should be enjoyable and visually appealing, aimed at those with little prior knowledge. Despite this openness, Clarke insists on showing only what experts know. He avoids displays that rely heavily on imagination, as he believes they misrepresent the past. The public deserves the truth.

The challenge for visitors is whether the stories of the objects can be told effectively using explanation panels, captions, and multimedia, with only about 30 computers available in the museum. With less than three days before the opening, it is still uncertain. However, some aspects are clear, such as the stunning views of Edinburgh Castle. 

Inside, visitors will notice a series of interconnected galleries of various sizes and shapes, with pale walls designed to resemble large stone blocks and deep display cases. Natural light pours in through narrow windows and roof lights, creating a space to appreciate each exhibit.

Thanks to a 12-member Junior board made up of 9- to 12-year-olds from across Scotland, the museum includes a Discovery Centre. The group wanted to create an interactive experience, and while they didn't achieve that, they did secure a dedicated hands-on area for children in what was supposed to be a temporary exhibition gallery. As a result, the Twentieth Century gallery on the top floor is the only temporary exhibition, featuring a mix of items chosen by Scottish people that have significantly impacted life in Scotland during the twentieth century. Suggestions included an electric guitar, televisions, thermos flasks, and favorite toys. While this idea is fun, it feels somewhat trivial and does not fully address serious topics. However, it may become more meaningful when the computerized collection of personal stories goes live next week.

Overall, Dr. Clarke is correct in saying that "objects open windows on the past more vividly than anything else." As for the modern architecture, it works well from the inside and the top, but whether it fits the location is still up for debate.

**The Future of Print Media: A Slow Change**

Peter Preston discusses the idea of "transition," which means moving from one state to another. While change can be scary for some, it usually happens gradually. However, the shift of newspapers to the online world is uncertain and uncomfortable. Many believe this change is inevitable because print newspaper sales are falling while visits to their websites are increasing. For example, major newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen print sales drop by 8% to 10% each year, while their online traffic continues to grow.

Yet, there are some surprising facts. A recent survey by the World Association of Newspapers showed that global newspaper circulation actually increased by 1.1% last year, reaching 512 million copies daily. While sales in Western countries have decreased, Asia has compensated for this decline. Interestingly, news and current affairs magazines, which many think would struggle in the digital age, reported a 5.4% increase in sales.

The same trend is seen in the book industry. E-readers like Kindle are very popular, with sales rising significantly. However, when booksellers looked at the sales of physical books over the past six months, they found only a slight decrease of 0.4%. This suggests that both digital and print formats can coexist.

The idea that young people are completely abandoning newspapers is exaggerated. According to the latest National Readership Survey, nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read major national newspapers. Different countries also show different trends. In Britain, there has been a 10.8% drop in newspaper sales, but in Germany, the decline is only 7%, and in France, it is just 3.1%.

These varying trends indicate that the situation is more complex than many believe. In the past, analysts thought that rising online advertising would support the transition to digital newspapers. However, digital ad revenues are now falling, and many US newspapers have started charging for online access. The most effective way to attract paying readers seems to be offering a package that includes both print and digital access. This means that print newspapers still play an important role in selling online subscriptions, as their advertising rates are much higher than those for online ads.

Maintaining both a print edition and a website is challenging and costly for newspaper companies. However, print media still holds significant visibility, and being noticed online is much harder.

**Photographing People**

People are the most fascinating subjects to photograph. A picture that includes a person is usually more interesting than one without. However, photographing people can be challenging. Besides technical skills, photographers must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. The presence of a camera can sometimes change how people behave.

**A. Grouping People**  
When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Instead, ask people to stand at different angles and distances. If possible, have some people sit or kneel in front so all faces are visible, or raise your camera to get a better view.

**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when it is obvious you are. This can create tension. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, even if they hesitate at first. They may feel self-conscious, so you might need to guide them. A picture can be less interesting if the subject looks away from the camera.

**D. Eye Contact**  
A photo is more powerful if the subject looks at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, but they don’t have to smile. They might not be able to maintain eye contact for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to capture a genuine reaction.

**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking directly at the camera, the subject can focus on something else in the picture. This can make them feel more comfortable, and it gives the viewer a sense of observing a moment. Candid shots are often very engaging, and the subject's expression is crucial.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures reveal a lot about a person. For example, a laughing child can make viewers smile, while a sad face can evoke sympathy. Look for common expressions like shrugs, winks, or smiles; they communicate feelings instantly.

**G. Situation Interest**  
While close-up shots of a person can be striking, the background can add context and interest. When including a background, avoid distracting details and focus on what is relevant. Ensure the subject stands out against the background, perhaps by using a wide-angle lens.

**H. Interaction**  
Capturing moments where people interact—like talking, laughing, or working together—can lead to great photos. Couples, parents with children, and teams are all good subjects. Look for moments of connection, such as eye contact or physical gestures.

**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken during trips. To improve these pictures, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the background, like a building or landscape. Position your subjects close to the camera while ensuring the background is visible. An elevated camera position can help achieve this balance.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If it’s to remember someone you met briefly, a clear posed photo against a nice background is good. However, family pictures can become boring if they are all formal poses. Candid shots of events are often more lively and can capture genuine moments, creating lasting memories.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist, which means she creates paintings that trick the eye into seeing a different reality. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her unique approach to art.

Not many artists choose not to sign their work unless asked, but Sarah Janson is one of them. She believes that the artwork is more important than the artist. "It's not the artist who is important, but the work," she says. Sarah is very modest and almost makes it seem like her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes for an interesting magazine interview. "I just don't like to shout about myself," she admits, and she looks shocked when asked if she minds being photographed.

After a short time, Sarah becomes more comfortable, and the interview turns into a fun and engaging conversation. She has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years, following two years of intense drawing at art school, a degree in graphic illustration, and work at a publishing house. However, she found illustration unfulfilling and began working with a well-known decorator, Jim Smart. He asked her to create one trompe-l'oeil piece, and that sparked her passion. "Suddenly my interest got channelled," she explains. She decided to start her own business, unsure of where it would lead but feeling it was the right choice.

Sarah's keen observation skills and attention to detail, developed through her illustration work, are crucial for her trompe-l'oeil art. She often gets asked where to learn this technique, but she believes it cannot be taught. "Trompe-l'oeil is the school of life. It's all about observation," she insists. She humbly claims she is still learning, stating, "The moment you think you've mastered a field, you might as well give up."

She is also honest about her weaknesses, like her inability to paint bread convincingly. When faced with a large project for a chapel ceiling, she struggled with the measurements and questioned her abilities. "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?" she thought. This self-doubt leads her to speak about her work in a detached way, saying things like, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it; she did.'"

Sarah's trompe-l'oeil art stands out from others, especially since the style has become popular again, but not always successfully. She has completed many significant projects for both businesses and private clients. Much of her work is inspired by architecture. For example, she created a trompe-l'oeil dining room based on a Venetian palace and a painting that makes a hallway look like it leads to two more rooms.

However, trompe-l'oeil art has a challenge: once people understand the trick, they may lose interest. Sarah knows this well. "Trompe-l'oeil has to do two things. First, it must draw you in; it has to trick you. Secondly, it has to hold your attention and engage your imagination. That is the most important part."

Sarah believes that trompe-l'oeil should also be personal to the client. "I love the interaction with clients; that is where the ideas are born," she says. Some clients have clear ideas, while others do not, so she emphasizes the importance of listening and understanding their vision. Many clients become friends, especially since she often works closely with them on-site. 

Sarah appreciates her clients, saying, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They seem happy with her work, which keeps her busy, despite her modesty. "I really don't like to shout about myself," she repeats. "Like my work, I am very restrained. I don't want it to shout. You become bored with things that shout." While this may be true, it is hard to become bored with Sarah or her art. Her work deserves more recognition, and I am willing to promote it, even if she might not like it.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman explores the important 'people skills' needed to succeed in your career.

A. The rules for work are changing. We are now evaluated not only on our intelligence and training but also on how well we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new way of judging is increasingly used to decide who gets hired or promoted. It helps identify who is likely to excel and who may not. These skills are important for our future job prospects, regardless of our current field. The ability to perform well in exams is becoming less relevant. The new focus assumes we all have the necessary knowledge and skills for our jobs. Instead, it emphasizes social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness—collectively known as emotional intelligence.

B. In a time when job security is uncertain, personal qualities are becoming more important in the workplace. For years, these qualities have been referred to by various names, such as 'character' and 'soft skills.' Now, we have a clearer understanding of these abilities, which we call 'emotional intelligence.' This is defined as the ability to understand and manage our own feelings and those of others, using emotions to guide our thoughts and actions. In the workplace, emotional intelligence includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. Some people mistakenly think it just means being nice. However, it can also involve being direct and honest when necessary. Emotional intelligence is about managing feelings so they are expressed appropriately, allowing people to work together effectively towards common goals.

C. More businesses recognize that promoting emotional intelligence is vital for good management. The more complex a job is, the more important emotional intelligence becomes. A lack of these skills can limit a person's ability to use their technical knowledge effectively. While some individuals have succeeded despite lacking emotional intelligence, as work becomes more collaborative, companies that foster teamwork gain a competitive advantage. In today’s workplace, where teamwork and customer focus are essential, emotional intelligence is crucial for success in every job around the world.

D. Unlike IQ, which remains stable, emotional intelligence can grow throughout our lives as we learn from experiences. Studies show that most people become better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and developing empathy and social skills over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is often called maturity. We can learn these skills and add them to our toolkit for success, especially in a time when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence is not a guaranteed solution for struggling organizations, nor does it ensure greater market success. However, if we ignore the human aspect, nothing else will work as effectively.

Text: 'Should the media profit from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture important news events, but social media has truly changed citizen photography. As news often breaks on social networks, some journalists are now using these platforms for images during fast-moving events. Unfortunately, some reporters have shared user-generated content (UGC) without asking for permission. Although there are guidelines stating that images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or when there is strong public interest, there is still debate about whether this is ethical. Research shows that about one in ten people would film or photograph a news event, highlighting the significant role of UGC in the future of media. However, to maintain a good relationship with the public, the media must ensure that individuals are fairly compensated for their work and that permission is always obtained.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

Acupuncture is a practice that is over two thousand years old and comes from traditional Chinese medicine. This system also includes herbal medicine, massage, diet, physical manipulation, and exercise. While acupuncture can treat many health issues, it is most recognized in the West for its ability to relieve pain. Some general practitioners, midwives, and physiotherapists use it regularly for this purpose.

**What is Traditional Chinese Medicine?**

Traditional Chinese medicine views health as a balance of energy in the mind, body, and spirit. This energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along pathways known as meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an internal organ, and many smaller ones that deliver Qi to every cell. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weakened, it can lead to weakness or illness. During a consultation, an acupuncturist will assess where the imbalances in Qi are by checking your pulse, examining your tongue, and looking at your overall health. They will also ask about your medical history, current health, mental state, and your eating and sleeping habits. Acupuncturists use fine needles that are inserted into the skin, and they may also apply heat from burning herbs or pressure on specific points to help Qi flow.

**Acupuncture Points**

The acupuncture points are connected to the meridians and may not be located near the area of pain. Many people report feeling a mild ache or tingling when the needle is gently moved. This can be done by hand or with an electro-acupuncture machine. Acupuncturists believe this sensation indicates that the needle has reached the Qi in a meridian. There are over three hundred acupuncture points on the main meridians, with many more that are used less frequently.

**Scientific Understanding**

While Western doctors do not fully accept the principles of traditional Chinese medicine, they recognize that acupuncture can help relieve pain. Scientific explanations suggest that stimulating certain nerves can block pain signals from reaching the brain. Some researchers believe that acupuncture points can trigger the release of natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body, known as endorphins.

**Types of Pain Treated**

Many people with chronic pain turn to acupuncture as a last option. Commonly treated conditions include back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, migraines, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also claim to treat menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**Modern Use of Acupuncture**

Although acupuncture has been practiced in China for over two thousand years, its use as an alternative to anesthesia during surgery began in the 1950s. This development helped convince some doctors outside China of its effectiveness. Today, acupuncture is used in various surgeries in China, from tonsillectomies to heart surgeries. Needles may be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or alongside medications. While some patients report significant pain relief, experiences can vary. Many people may find the idea of being awake during surgery unappealing, but acupuncturists argue that acupuncture anesthesia has fewer side effects than traditional anesthesia and allows for quicker recovery.

**Effectiveness of Acupuncture**

Like many alternative therapies, it is challenging to conduct clinical trials on acupuncture. However, studies have shown that 50 to 80 percent of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists generally report similar success rates. They acknowledge that acupuncture may not work for everyone and that individual responses can vary. Traditional acupuncturists suggest that for chronic pain, patients usually need six to seven sessions to feel significant relief, although some improvement may be noticed after just two or three visits.

**A Holistic Approach to Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine have different views on pain. Acupuncturists take a holistic approach, meaning they consider the whole person rather than just specific symptoms. They spend time diagnosing the problem and looking for underlying issues with Qi. They also consider external factors that may affect pain, such as weather conditions and the nature of the pain (sharp, dull, throbbing, etc.). These factors are important in determining how acupuncture can help. Most conventional doctors may not consider these aspects.

**Traditional vs. Scientific Approaches**

Some medical professionals have training in traditional acupuncture, while others, including many general practitioners, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that applying traditional Chinese medicine is essential for achieving deep healing and long-lasting results, which can be hard to measure in studies. It is important to choose a qualified acupuncturist, who should refer you to a medical doctor for further investigation if needed.

P.D. James is a well-known crime writer whose gentle appearance hides a deep and creative mind. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, and she carries herself with quiet confidence. One can easily imagine her as a headmistress of a girls' school if she had not chosen to write detective stories filled with unexpected twists. However, it quickly becomes clear that her confident demeanor is a cover for her shyness. She admits that her main character, Adam Dalgliesh, the detective in her books, is based on herself, or how she might have been if she were a man. Dalgliesh prefers to solve crimes alone, just like James does. She needs time alone to write and can do so anywhere as long as she has complete privacy.

Despite her success, she is too humble to agree that she is the most famous crime writer in Britain, even though millions read her twelve major detective novels worldwide. She admires the work of her close friend Ruth Rendell, especially her psychological novels written under the name Barbara Vine. The books she enjoys most are often by female authors like Iris Murdoch, Anita Brookner, and Penelope Lively, but she also appreciates male writers like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh, whom she considers some of the greatest novelists of their time.

P.D. James found success later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, Cover Her Face, was published. Born in Oxford, she grew up mainly in Cambridge after her family moved there when she was 11. She met her husband, a university student, in Cambridge, which is why she chose it as the setting for her book An Unsuitable Job For A Woman. She shares that her life has had its challenges, including the struggles she faced when her husband, Connor Bantry White, returned from World War II very ill. To support him and their two young daughters, Clare and Jane, she worked long hours. Although she had many ideas for stories, she had little time to write. Thankfully, her husband’s parents helped care for her daughters during those tough years.

While working full-time in administration for the National Health Service, she used her excellent organizational skills. At one point, she managed five psychiatric outpatient clinics. She then spent 11 years at the Home Office, first in the Police Department and later in the Criminal Law section, focusing on juvenile crime. While working in forensic science, she became used to seeing dead bodies, but it was not death itself that inspired her writing. Instead, she was drawn to the structure and creativity involved in writing crime novels. She has always loved reading detective stories and knew she wanted to be a writer.

James did not want to write about her own traumatic experiences. She saw writing detective stories as a great way to learn the craft of serious novel writing while keeping a distance from her own life. Over time, she realized that it was possible to follow the traditional format of a detective story and still create a meaningful novel about human nature. She believes that writing detective stories helps bring order to chaos and that solving a crime affirms the value of life, even if that life is difficult to love. She acknowledges that no one truly enjoys violence.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**

The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you will likely be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting sample can significantly influence whether you are considered suitable for the position. Handwriting analysis, known as graphology, is recognized as a legitimate science in many places. Researchers suggest it can help identify certain health issues, like heart disease and cancer, and can also reveal emotional and psychological states. 

Graphology is increasingly used for career guidance and as a supplement to job interviews. Many large companies now hire graphologists to analyze the handwriting of job candidates. However, many doctors and psychiatrists are skeptical about the effectiveness of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist with over 20 years of experience, believes it deserves more attention. She argues that handwriting can reflect psychological traits and some medical conditions. 

Marne states, "Handwriting is a strong indicator of social class and intelligence. It can also help assess a person's mental abilities, whether they should focus on arts or sciences, and whether they have a manipulative or open personality." She claims that graphology can be particularly useful in identifying potential criminal behavior. According to her, "Criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which is usually poorly shaped and sometimes illiterate. Many come from difficult backgrounds and show signs of emotional development issues, which can appear as childish handwriting or repeated letters."

Marne explains that handwriting can reveal a lot about a person. For example, she can determine if someone is honest or manipulative. She notes that young male offenders often have tall letters, suggesting they live in a fantasy world and dream of success. Graphologists can also predict if someone is under extreme stress or has violent tendencies. Handwriting can even indicate potential suicidal thoughts. 

She adds that heart and lung issues can sometimes be detected through handwriting. "You cannot diagnose a condition from just one sample unless the writing is clearly shaky or disturbed. However, if the handwriting changes over time or becomes disjointed, it may indicate a serious issue," she explains. A significant emotional upset can also temporarily alter a person's signature.

Marne describes how different handwriting styles can reveal psychological traits. For instance, people whose letters connect in a thread-like manner may be clever but deceptive. Those who write mostly in capital letters might be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing suggests sensitivity and low energy. Originality in handwriting shows confidence and creativity, while disconnected writing often indicates loneliness. Small signatures can reflect feelings of inferiority, and circles over the letter "i" may indicate a desire for attention.

Marne believes that it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting accurately, along with empathy and intuition. She thinks more research is needed to establish graphology as a scientific discipline, and she is optimistic that this will happen soon. "It is actually more accurate than psychoanalysis because it can reveal a person's entire history, including emotional crises, without asking them questions that they might answer incorrectly."

Despite these interesting claims, there is little solid evidence to support them. Some psychiatrists criticize graphology, arguing that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic skills, and the writing style taught, and that it does not have any deeper significance.

**Is Your Office Working Well?**

Fresh air and comfortable chairs are essential for a happy and healthy workplace, according to a recent survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they were as work environments. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist who studies working conditions, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.

**Office A: Advertising Agency**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very basic; it has no central heating or mechanical ventilation, and the windows open directly onto the street. It’s surprising that this space works, but the small, energetic team seems to be happy. They adapt to the seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, similar to how they would at home. This might be the key: the seven-person team has created a comfortable, home-like environment without unnecessary rules.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is mismatched and creates poor working postures. Many chairs are old, not adjustable, and some are broken. However, the staff have a varied work schedule that they control, which includes office work, client meetings, and presentations. This variety helps reduce fatigue, boredom, and muscle problems.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** Employees enjoy the variety of work and the flexible office space. They feel the office is "just the right size"—small enough to know what colleagues are doing, yet large enough to focus on individual tasks. I found the office attractive and fun, showing both efficiency and creativity.

**Office B: News Service**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office may not be very exciting, but it is comfortable and staff do not dislike it. The air quality and maintenance are good, partly due to a No Smoking policy.

- **Ergonomist:** The company has already hired an ergonomist, which is not surprising. The chairs are excellent, and the lighting and computer equipment are good. The space is adequate, but the layout could be better. However, the environment feels impersonal and dull, with plain grey walls.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls are mostly bare, except for year planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have been there for over five years, and relationships are satisfactory. The office could improve by arranging desks to make sharing information easier and displaying success stories or project updates on the walls.

**Office C: Bank**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office receives mixed reviews from employees. It feels like being in a glass case, surrounded by many similar spaces. Despite having both smokers and non-smokers in a small area, the air quality is surprisingly good.

- **Ergonomist:** The office is very standard and uninspiring. The desks are just adequate, and not all chairs meet ergonomic standards, but this is a choice made by users. Computer screens are often placed on low desks, which is not suitable for modern equipment.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** Staff support each other well and have good technology. There are many awards displayed, but the wood paneling and brown carpet create a somewhat gloomy atmosphere. The office is busy and active.

**Office D: Newspaper**

- **Building Health Consultant:** There is not much positive to say about this office. The air conditioning is poorly controlled, leading to uncomfortable temperature changes. The space is cluttered, and most people have too little desk space. It is very dusty, with many places for dust to collect, and the roof collects dust that falls on those below.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture looks more suitable for a workshop than a modern office. Many chairs are not helpful for people using computers, especially those shorter than 1.75 meters. Most chairs are old, lack proper adjustments, and have armrests that make it hard to get close to the desk.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office has old brown chairs, dirty carpets, and dust everywhere. There is a lot of room for improvement—cleaning is needed, individual achievements should be recognized more, and the air conditioning must be fixed, especially with so many smokers. When we visited, there were few conversations; everyone seemed stressed and focused on deadlines. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular, accessible to everyone, and Americans chew about 12 million sticks of it every day. This ancient practice has turned into a big business. Each stick of chewing gum has fewer than ten calories, but it is considered a food and must meet the standards set by the American Food and Drug Administration.

Today, most chewing gum is made from synthetic materials, including pine resins and softeners that help maintain flavor and improve texture. However, this was not always the case. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, which grows mainly in Greece and Turkey. Women in Greece especially liked mastic gum for cleaning their teeth and freshening their breath. American colonists learned from the Native Americans in New England and chewed resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, lumps of spruce for chewing were sold in the eastern United States, marking the beginning of commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree found in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother, more enjoyable, and more elastic, leading to the growth of a new industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla trees commercially have not been successful. As the demand for chewing gum increased, synthetic alternatives were developed.

Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, known as chicleros, live a difficult and dangerous life. They trek for miles to collect sap from scattered sapodilla trees in very humid conditions. The environment is harsh, with poisonous snakes and many insects. One particularly troublesome insect, the chicle fly, lays its eggs in the ears and noses of the gatherers. Despite these dangers, experienced chicleros can climb a mature tree quickly to cut the bark and collect the sap in a bag below. They then carry the liquid back to a camp, where it is boiled until it becomes sticky and is formed into bricks.

Life at the camp is also tough, with a boring and often inadequate diet based mainly on maize, accompanied by a local alcohol made from sugar cane. Despite these challenges, chicleros worry about their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula.

As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetic materials to lower costs and meet demand. Meanwhile, gum producers are finding creative ways to market their products. They claim that chewing gum helps you relax, boosts your energy, and reduces stress. During both world wars, soldiers were regularly given gum. One of the main benefits of gum is that it can help reduce tooth decay. Plaque acid forms when we eat, but our saliva helps neutralize this acid and provides important minerals like calcium, phosphate, and fluoride. Gum manufacturers say that chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva production.

Research continues on new textures and flavors for gum. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are now used to create the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still require natural ingredients. Additionally, 137 square kilometers of land in America is dedicated to growing mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the peacefulness of an English country house with Indian culture. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests into their home. The hotel has basic facilities, with hot water provided in buckets, but this simplicity adds to its charm.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
One of my favorite hotels is the Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island. I discovered it by chance while climbing. After being flown close to the top of a glacier and climbing to the peak, we had to walk down. When we reached the bottom, I was amazed to find this hotel in a stunningly beautiful and remote area. After a tiring climb, it was incredible to relax in luxury, with a pianist playing Cole Porter music.

**C. MAURITIUS - PARADIS HOTEL**  
On the southwest coast of Mauritius, the Paradis Hotel is located on a quiet peninsula. The road to the hotel winds along the coast, passing empty beaches where only fishermen are present. Although the hotel is large and offers many free water sports, you can easily find solitude on its nine kilometers of private beach. Just swim a little way out into the Indian Ocean, and you will hardly see the hotel among the palm trees. In the evening, when everyone has left, you can enjoy the peacefulness as the sun sets.

**D. ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has one of the most stunning views in the Caribbean. It is quiet and located at an altitude of 1,000 feet, with open rooms that look out between the twin peaks of the Pitons to the Caribbean Sea. The hotel features colonial-style furniture made of mahogany and greenheart wood, and has four-poster beds with muslin netting.

**E. TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
The Splendid Hotel, located on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, is a perfect escape from the noise of Istanbul. The islands are just an hour away by boat and are very picturesque. There are no cars, only horse-drawn carriages, and beautiful wooden buildings from the 1920s. The Splendid Hotel, made of wood and painted white with red domes, is inspired by a historic hotel on the French Riviera. Although it is a bit worn down now, it still retains its charm.

**F. FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the Champagne region, there is a lovely seventeenth-century chateau surrounded by a moat with two swans. This chateau, which was a family home until recently, has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds, and one even has a billiard table. They offer special weekend rates for two nights, including breakfast and dinner, along with complimentary champagne from their own brand.

**G. KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel is a rare find in Africa—a comfortable hotel that is not overly luxurious. It is a popular stop for travelers recovering from safaris and planning their next adventures. Guests often arrive, see the beautiful gardens and inviting rooms, and decide to stay longer. There are even apartments for those who want to settle in for a few months. The hotel is set on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city center, making it a great place to enjoy the stunning African sunset while sipping beer and looking forward to a hearty dinner.

**H. ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Hotel Splendido was first signed into by the Duke of Windsor, and since then, many famous people have visited, including Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet wealthy guests, but this former monastery turned villa still offers a splendid experience. The restaurant serves delicious, simple food, and the hotel features beautiful Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

The Hotel Inspector, Sue Brown, evaluates hotels as her job. Christopher Middleton observed her during an inspection. Just one minute into the annual check, problems are already appearing at the Globe Hotel, although the staff are unaware of it. The receptionist is busy giving room rates over the phone to a potential guest and does not notice Sue and Christopher. "She hasn't even acknowledged us," Sue whispers. "Very poor." This is a common mistake during the arrival phase, which Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. "But this isn't just any three-star hotel," she argues. "It has three red stars, and I expect better." Having red stars means the Globe is among the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 listed in the guide from her organization.

Before they even receive a cold welcome, the atmosphere feels off. Access from the car park is through an unmanned door with a buzzer, leading to a long, empty corridor to the hotel entrance. "Again, not what I expected," Sue comments. Could it get worse? Yes, it can. The receptionist cheerfully informs them, "We seem to have no record of your booking." It turns out that out of the hotel's 15 rooms, 12 are empty that night. One room is on the top floor, but it does not meet Sue's standards: it feels stuffy, and there is a large hole in the wall behind the wardrobe.

When Sue started her career, she earned a reputation for being tough. "I was known as 'The Woman in Black,'" she remembers, "which is funny because I never wore black. And I’ve never been too tough." However, the next morning, after paying her bill, she reveals her identity to the hotel’s general manager, Robin Greaves. His face shows fear. Before she says anything, he apologizes for a bad smell in the main lounge. "We think there’s a blocked drain," he sighs. "The whole floor might need to be replaced."

Sue kindly suggests that, in addition to fixing the plumbing, he should instruct his staff to be more careful about showing guests to the lounge. "It might be better to guide them to the other lounge," she advises. Greaves nods sadly and takes notes. He has only been at the Globe for five months and struggles to believe Sue when she says her feedback is meant to help the hotel in the long run.

Not everything is negative. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the young waitress, who provided information about the hotel’s 400-year history. The dinner also meets the standards to keep the hotel’s two-rosette food rating, encouraging Greaves to ask, "What do we need to do to get three rosettes?" Sue’s response is, "Don’t serve a dessert that collapses." Greaves’ brief excitement fades.

Sue’s job is to express the complaints that many customers are too afraid to voice. "Sometimes, it can be very sensitive. I remember a woman called to complain that I got her son fired. All I could say was the truth: he served me apple pie with his fingers." She often receives letters with false accusations, from being arrogant to demanding bribes. "You get used to it, but it still hurts," she says.

Sue must not only share her findings verbally with the hotel manager but also send a detailed written report. After all, the hotels pay for her advice (there is an annual fee to be included in the guide). However, being recognized with red stars makes it worthwhile. It is good news for Greaves to hear that Sue will not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars. The bad news is that another inspector will return in the next two months to ensure that everything has been fixed. "Good," Greaves smiles, though it seems unconvincing. "We’ll look forward to that."

**Seven Summits: A Mountaineer's Journey**

Doug Scott, an experienced mountaineer, shares his incredible experiences of climbing the highest peaks on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. He began this journey later in life and will describe each mountain in the order he climbed them.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
While climbing Mt. Everest, Doug and his partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave 91 meters below the summit. Dougal started discussing sleeping bags with their Equipment Officer, Dave Clark, even though only they were there. Doug thought this was odd, possibly due to low oxygen levels. He even found himself talking to his own feet, which were getting cold. They were not just worried about survival but also about how well they could survive. Over the next two days, Doug reflected on their time on the summit ridge and felt grateful to have Dougal with him, as he inspired confidence. Doug focused on finding a better rhythm to reach the summit.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
Mt. McKinley is known as one of the most dangerous mountains. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days carrying equipment and food to the base. After the first day, they realized how challenging their climb would be. They followed a route established in 1967 but decided to take a new path to the summit. They climbed with all their gear on their backs, which was a first for this area. After facing tough conditions, including a wet sleeping bag and strong winds, they finally reached the summit and celebrated their success.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul Braithwaite flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up climbing Kilimanjaro instead. They got lost in the dense jungle on the lower slopes, which was concerning because water was hard to find. On the second day, they found a trail marked by arrows and some litter, leading them to a rock pool. They attempted a challenging climb but decided to take a safer route to reach the summit.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Aconcagua. They met a fellow climber, Phil Erscheler, who invited them to join his group on a less crowded route. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they set off. The Polish Glacier was icy and dangerous, so they chose to take the standard route instead. They faced strong winds but successfully reached the summit and camped nearby. At base camp, they met climbers from the Jakarta Mountaineering Club, who encouraged Doug to pursue the Seven Summits goal.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug realized that climbing Vinson Massif could be possible if he guided enough people to cover the costs. In November 1992, his team traveled to the South Pole. During this time, the sun never set, creating a unique atmosphere. On December 7, they set out for the summit. Despite strong winds and freezing temperatures, they all reached the top within eight hours, although visibility was poor due to a storm.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team gathered in St. Petersburg and traveled to Elbrus. They faced some challenges with local regulations but eventually began their ascent. After acclimatizing, they took a cable car to a high point and then walked to a refuge. On their climb, they encountered strong winds and icy slopes. They thought they had reached the summit but discovered there was still more to climb. They returned to the refuge and descended the volcano the next day.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On their expedition to Carstensz Pyramid, Doug and his team aimed to create a new route and connect with the local Dani people. They were warned about potential dangers but decided to proceed. On May 12, they began climbing, and the weather improved. Doug and his team reached the summit by 11 am, and he received a warm welcome for completing his seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**

Style influences many aspects of our lives today, from clothing to home decor and accessories. Jo Foley shares the latest trends for fashion enthusiasts this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham creates beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He advises people to avoid traditional, stiff dresses and the overly frilly style, suggesting simpler designs instead. Ingham has been sketching and designing wedding dresses since he was a child. At 16, he attended fashion school, where he learned how to cut and make clothes. However, you don’t need to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress; he also designs elegant evening dresses with modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, Ingham offers a timeless navy-blue summer suit, a staple in women's wardrobes throughout the 20th century, but he gives it a fresh look.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail previously worked for an art dealer but has no formal training in jewellery design. She started designing her own engagement ring when she couldn’t find one she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990, and now her pieces are popular among many celebrities. Her unique style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, creating stunning necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by 18th-century designs. Recently, she has begun using diamonds, saying, "I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond."

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Just four years after starting her career in the competitive fashion industry, Lily Grimson has had two of her designs chosen for a major exhibition, despite only taking an introductory art and design course. Her handbags are always noticed, as they are handmade in the UK and exude glamour, whether made from luxurious calfskin or rich silk. A Grimson bag is not just a bag; it combines style and quality, making it truly special.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. He understands that most women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage at home. His unique approach ensures that clients don’t look like they just left a salon. However, this casual style comes at a price—£250 for the first appointment, with a three-month waiting list. Leveraging his fame, Peter has created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, allowing those who can’t visit his salon to achieve their desired looks at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and works as a consultant for a large supermarket chain, providing floral ideas for top restaurants. Remarkably, she has no formal qualifications in floristry and left her teaching job ten years ago to pursue a new path. Her modern and simple floral arrangements have won numerous design awards, helping her establish her own London Flower School. She has also enjoyed successful lecture tours in Japan and the USA. Penny believes that flower arrangements today should be simple yet striking, with fewer large leaves. For wedding bouquets, she emphasizes that all flowers should be of the same type.

**Five-Star Luxury with Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin combines luxury with the latest technology. It was created by transforming four large 18th-century houses and took nearly two years of work. This approach allowed the hotel to install advanced technology that benefits both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses a computer system to keep track of their preferences. This system helps the hotel provide special treatment for returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to set up, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time because of its efficiency. For instance, if a guest requests specific music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Room temperature is another common concern for hotel guests. The Merrion has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers are a significant part of the hotel's clientele, making up about 65% of its business. To cater to their needs, the hotel has equipped each room with a business center that includes three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing capabilities. The hotel has also prepared for future technological advancements by installing extra cables and renting televisions and DVD recorders, allowing for easy upgrades.

Despite all this technology, MacCann emphasizes that they want guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 spacious and well-furnished rooms that are inviting and cozy. Guests can also enjoy a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.

The food at the Merrion is exceptional, thanks to Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who moved his two-Michelin-star restaurant to the hotel. This move has allowed him to create a modern kitchen and improve parking facilities. For the hotel, having a renowned restaurant adds value without financial risk. With its combination of technology and skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is poised for success.

**An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings, which are inspired by the large garden around her house. This garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west are beautifully arranged in terms of color, shape, and structure. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to create detailed studies of individual plants instead of painting the entire garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants in their natural setting, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which can take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build the painting gradually. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all bloom together, and you're so busy," she says. However, she also finds beauty in the gradual decay of flowers. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, you might think they are dull, but they keep changing with twists and turns."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she recalls. "I wasn't really interested in gardening back then; in fact, I didn't like garden flowers because they reminded me of fake ones sold in some flower shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden includes many plants from distant lands, but they thrive just as well as they do in their native places like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, similar to a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of inspiration right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging lately. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**No Title**

Many trees in the Brackham area were destroyed during the terrible storms in March. The town lost two large lime trees from the old market square. The loss of these important trees completely changed the look of the town center, which upset many of the more traditional residents. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have been among those upset. However, during the worst of the storm, when the strong winds knocked down the walnut tree in his garden, Pelham was too ill to notice. He was a large and healthy man, but for the first time, he was seriously sick with bronchitis. When he first felt pain in his head and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, urged him to see a doctor. Believing the police needed him, he ignored her advice and tried to keep working. This only made him forgetful and irritable. Eventually, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor, and by then, he was too weak to argue. Soon after, she took him to the pharmacy for his antibiotics and then home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed.

On Thursday morning, when Molly told him that the walnut tree had fallen during the night, Pelham could hardly believe it. That evening, he weakly asked if the house was damaged and felt relieved to hear it was not. He then pulled the sheets over his head. It was not until Saturday, when the antibiotics started to work, that he got up and realized the loss of the walnut tree had changed the living room forever. The Pelhams' large house was in a big garden. It had been expensive, but Pelham had no regrets about buying it. The green garden had given them a sense of privacy. Now, however, the storm had changed everything. Before, the view from the living room included the beautiful walnut tree, which had not made the room dark because there was also a window on the opposite wall. The tree had created interesting patterns of light and shadow that hid the worn furniture they had brought from their old house. With the tree gone, the room felt harshly bright, revealing the shabby furniture. The view from the window was not pleasant either. The tall house next door, which had been hidden by the tree, now loomed over them with its unattractive purple bricks and pipes. It had many upstairs windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams' every move.

"Doesn't it look terrible?" Pelham said weakly to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded more happy than upset. "That's what I've been telling you since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

**Living in the Valley**

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first noticed the dangers that could come from the surrounding hills and threaten our survival. That year, the storms arrived early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe and protected in our valley below the hills. Soon, snow began to fall, and within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. The snow almost completely blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. However, in the hills, the snow was much deeper and lasted longer. The wind blew fiercely up there, but in our valley, we only felt sudden gusts; the trees swayed, but their branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had reasons to worry. The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not truly trouble us. The real threat was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently but now posed a danger. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by the dams built many years ago.

Soon, the snow began to melt. Day after day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These ominous grey clouds spread over the valleys, twisting and rising, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we focused on the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder each day. The melting snow was washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and nearing a dangerous level. Then, it happened – for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a mini Niagara Falls as the water surged over the dam and rushed into the stream below. The river seemed furious as the water poured down towards its lower stretches. Just a few meters from our cottage, the stream looked wild beneath the bridge. It was deeper than we had ever seen it so close to our home, angrily pushing against its banks. For three days, we prayed that it would stay below its limits. Luckily, our prayers were answered as the dam held strong and the waters began to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages in such a rage. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine. The large amount of water from the hills, caused by snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam, with only occasional overflow. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the huge clouds above the valley and appreciate the great power of the river without fear. Thanks to the dam, we feel that our home in the valley is still safe and secure.

Film critic Mark Adams reflects on his ten years of work for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing film articles for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I had done some reviews of novels for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and various tasks for the radio. This is how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also worked in radio and television. He hired me, but since Tom was not mainly a journalist, he was not very careful in choosing his team. 

Initially, Tom wanted a group of critics to cover art forms that didn’t need special knowledge, like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to discuss which topics to cover, and there would be guests to make it more enjoyable. At that time, it felt like a dream: a new newspaper, and I was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market. I even thought a millionaire was helping me personally and pretending to hire me because I lacked confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to a page with my review, I felt embarrassed.

Tom's idea of a team of critics for the arts did not work out as planned. Although it was a good idea, we didn’t meet as expected, and everything was done over the phone. It also turned out that the public preferred to have a reviewer focus on one subject area, so I chose to write about films. Without Tom's initial support, we might not have developed the current system, where I write a detailed weekly piece about one film. This way of working suits me well. I wouldn’t have enjoyed the typical film critic role, which requires reviewing every new film. That routine would quickly make me feel bored. I would find myself sitting in a screening room on a Monday morning, sighing, "What terrible film do I have to watch now?"—a sigh often heard in screening rooms worldwide.

The freedom I have allows me to expand my arguments or, during a dull week, to create something interesting from little material. But what is my role in the public eye? I believe people choose films based on stars, marketing, or the director. There is also loyalty to certain types of films. It is rare for someone who dislikes westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romantic film lover to skip a love story because of a critic's opinion. So, if a film review isn’t really a guide for consumers, what is it? I don’t feel I need to be "right" about a movie. I also don’t think there should be a specific number of "great" or "bad" films each year. My job is to present an argument. I’m not a judge, and I wouldn’t want to be one.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because "it's fun." 

A teenager who loves sports is looking for a training partner for triathlons, preferably a female. This is a chance to work with someone who could be an Olympic champion. The partner should be very interested in long-distance running (regular 15 km sessions), swimming (enjoying winter training in cold rivers is a plus), and cycling (a love for 100 km rides is helpful). It is essential to be able to do all three activities without taking a break.

Triathlons are becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. They attract large crowds who are both fascinated and shocked by athletes who swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers without stopping. While it may be exciting for spectators, what drives triathletes to push their bodies so hard? What makes a talented 17-year-old, who does well in school, give up so much for this challenging sport?

Melanie Sears, a young triathlete, has not yet learned the common phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that many athletes use when asked about their motivations. She explains, "You swim 1500 meters, then run out of the water and jump on your bike while still wet. Of course, you get cold. After the 40 km bike ride, you have to run 10 km, which feels long when you’re tired. But it’s really fun, and it’s all worth it in the end."

Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14 and won the junior section, but that was because she was the only junior participant. Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not place well. "I was following a man, and suddenly we found ourselves at the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried the whole time I was running." However, she did not give up and is determined to keep going. "Sometimes I wish I could stop because then the pain would end, but I’m afraid that if I stop once, I might want to stop again."

Her determination impresses Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director. "I tested her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off into a wall. She gave it her all, while most people would step off when they realize they can’t go any further. She just kept going."

Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower in cycling. That’s why I’m working hard on it." She is trying to convince her parents, who will pay the £1,300 cost of her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships, to buy a £2,000 bike (it’s a special deal with £1,000 off) so she can compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year.

However, there is a cost to her dedication. Her intense training has made her somewhat of a recluse. "I don’t have a social life," she says. "I’m not really into parties. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I do keep in touch with the other girls on the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about our times and achievements."

Where will this strong focus lead Melanie? She has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," which involves swimming 750 meters, cycling 20 kilometers, and running 5 kilometers. She wants to enter even tougher competitions than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I don’t have anyone my age to train with," she says. It’s interesting, isn’t it?

**The Collectors**

Amanda Roy discusses her passion for collecting and why many people share this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults participating. It is a world filled with passion, envy, enthusiasm, and joy. However, if you decide to collect, remember this: only collect items you truly love. 

Since ancient times, people have felt the need to collect. Early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They were drawn to the shapes and colors of these stones, which represented their first efforts to gather objects for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Over the years, not much has changed. Children still collect stones and seashells simply for their beauty.

I have been collecting for my entire life, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones I found in my parents' garden. When I was six, I was sent to a school in a remote, cold part of England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum filled with objects collected by people from the past. I was fascinated by these items. 

Interestingly, I am not alone in my interest in collecting. One in three adults shares this passion. Researchers believe that for some people, collecting is the only part of their lives where they feel they have complete control. For me, it is simply something I enjoy.

One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France, who had a "room of wonders" filled with natural and artificial curiosities, like coconut shell cups and carved ivory beads. Another notable collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, owned over 4,000 paintings. However, you don’t need to be wealthy to start a collection. I have collected various items, from tulip bulbs to china cups, with great determination. 

I remember convincing another tulip collector to sell me a special bulb. I planted it and cared for it, but one year it disappeared—stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching all over the USA for different designs. Unfortunately, this collection was lost in a fire that destroyed my house. The next morning, I stood in my front hall, looking at the remains of my furniture and my collection, unsure which loss saddened me more.

I have always been intrigued by how collections change hands. A silver spoon that once belonged to a king or a poet adds value to the items traded in markets. As certain small objects become popular among collectors, their prices rise. For example, toys from the 1950s are now considered valuable, especially if you kept the original boxes. (I, unfortunately, threw away both the boxes and the toys.)

**My Line of Work**

Four people talk about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I need to learn about the exhibition topic in advance and talk to key people to understand the main themes and goals. I decide what objects and images to display. It’s important that the public understands the exhibition, so I plan interactive displays, workshops, and performances. I also work with engineers and electricians to ensure the display is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
When I arrive at 7:30 a.m., I first check the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents are needed for the taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in class, figuring out the best routes. They learn how to navigate one-way streets and make turns. I step in when there are disagreements, like whether a right turn is allowed at a certain junction. As they prepare for the test, I give them a simple route but tell them they must take a different one because the road is closed. This forces them to think creatively about alternative routes.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and usually work from home. My job involves answering phone inquiries, creating educational materials, and organizing training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I mostly work along the coast. I collaborate with schools and study centers, running courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about marine life. I take them out to sea to help them understand the underwater environment better, which often changes their perspectives. I feel fortunate because conservation is my passion, but since I work for a charity, I constantly seek funding, which limits what I can achieve.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is quite diverse. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and that we keep around 300 copies of our books in stock. We maintain high standards for information and content. We receive many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which require careful responses. I discuss future projects and current sales with my co-publishers. I enjoy working with a passionate team, but like many jobs, there is too much administration, which takes time away from more interesting tasks like product development and design.

**No Title**

Every June, we traveled to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a large house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have made some additions to it, but they did so very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds were still advertising. "How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it was not a good experience because the food was terrible.

The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school; Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe were schoolmates, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. We always think it’s a funny coincidence.

"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she is usually waiting in the large hall that always smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium," she said, naming the rooms we would stay in. Instead of numbers, Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors. In winter, when few people visit Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of small details like that, while her husband handles repairs and redecorating.

"Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he entered the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way.
