He was smiling widely, and his dark brown eyes sparkled, making us feel like we were more than just another group of hotel guests. Everyone smiled, and I could sense that the others felt our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was perfect.

Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone in the hall laugh again. Arthur led the way to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we didn’t play for too long because we were still tired from the journey.

In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other guests at dinner, of course, because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others taking the path down to the beach. In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the beach to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this would happen because over the years, we had developed this routine. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape in every season.

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

A chalet girl's work is never finished, as Sarah Sutherland-Pilch explains to Veronica Lee. This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex. Known as Pilch, she works for a company in Val d'Isere, France, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University, where she studied French and History of Art. She sees being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can accommodate up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she considers the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can be on the slopes until 4:30 p.m.," she says.

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower first, but she avoids sleeping. "It's not good if you do," she warns. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning," she says. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week wonderful. Breakfast this morning was great fun, but some weeks don’t go as well for various reasons."

Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they usually go out around 11 p.m. "We often start at Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar," she explains. However, she doesn’t stay out too late on Saturday nights because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day," she says, "when you definitely don’t want to cook breakfast with a bad headache."

On Sundays, work starts earlier than usual because breakfast for guests leaving has to be ready by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We just blitz the place—clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get everything ready." If she hasn’t done the shopping for the week on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests seem confused and have many questions. "I think the mountain air affects them," she jokes.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests who need boots or skis to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and sometimes she enjoys a drink afterward, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early," she admits.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small, pale girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she visited his factory wearing overalls and large shoes, with messy hair framing her pretty face. Seymour found it hard to believe that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. 

Several times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions over the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how gloves were made. Seymour remembered how Marie had been fascinated by the steam-heated brass hands used to shape the gloves, which she called "pancake hands."

Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He explained, "They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather, father, and I all worked in the tannery here in town. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" 

"Not yet," she said. 

"You should visit one if you want to write about leather. I can arrange that for you. They are basic places. The technology has improved, but it’s not very different from what it was hundreds of years ago. It’s tough work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries; they’ve found 6,000-year-old tanning artifacts in Turkey. The first clothing was just animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s a fascinating subject. My father is a leather expert; you should talk to him. If you start a conversation about gloves, he could talk for two days. Glovemakers are passionate about their work. 

"Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" he asked. 

"I can't say I have," she replied. 

"Never seen anything manufactured?" 

"I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child." 

He laughed at her answer. She was innocent and eager to learn, reminding him of Marie, who was much taller than Rita but shared her good-natured intelligence. 

"I have an idea," he said. "We will take you through the entire glove-making process. Come on! We’re going to make you a pair of gloves, and you’ll watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Is It a Tough Job?** Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she often travels around the world at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and has a good relationship with her boss. However, she has one small issue—she dislikes flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she admits. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so cramped with those tiny windows." When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London, handling routine tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning itineraries, and making more travel arrangements. She did not apply for this job; a chance meeting with a pop group manager led to her working behind the scenes, and she took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place at the right time when her boss needed a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he prefers caddying, especially since golf is his passion. However, there are some downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings, with average earnings between £25,000 and £35,000, much of which goes to travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman when he was 31. "You're not just carrying bags; you're giving advice, using your knowledge, and trying to understand the course," he explains. Recently, his accounting skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, which made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies' scorecards, which are valuable to TV commentators, golf magazines, and the players themselves.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to taste food at the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants with high prices? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend, who was an editor of a Saturday Review, offering him a food column. At that time, Martin was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it provided him with extra income. When he was 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income," he says, "but it was a chance to turn my passion into a career." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's authors. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed writing, but I mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. Having been a farmer, I knew about the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called *The Fox Busters*, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy; I have to work hard at them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I'm not an early riser, though. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning—all with one finger on an old typewriter instead of a laptop, which I dislike. I receive between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that is the part of being a writer I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but I now have some secretarial help."

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Surrounding it were large piles of soft sawdust, creating golden mounds that reached down to the blue lake. That afternoon, feeling bored, a group of boys followed Michael up the ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking out at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, trying to get them to jump too.

Still laughing, he watched as they hesitated on the roof, looking scared. One by one, they jumped down, relieved to land safely. In the warm afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes until one of them suggested going back up to the roof to jump again. Although they were not very excited, they climbed back up and began jumping off in a determined way until only Michael was left. The others were down below, grinning and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong with you?"

Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed on the edge of the roof, nervously licking his lips and grinning foolishly, wondering why the jump had seemed easier the first time. For a while, they thought he was just joking, but then they noticed him clenching his fists. He tried to count to ten and jump, but when that didn’t work, he took a deep breath and closed his eyes. Eventually, the boys started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward! Do you think we're going to sit here all night?" they shouted. When he still didn’t move, they began to get up and walk away, still teasing him.

"Who started this?" he called after them. But he remained on the edge of the roof, staring unhappily at the ground. He stayed there alone for nearly an hour while the sun slowly set over the lake. His clothes were damp from nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, jumped off the roof, and landed heavily in the sawdust, lying there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he had been unable to jump earlier. Eventually, he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone.

He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You should be able to get home in time for dinner by now. If you won't come home, you might as well stay out tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a hint of grey in her hair, and a patient smile. Although she spoke firmly, Michael, with his dark, gloomy face, hardly heard her; he was still thinking about the grinning faces below and their laughter.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job but unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change their careers turn to a careers adviser. You will need to write a brief history of yourself and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. After this, you will receive a summary of the results, along with suggested careers and any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, one of the largest career advice organizations. Taking the careers test felt like being back in a science exam. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions under time pressure. I had to remind myself that it wasn't about passing or failing. It was hard to see how the psychometric tests would accurately reflect who I am. The tests included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes.

After the tests, I had a long conversation with an adviser. Based on our discussion and the test results, he created a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, although I was a bit disappointed to learn that I had performed poorly in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. I’m sure many sick people are relieved I didn’t become a nurse! However, it was comforting to hear that I had made the right choices regarding journalism.

Changing your career doesn’t always mean a complete shift. Last March, after losing her job as a marketing manager at a large insurance company, 25-year-old Donna Laney sought help from Career Analysts. She said, "Losing my job was a great chance for me to reflect on my career. I wanted to reassess my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn’t realize I had a talent for design. But in the end, I had to weigh the cost of retraining in design against my financial responsibilities," she explained. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. Ultimately, she decided to use her existing skills and move into a field that suited her better than insurance. Now, she works as a Public Relations officer. She believes she could have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped her understand what she truly wanted to do. She has recommended the service to several friends, all of whom are satisfied.

Some people feel they would not have made significant changes without help. For example, 26-year-old Juliet Greene visited Career Counselling Services and made important life decisions. "After working at a major bank for six years, I found my job boring and wanted a new challenge. I had no idea what I wanted to do, so I approached Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed I was interested in sciences," she said. "I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which I found helpful because you forget much of what you say. After the fourth meeting, I carefully considered the test results and decided to study geology. I plan to start a degree in it later this year. I believe the advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the cost. I feel much happier and more positive now."

However, career advice does not work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, said, "I reached a point in my career where I felt lost. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they either required a significant pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself. You have to share a lot of personal information with the adviser, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice."

**Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you will notice bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he examines their teeth. Jerome explains, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain instead of for regular check-ups. This is often because they are scared." To change this, he has worked to create a space where people feel comfortable. For example, he decided not to wear a white coat, which many people connect with pain. He believes that dental treatment should happen in a relaxing, interesting, and enjoyable environment.

This approach may surprise many, as most people associate dental visits with discomfort or clinical settings. Jerome states, "If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past negative experiences." One of his innovative relaxation methods is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental practice in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the initial check-up, the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I examine their teeth. Then, the headset switches to a special camera that gives the patient a visual tour of their mouth."

Interestingly, most patients seem to enjoy this part of their dental visit. Another important aspect is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it has a pleasant orange scent. Jerome explains, "When people enter, I want them to realize through all their senses that this is not a typical dentist's visit. Smell is very important. The usual dental smell can make someone anxious if they are afraid of dentists." I found the gentle scent in the office very nice.

Although Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, he emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. While relaxation techniques are important, the quality of treatment is the top priority. For instance, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them instead of scraping, which can feel strange at first but is not painful if the patient is relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome traveled to the United States to study dental techniques. "One thing I learned is that when you make it easier for the patient, it also makes it easier for you," he explains. He believes his patient-focused approach is the beginning of a shift towards a more relaxed atmosphere in British dentistry.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this five-star treatment, and it’s easy to see why. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which comes from South America, is now a huge global business worth millions. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate during Easter, making it a popular time for chocolate sales. Only Christmas sees more chocolate consumption. Although large-scale chocolate production started in the last century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. 

The cacao tree is a tropical evergreen plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20 to 40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often incorrectly called cocoa beans, a mistake that dates back to the 17th century when they were also referred to as cacoa and cocao beans. The Aztecs even used cocoa beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in their language, Nahuatl. This drink was flavored with spices and served during ceremonies and to welcome guests.

The Spanish found the drink more enjoyable when mixed with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to reach the rest of Europe. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in major European cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, the drink was made from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. However, in 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from crushed beans. 

The modern chocolate bar began in 1847 when a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, combined cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid bar. A Swiss company later added milk solids, leading to the creation of milk chocolate. At the start of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French charm. Then, Cadbury introduced the Dairy Milk bar, originally called Dairymaid in 1905. Smart advertising linked it to the healthy image of milk from the English countryside, making it a strong competitor against rich French brands.

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain seems to have stabilized at about four bars per person each week. This has led manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. One recent strategy is the "extended line," where chocolate bars are transformed into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who want something different. 

On the other hand, cacao farmers are still struggling due to a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business because of this. So, as you enjoy your next chocolate bar, remember the challenges faced by those who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83 years old, Peter Cooke has become a master in his craft. He still has many interests, such as paper-making and feather-work, but for now, he focuses on creating delicate and unique objects from shells. As he shows me around his apartment, he asks, "Tell me if I am boring you." There is a fine line between being boring and being passionate, but Cooke is definitely the latter, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to some shell-covered decorations above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I’ve grown so fond of them. I never intended to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends suggested I have an exhibition so more people could see my art. They even spoke to a gallery owner." This led to a successful exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. Given the high prices of his work—around £2,000 for some ornaments—Cooke seems happy to part with them.

There are 86 pieces in this exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Cooke says he has no control over the prices and is open about them. He believes no one else makes art like his, and as the gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won’t be any more."

Cooke wishes he had started this work earlier, as he feels he could have created even more amazing things. Although he still has many ideas, he feels physically limited compared to when he began. However, his work is far from the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he says, which has led him to create boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, shaded pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers.

He has developed his own techniques and uses materials he finds. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue bought in bulk from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens," he explains. Yet, the detail, color variations, and symmetry in his work look very intentional.

Cooke's search for beautiful, tiny shells has taken him beyond his local beaches in Norfolk to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists that he only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of damaging the environment. "When I collect shells, I hear people walking on them much faster than I can collect them. The ones left behind are broken by the sea. I would never take shells with living creatures in them, but once they are empty, why shouldn’t I collect them?" His argument is convincing, especially considering the beauty he creates from the shells he finds.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is a 15-year-old model who often travels to exciting places and appears on magazine covers. When she is not modeling, she studies for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw shares more about her.

The receptionist at Kira's modeling agency told me, "I'm afraid Kira will be a little late." I thought, "That's fine." I had been trying to ignore the negative things I had read about models, but words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent kept coming to mind. I wondered how late she would be—an hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she chose to go to the hairdresser instead of meeting me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to talk. 

However, when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, arrived, she was smiling, relaxed, and accompanied by her mother. She was not wearing expensive designer clothes but a simple black dress and trainers. There was no sign of a selfish attitude; she was just a very friendly, tall, and pretty girl. Kira explained that all models under 16 must bring an adult with them to work, and her mother, who looked proud of her daughter, was just a normal mum.

Kira seems a bit confused by her sudden fame, which is understandable since it was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter the modeling competition. "She saw the competition and said I should join," Kira recalled. "I said no, but she sent some photos anyway." When she learned she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected gave Kira the confidence to continue, and she performed well, winning easily. The Select model agency in London quickly offered her work.

Now, Kira finds it challenging to balance her two lives. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some unkind classmates make rude comments about her success, saying she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this difficult, especially since she is not self-important. She said, "They think that because I became a model, I can't stay the same. The only thing that has changed is that I am more confident—not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more."

Being a busy model affects her social life. The Select agency can call her at any time to offer a job for the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't promise to join them because I don't know my schedule. I can't make plans, and sometimes they get canceled, but my friends understand. They don’t complain that I’m always busy with modeling."

Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a great career ahead of her, and not many people can say that before finishing their school exams. As I was about to end the interview with this remarkable girl, I asked what she would like to do if she didn't have her beauty. She paused and replied, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

**Father and Son Start Gold Rush**

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the warm lands of Africa in search of valuable metals. This father and son team—one an explorer and the other a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could hold up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they are sure they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated."

They have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their journey began when Terence read about gold worth millions hidden in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the most promising land to explore. After clearing away plants and finding pieces of gold in the rocks, they spent the last ten years getting permission from landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. 

Now, they are running low on money. Having spent their savings on this dream, they need to convince an investor to put £50,000 into the project to dig a bit deeper to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, this seems unlikely, but we have several people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread through the valleys last week, the allure of gold began to attract the attention of local residents as well as other gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourism, and locals are cautiously optimistic. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they are right, it would bring more visitors here, but I hope millions of people don’t come and disturb the hillside if they find gold."

The Welsh gold industry has greatly declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It’s adventurous and exciting, the thrill of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I’ll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited, and she can touch the two pilots. They are used to these cramped conditions, where they cannot stand up or move freely, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is an emergency and they need to get to the top quickly, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface, similar to a ping-pong ball in water. "No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey," she says.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She climbed in on the deck of a ship with an instructor, who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were assessing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with their chimneys releasing black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effects of a multinational program that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers,'" she explains. This term refers to underwater volcanoes where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This water flows out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel recalls a frightening experience during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment with a 50-meter rope when suddenly there was an explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought, "I'm going to die." They looked at each other in silence, waiting for something to happen. When nothing did, they felt an incredible relief—they were still alive!

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my PhD, and when I finally saw them in person, it was an amazing feeling."

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was exhausted, and my mind was tired of dealing with different train schedules, currencies, and languages. "Never again," I told myself as I returned home. I repeated this every year after. All I needed to do was buy one train ticket, and since I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month.

Once you learn to sleep in a train corridor, regular beds feel different. Carrying all your belongings in a rucksack makes you travel simply and can lead to wasteful habits, like burning socks that smell bad or throwing away finished books. However, this carefree attitude is part of the Inter-Rail experience, where common sense can be forgotten along with your paperback and socks. All it takes is one of those tickets in your hand. A system that allows young people to travel through multiple countries in a day is quite special.

On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t realize how much we could do with this train ticket. We thought it was just a cheap way to reach our campsite in southern France. But the idea of traveling non-stop was too appealing; there was always another country just across the border, always somewhere further to explore. And the extra miles? They cost us nothing.

We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Railers. We focused on the sights that were easiest to see. It was a chance to escape guided tours and do something different. I took pride in the fact that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We were just trying to get by and enjoy ourselves, just like most other Inter-Railers who shared the train corridors, food, water, money, and music with us.

The excitement of travel comes from arriving in a place that was just a name before. It feels like the city didn’t exist until the train arrived, and you could finally see it with your own tired eyes. Only by experiencing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing different attitudes and lifestyles can you truly understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means nothing until you see it for yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be so dull. While the train journey may not reveal new things about the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is vast, and Inter-Rail offers the best chance to appreciate this, even if it didn’t happen for us right away.

Text: 'There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline returns your bags. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and stuck in unsuitable clothing. Although airlines do not often share how many bags they lose, it is a common issue that regular travelers will eventually face. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and it is impossible for any airline to guarantee that your checked luggage will travel on the same flight, especially if your journey involves changing planes.

The system works like this: Airlines require passengers to check in early, which is meant to give enough time for luggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to transfer between two flights, and these times are also extended to help with baggage transfers. Normally, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic issues can lead to flight delays, which can disrupt the baggage system. Human error or accidents, like a torn destination label, can also cause problems. These issues can be worse at large airports, known as 'hubs', because they handle many bags. 

For example, last year, London’s Heathrow airport served over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone managed two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom transferred between Terminal 1 (for domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights). Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. The risk of losing luggage during plane changes is higher at certain airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when transatlantic passengers connect to flights in Latin America.

To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights whenever possible and check in well before the official time. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline for your entire journey. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and make sure to label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, including your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

**The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing some shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, muddy browns, and various shades of yellow from the sunlight, creating a peaceful atmosphere, just like the gentle sounds of water in the breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and gracefully through this setting, appearing like a flash of light. It is gone in an instant, but its image stays in your mind, powerful despite its small size.

Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. His deep feelings for this little bird are shown by his uncertainty about what exactly attracts him to it. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is a moon goddess that transformed into a bird. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its lower body was burned by the sun. There is some truth to this tale. Although kingfishers have many shades of blue in their feathers, they do not actually contain blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light, making them appear blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the angle of the light.

It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers are passionate about kingfishers. Their vibrant colors, combined with the fact that these birds are shy but can be observed from a distance, create a perfect opportunity for photographers. Charlie's first hideout was an old blanket he draped over himself while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat just a meter away. However, it took him another four years to capture his first good photograph. During this time, the European kingfisher became a major part of his life. He spent as much time as possible by a stream rich with kingfishers, but school limited his time with the birds. He missed classes and considered himself an "academic failure." Nevertheless, his passion for this widespread kingfisher, the only one of its family that breeds in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine, then became an assistant to the editor, and eventually worked as a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Now, Charlie dreams of making the perfect kingfisher film: "No speech, just beautiful images that say it all," he says. He prefers a simple approach and enjoys photographing parts of the kingfisher's wings. His thoughts drift as he reflects on the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still captivate him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his connection with the kingfisher than his work can ever reveal.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from New Conductors**

Giving directions to an orchestra is challenging. Anne Inglis interviews five new conductors about their experiences.

**A. Anne Manson**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She ended up filling in for an absent assistant and was later invited to help with another opera. "I had to lead the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. I wasn't nervous; I always feel confident in front of an orchestra." Manson, who is from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern music. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since her first experience, she has assisted Abbado on several projects.

**B. Andrew Constantine**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is finding the right opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after two unsuccessful attempts. Looking back, he feels lucky about the timing: "If it had happened earlier, I might have been forgotten." The competition opened many doors for him, including a position as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he struggles with being labeled as a competition winner: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be concerned. But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, which hired me after the competition, are inviting me back. If that stops, my career could suffer."

**C. Wasfi Kani**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods that come with opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," says Kani, who began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's commercial sector until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Taking lessons with Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size, unlike the larger conductors I had learned from before. This made a big difference." Kani appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many conflicts, and you have to consider the personalities of the singers."

**D. Roger Vignoles**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, says conducting surprised him but is very interesting. He started as a resident musician at an opera house and learned from great conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's *Agrippina* from the piano at a festival, which was a new experience for him. "It was easier than I expected. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I did my best to achieve that. Thankfully, people respect my overall musical ability. I learn from every experience, both in musical style and performance. Now, I am open to any opportunities to discover what I enjoy."

**E. Wayne Marshall**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, a young assistant conductor, and recommended him to his agent. Now 32, Marshall quickly found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was a tough start. He even had to manage some relaxed professional musicians who were reading newspapers during the performance. "I was firm with them. I always kept a clear beat and aimed for the best results. Many orchestral musicians I’ve seen don’t seem to need much guidance from a conductor. But I’m never afraid to express what I want. If people see you’re anxious, it only gets worse. I haven’t studied conducting formally, and no book teaches you how to conduct, but people have been supportive. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you are considering taking children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to review some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US and thought Fun Island might be boring in comparison. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is designed for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is also a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides, like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could use more atmosphere and better scenery. However, the staff were very helpful, and we found the park to be clean, well-organized, and focused on safety.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we were unsure what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings that he could see easily! The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to relax. The landscaping was beautiful, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There was something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we still felt there was more to explore. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act that kept us excited. We tried the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes closed, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, which looked like it would get you wet, but it didn’t. For younger children, Toy Land was a lot of fun. The kids wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved when they found out they were too small for it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides is not boring. It was very clean, and the staff were excellent. On one ride, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member kindly went with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am quite timid, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over before we knew it! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the children were a bit older, they might have found it less exciting, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we definitely felt that was true. Europe's tallest roller coaster, the Rocket, stands out in the park, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, while Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We noticed that the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World, and we wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.

A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer-aided design business that earns over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Since she had experience with computers, her husband suggested she start a design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. However, she was careful with her spending and kept the bank informed. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. Her business remains small, and most customers pick up their work directly.

B. **Maggy Sasanow** is a greetings card designer who works from home. She studied art at university and initially wanted to work in a museum. After moving to the countryside, where such jobs were unavailable, she decided to start her own business. She creates a collection of 50 greetings cards that she sells to museums. Although she enjoys her independence, she finds it challenging to focus at home because there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. She relies on word-of-mouth for business and does not advertise. Her prices are lower than those of other artists, which attracts customers from London. While she misses exchanging ideas with others, she believes the benefits of working alone outweigh the drawbacks.

C. **Delia Turner** runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started her business eight years ago when it was growing, and her income increased from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. At one point, she managed six full-time workers, but due to an economic decline, she had to let them go, which was difficult because jobs are scarce in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband’s help and employs women who work from their homes. She must be ready to lower her prices when needed and explore new opportunities.

D. **Tessa Strickland** manages her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and because she loves the rural lifestyle. She enjoys the flexibility of working when she wants, but 80% of her income comes from international deals, which means she often takes calls at unusual hours. The challenge is maintaining discipline to separate work from home life. Tessa publishes children's books from various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt isolated since all her professional experience was in London.

E. **Meg Rivers** runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop that earns £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. She started her business ten years ago at home, focusing on health by making fruit cakes with high-quality ingredients. Requests from friends and family led her to send cakes across the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where all the baking is done, employing a baker and a cake decorator. Meg no longer bakes herself, as she manages the business side. Her biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, as she started with limited funds.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is made up of talented musicians. The sons are composers and award-winning musicians, while their father, John, makes musical instruments. 

In South Wales, schoolteachers John and Hetty Watkins wanted to buy a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, who was showing great talent. However, they found that cellos were very expensive. John thought about making one himself. He discovered the Welsh School of Instrument Making nearby and took evening classes for about three years. 

After trying to make violins and violas, John finally made his first cello. Paul, now 28, remembers, "It turned out really well. He made me another one later, and I used that one until a few months ago." John has now retired from teaching and works full-time as a craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. Selling one to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo was a special achievement for him.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano: "As soon as I could climb up and bang the keys, I did," he recalls. Soon after, he was drawn to the cello. "My parents wanted me to play the violin because Dad played the viola and needed another violin for his music group. I tried it for six weeks but didn’t enjoy it. I was inspired by the cellist in Dad's group, who I thought was really cool when I was six or seven. He offered to give me lessons, and that’s how I started."

Huw, now 22, says, "My parents were supportive but not pushy. I wouldn’t have responded well to pressure. Instead of feeling jealous of Paul’s success, I saw it as something to aspire to." Huw is now making a name for himself as a pianist and composer.

Paul has achieved great success with the cello his father made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and, at just 20 years old, became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, using his father's cello until last year. Now, he plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, which he has on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. 

"Dad hasn’t said anything about me moving on to a new cello," Paul shares. "But he did play both cellos and admitted that my new one is quite nice! My dad's cello might need 50-100 years to develop the power to fill large concert halls like my Rugeri, which is already 304 years old."

Soon, Paul will perform on television with the Rugeri cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto, part of a new series called Masterworks. "The history of the piece doesn’t change how I play it," he says. "I will always play it my way." However, Paul won’t be able to watch himself on TV because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will have its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall that evening. John and Hetty will need to be organized and energetic to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking After the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks with Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust to care for its beautiful areas.

According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills. "You are always interacting with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and construction companies," he explains. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the warden position, but Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he did not have formal training. 

Gareth finds it useful to still farm with his parents, as it allows him to relate to farmers and understand their challenges. He also has the physical strength needed for the job, which includes tasks like building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers, butterfly larvae, and birds' nests as a child and now realizes how farming has changed the countryside. He believes that farmers were just following government advice and that it is not their fault.

When Gareth started his job, farmers and conservationists often disagreed. However, now they are communicating and understanding each other's perspectives. "We are at a turning point, and it only takes a small step to bring them together," he says. 

Gareth's work focuses on conservation, allowing public access to Trust land, planting and caring for trees, and working with tenant farmers. "My job is to ensure tasks are completed efficiently and with minimal fuss. I enjoy seeing projects finished, although I spend about half my time on reports and paperwork," he shares. 

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys every moment, especially interacting with the public. However, he finds some visitors frustrating. "Some people come in, demand everything, and leave as if they own the place. It can be annoying to stay polite with them!" he admits. 

In the end, Gareth believes that common sense is key. If you have plenty of it and enjoy working outdoors, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. Just remember, there may not be a position available on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had just finished a typical day of teaching at a local school, followed by a training session in a supermarket parking lot. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm so focused on my movements and my feet that I don't notice much else. I might see cars slowing down out of the corner of my eye, but that's it."

Kendra explained, "My whole life is about being at my best for the Championships." She is following a strict schedule to reach maximum fitness. This will be her fourth World Championships, which will be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. "Having home support is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a strong performance."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra noted that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day; there is no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years since she started playing at a high level, the sport has become more difficult and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard just to lose. But once the game is over, we become friends again."

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. Kendra stated, "It is essential for us to think and train like world-class players. As captain, I believe it is important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging my teammates."

Kendra mentioned, "From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned. I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she will probably have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents support a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be challenging to know how to nurture their abilities. Some parents may not realize their child's needs until frustration leads to difficult behavior. While most schools can help academically gifted children, musically talented kids often need special attention that regular schools may not provide, especially if music is seen as less important.

Children who are musically gifted, or those whose talents are encouraged by their parents or teachers, can benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established relatively recently. These schools create a supportive environment for children aged seven to eighteen to develop their musical skills under the guidance of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, students spend about one third to one half of their day on music-related activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), playing in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program that focuses on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, although students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with smaller class sizes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school, which allows them to spend their formative years with peers who share similar goals and interests.

However, there are some disadvantages. The cost is a significant issue, with fees ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 a year for boarders. Each school tries to help families with scholarships and financial aid for exceptionally talented children. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop well-rounded individuals.

Separating musically gifted children from a young age can create stress. Some early signs of musical talent may fade during the teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide support when needed. 

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some worry about the limited academic focus, as many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and may feel frustrated if their academic needs are not met. Therefore, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before considering a specialist music education.

Students who are also academically gifted may thrive in a less specialized setting, such as a school with a strong music program, or by combining regular schooling with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, along with orchestral and chamber music experiences. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

**An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings, which are inspired by the large garden around her house. This garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west are beautifully arranged in terms of color, shape, and structure. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to create detailed studies of individual plants instead of painting the entire garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants in their natural setting, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which can take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build the painting gradually. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all bloom together, and it's a hectic time," she says. However, she finds beauty in the gradual decay of flowers. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem dull, but they keep changing with twists and turns."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she recalls. "I wasn't really interested in gardening back then; I didn't like garden flowers because they reminded me of fake ones sold in some flower shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden features many plants from distant lands, which seem just as comfortable in her garden as they do in their native places like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed approach to gardening, similar to a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of inspiration right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

A chalet girl's work is never finished, says Sarah Sutherland-Pilch to Veronica Lee, as she balances making beds and cooking delicious meals. Sarah, 24, from West Sussex, is in her second year as a chalet girl. She works for a company in Val d'Isère, France, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art. She views being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent career. "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week," she explains.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she admits is the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can be on the slopes until 4:30 p.m.," she says.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but avoids sleeping, as she believes it would make her feel worse. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen, saying, "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning." Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week wonderful—breakfast this morning was great fun—but some weeks don’t go as well for various reasons."

Sarah lives in a chalet with friends, and they usually go out around 11 p.m. "We often start at Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar," she shares. However, she doesn’t stay out too late on Saturday nights because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day," she says, "when you really don’t want to cook breakfast feeling tired."

On Sundays, work starts earlier, with breakfast for guests served by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We just blitz the place—clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get everything ready." If she hasn’t done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. "Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions. I think the mountain air affects them," she jokes.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or equipment by taking them to the ski shop and getting a ride back. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and she might chat with friends, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zookeeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing my outfit for Marie Claire was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at work. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, and here I was rushing around when I could have been quietly cuddling an animal. Some fashion team members seemed stressed, but my job is not very pressuring. During a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed at the thought that I would usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I find it interesting to see how magazines operate, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. They gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. While I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes in a cupboard. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a fantastic day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the television gardening program Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I enjoyed being outside because I sometimes don’t see daylight due to my shifts. Even though it was hard work, it was a lot of fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the rest of the team. My idea of landscape gardening didn’t include hard physical work or careful planning. I’m more enthusiastic than effective at gardening, so I don’t plan to quit my other job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener on Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and handed out medicine. I thought I would feel faint during some tasks, but I surprised myself by managing well. The friendship among the nurses was great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less meaningful compared to nursing. My day at the hospital wasn’t pleasant, but it gave me a great sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and as soon as I put it on, I felt different—people looked up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew about from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt very self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult to manage them."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I was surprised to see that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drank a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast and crosses into Italy. It takes you past some of the most beautiful sea views. No matter the weather or the time of year, the journey is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the stunning scenery.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many great train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels through the northern Sudan desert. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. I was sent to stay with an aunt instead. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn’t traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real train station I saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey itself was wonderful, traveling through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding planning.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on articles about a round-the-world trip and needed to cross a desert in Africa. There were no roads, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was unpredictable; we were just told to be ready on a certain day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train finally arrived, it was a rush of people climbing into and onto the carriages, and some even traveled on the roof for free. At night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite memories of trains when they are young, but that’s not my story. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming took place on an old, unused part of the line that volunteers had carefully maintained. That’s where my love for steam trains began. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, it felt like time had stopped. Everything was still the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Are you trying to get your work published? If you’re unsure where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" One important thing to remember is that you need to research your market and learn about publishers while also improving your writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires a good understanding of the publishing world. 

No matter what type of writing you do, it’s essential to know the markets you want to target. There are several ways to do this, but the best method is to read as much as you can about relevant topics. Visit your local library and explore nearby bookstores and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are currently accepting. 

As time goes on, you need to keep updating your knowledge because new publications are always appearing. Editors change jobs, and magazines can shift their focus. Publishers are always looking for new talent, so as writers, we must provide what they want. 

If you’re unsure about what to write, let’s say you want to write short love stories. The first step is to find out which magazines publish love stories, a limited market these days, and collect recent copies. Familiarize yourself with the types of stories they buy and pay attention to their readers' expectations. The editor’s goal is to meet the needs of their audience.

Writers often ask me, "This has been rejected three times—am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone, but it’s likely that the work isn’t ready for publication. I try to give honest feedback while remaining positive. Many new writers are too eager to submit their work before they are truly ready. If you’ve only written one story or article, it’s very unlikely to be published. This rarely happens. When you hear about someone’s success, they usually have years of experience in publishing or journalism behind them.

When you finally send out your work for the first time, start writing more while you wait for a response. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will improve your skills, and you will start to see yourself as a writer, which will boost your confidence. Instead of discarding any of your work, focus on improving it. I also recommend not sharing your work with others in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before achieving success.

Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for creative writing courses in your area. If you can’t find one, consider joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.'

**No Title**

On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people waiting than I had expected. The usual clean and bright atmosphere of the station was gone. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students had left their bags all over the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers one by one. He looked well-off: he had tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came over to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I wouldn’t mind talking to her myself. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" 

"Well, I’m going north," she replied. "But to Philadelphia?" 

"No, I’m going to New York, but I’ll be..." 

"Thanks anyway," he said, moving on to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. "Ma'am," I heard him ask an old lady, "are you traveling to Philadelphia?" When she said she was going to Wilmington, he just walked on to a couple with matching luggage.
