I straightened up from my pillar and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform as if I was focused on the train. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn’t; I probably seemed unreliable to him. He glanced at me quickly and then turned to the other end of the waiting area. By now, he looked very stressed. 

"Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you’re going to Philadelphia!" She looked up from her book. She was in her thirties, maybe thirty-five—older than me. She looked like a school teacher. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." 

"Then could I ask you a favor?" I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my left wrist (even though I didn’t own a watch). I could tell she was becoming cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" They were announcing my train now. People started moving toward Gate E, the older couples pulling their wheeled bags behind them like pets on leashes. 

Next, I heard the man talking. "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries afterward, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia and didn’t know what to do." The woman nodded sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet and waited to see where he was going with this. 

"So I told her to stay put. Stay right there in the station, I said, and I would get someone to bring her passport." It sounded suspicious! Why didn’t he go himself if it was such an emergency? 

"Why don’t you go yourself?" the woman asked. 

"I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." This seemed like a weak excuse to me. Also, it was too much bad luck for one family. I glanced at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded one the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn’t feel what was inside! From where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. Watch yourself, lady, I thought silently.

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, shares his thoughts about his son Gary, who is a well-known TV chef. John believes that everyone has a chance in life. For him, that chance was to run a restaurant, while Gary's chance was to cook. When John learned about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it. The place was in terrible condition, but it was just what he needed.

Starting this business reminded John of his childhood. He remembers feeling sad when his mother went to work in a factory and left him alone. This made him want to ensure his family had time together. His wife took care of their children and managed the finances while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made it a point to have meals together. This focus on family helped their children, Gary and Joe, grow up confident. From a young age, they would talk to the restaurant's regular customers, which gave them a good start in life.

Gary was an energetic child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and accidentally knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to earn his pocket money. He started with small jobs and by the age of ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which meant he always had money at school. He was disciplined and often woke up before his father. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John enjoyed seeing Gary contribute.

Although Gary was not very good at school, he excelled in the kitchen. By the time he was 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could prepare over a hundred meals, and John realized that Gary had a talent for catering. When Gary needed to do work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one goal at a time, saying, "If you chase two hares, you will catch neither." John also told Gary that he needed to achieve his goals by the age of 30, or it might be too late.

At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, while other students were just starting, Gary quickly chopped vegetables and sliced meats, finishing his tasks in less than an hour. He even helped his classmates. No one expected Gary's TV cooking show to become so successful, and John is very proud of him. He has always taught Gary that hard work is essential because nothing is given for free. Gary recognized the opportunity he had and took full advantage of it.

As parents, we hope our children listen to us as they grow up. If they remember even a small part of what we say, we should be grateful. John feels that Gary has listened and learned from him.

**Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very difficult. The best way to find one is through personal connections. If you know someone who knows someone leaving a flat, that can help. But if, like Jo, you have just arrived in Dublin, you don’t have those connections. You might have to stay in a hostel and search for a place. For Jo, Dublin felt like a big unknown. She felt nervous when she took the train to start her new job there. She didn’t question why she was going; everyone at school expected her to leave her small town. They all wanted to escape and experience life. Some of her classmates had moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family members helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo’s mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel permanently. It was run by nuns, so her mother believed she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel would be warm, as they are often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a week. However, Jo was unaware that they were still talking about her while she responded to an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen and bathroom." It was very close to her workplace and seemed too good to be true. Jo hoped it would be nice, that the people would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive.

There wasn’t a long line for this flat because it was more about finding a "Third Girl Wanted" than just a flat to rent. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal—an ordinary red-brick building with a basement. The flat was upstairs, and as Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down. 

"Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They’re both awful. Common as dirt." 

"Oh," Jo replied and continued up. 

"Hello," said the girl wearing a T-shirt with "Nessa" on it. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can’t stand her kind." 

"What did she do?" Jo asked. 

"She didn’t do anything. She just looked around, made a face, and giggled, saying, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" 

Pauline, wearing a very colorful shirt, looked like a punk, which surprised Jo. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but had never talked to one before. 

"I'm Jo, I work at the post office and called about the flat," she said. 

Nessa mentioned they were about to have tea and brought out three mugs—one with "Nessa," one with "Pauline," and one labeled "Other." 

"We’ll put your name on a mug if you decide to stay," she said kindly.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside marinas, movies, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of these animals.

Dolphins are special to us. They are among the most intelligent animals, sensitive to human feelings, and they inspire us with dreams of freedom in the ocean. Our affection for dolphins has been supported by television shows. First, there was Flipper, and now we have Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy images hide the harsh reality of dolphins living in polluted and overfished waters.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000. You might think that such beloved animals would be protected by law and cared for in marine reserves, but this is not the case. The lack of protection for dolphins could lead to one of the biggest wildlife disasters of our time.

There are forty different types of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out at sea and are often seen in small groups. We know very little about them. In contrast, bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises were once frequently seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and used to be found along the Channel coast and in rivers like the Thames. Now, they can only be found in a few places, such as the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show signs of stress, such as skin injuries.

Understanding why dolphin numbers are declining is complicated. Overfishing is greatly reducing fish populations, which threatens both local fishing industries and dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are removed from one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They are also at risk of getting caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use large nets that are either left floating or pulled quickly through the water. In recent years, hundreds of dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall, with injuries indicating they were caught in these nets.

Dolphins can also store harmful substances in their bodies. For example, pesticides can build up in their fat. Female dolphins produce milk that contains these toxins, which can harm their young. There has been at least one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s contaminated milk.

Another serious threat to dolphins comes from human activity. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their environment. Noise pollution from ships and oil drilling travels much better in water than in air, which may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced, especially when life feels chaotic. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to.

Exercise improves your muscle tone and can quickly change your body shape. It increases muscle strength and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It also prevents muscle imbalances that can lead to injuries and improves specific areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. Additionally, exercise benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You may have heard these benefits before, but here’s something new: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can improve your sleep. It also helps manage stress and can relieve some medical conditions. If these reasons don’t motivate you, just remember that common sense tells us exercise is good for our health.

There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, jogging, and weight training. However, be careful not to overdo it, as training too hard can lead to injuries. If you’re unsure about what exercises are right for you, it’s a good idea to talk to your doctor.

Good posture is essential for improving your body shape. Poor posture can make you look and feel less energetic and can lead to minor health issues. If you tend to slouch, imagine that a helium balloon is pulling the top of your head upward. This can help you lift your chest for better breathing and make your body look slimmer.

Stretching is also important. It improves flexibility and helps you move easily, while preventing injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. Stretching should be done slowly and carefully.

A good exercise routine includes warming up, stretching, an energetic workout, and cooling down afterward.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What keeps filmmakers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman away from their comfortable homes for months? They are searching for the perfect shot. Among all the animals in the jungles and plains of East Africa, Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman are some of the hardest to find. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has experienced six months of almost continuous rain, leading to many unexpected problems. Newman explained that they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their partnership has produced some of the best wildlife films on TV, including a well-received film about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time following the shy jackal.

This is common for traveling filmmakers, who have been exploring the world to film exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke to Newman during one of his rare meetings with other people at a safari lodge. He mentioned, "We do have occasional arguments, but we tend to resolve them quickly." Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and he believes they get along well because they both view animals in a similar way. "When we are on the move, we usually set up our tents each night. But this time, we are working from a more fixed camp. We set out at 5 a.m. each morning, so we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask." Their daily meals consist of pre-packed food that is heated and served by whoever is available. "It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks at a time, so meal preparation can be stressful," says Newman. 

Their life can be tough, but being in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals and become part of their lives. Newman recalls filming a family of lions, where one lioness would often wander off. When she returned, she would greet all the other lions, and eventually, she included their car in her greetings.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift," and two years later, they teamed up to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. "Amanda and I developed a strong working relationship from the beginning," says Newman, "because it was clear we shared the same ideas and vision. We aim to create a film that captures the atmosphere, brings the true spirit of the place and animals to life, and touches people's hearts. I believe evoking an emotional response is much more powerful than just appealing to logic."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had just finished a typical day of teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised by her training location. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm so focused on my movements and my feet that I don’t notice much else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that’s it."

Kendra explained, "My whole life now is about being at my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to improve her fitness. This will be her fourth World Championships, and it is expected to be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. "Having home support is very special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a strong performance."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra mentioned, "We have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against because they have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra noted that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There’s no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years since she started playing at a high level, the sport has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard just to lose." But once the game is over, players become friends. 

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. Kendra stated, "It’s essential that we all think and train like world-class players." As captain, she believes it’s important to have a strong mindset and to lead by example. "I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team."

Kendra has carefully planned her netball career from the start. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she is likely to have tears of joy, knowing her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, Rachel says, "Space is very limited. I can reach out and touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move around, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface."

"If there is an emergency and we need to get to the surface quickly, we can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but I imagine it would not be a pleasant experience."

Rachel recalls her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were assessing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes that release black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I enjoy, but I do it to support my research on 'black smokers,' another name for underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke, pouring out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."

The only time Rachel felt scared was during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied black smokers for three years for my Ph.D., and seeing them in person was an amazing experience."

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Research shows that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, and how we speak, including our speed, volume, and tone of voice, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she noticed a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing but decided it would make her late, and she believes being on time is very important. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who teaches at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, explains that candidates who take care of their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. While people often say that what matters is inside, it is important to present yourself well in an interview.

Many people overlook the importance of a professional image. For instance, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but did not even get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed her work performance should matter more than her appearance.

Body language and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message about feelings comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our words and facial expressions send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. Therefore, it is important that your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It is also crucial not to seem too desperate for the job or overly eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion and had a great interview, leading to an immediate job offer. She was very excited but showed too much enthusiasm. Once her boss sensed her excitement, he offered her a lower salary than she expected. She believes she could have negotiated a better salary if she had controlled her excitement.

Finally, what you say and how you say it can greatly affect your interview success. David Artesio, a manager at an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, reading the annual report can help you understand the company's activities. Mentioning an area that interests you during the interview can show your genuine interest.

Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions prepared and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators use short sentences and highlight key points."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City became boring—no one was enjoying it anymore. I didn’t plan to leave for another five or ten years, but then I was unexpectedly laid off. I didn’t receive a great severance package, but it was enough to start my farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel that has one of the top 20 restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat through mail order. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed for me: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and I’m still selling a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. He explains, "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. Choosing to take redundancy and become an artist felt like the right choice. The career counselor I spoke to was very supportive. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for financial reasons. My wife and I married young, and our children are now independent, so we took a risk and moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but luckily, our friendships have lasted, and many of them visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. She says, "Being a lawyer was enjoyable and well-paid, but the hours were awful. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even longer hours, so I decided to leave. Many people thought I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to set deadlines. Since my business is related to fashion, I have to keep up with collections and trends, which keeps me busy. I feel happier now and much less stressed. However, I do miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a poor job, I am the one who faces the consequences. When you work for a company, you care, but when your name is on the product, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He shares, "I was in financial markets from the age of 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I never found the work fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I decided to resign and travel for a year. During that time, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms in the world and spoke to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Eventually, I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future, which is the best part."

**Dedicated to Their Sports: Four Young Athletes Share Their Lives**

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always been active in sports. I tried many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it did not get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training can be expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It’s fun there with great facilities and nightlife, but I have to be very disciplined. If friends invite me out the night before training, I have to decline. I wish I could go out, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics, which would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I often see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers take their sport seriously, and the best waves are usually at dawn. To succeed, I have to avoid late-night parties. I don’t mind giving that up, but I do miss sleeping in. However, it’s worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice getaway. Winning the championship also led to me being chosen to host a surfing series on TV, so I guess I’m a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
Being on a boat with my teammates is always fun. We have a traditional way of celebrating our wins, and some people say we act a bit childish, but we don’t seek media attention. Sometimes, reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than our race results. I spend eight months a year away, so it’s nice to return home and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. It’s not healthy to focus only on sailing all the time. I am known in the sailing world, but I rarely get recognized in public, which I prefer. I receive many nice letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I make sure to reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to walk onto the court and feel the support of the crowd. At my last tournament, things got a bit hectic with fans crowding around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I’m out shopping, but it has its challenges. My last girlfriend didn’t like it when I received too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that contributed to our breakup, which was tough. However, sacrifices are necessary in any sport, and I try to stay focused and professional. I’m happy to concentrate on my game now and will catch up on other aspects of life after I retire, which comes early in this sport.

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder." Her children want everything they see, whether it's the newest sugary cereal, a Disney video, or a comic book—often all three. She feels guilty when she buys them unhealthy items, but she also hates saying no all the time. This makes her feel frustrated before they even leave the house. Although she tries to avoid taking them shopping, she worries that she is not giving them the chance to learn how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are a key place where this advertising is effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot afford certain items, and arguments about the dangers of sugar are not convincing when faced with attractive ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says that most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, even if those ideas are not always correct. It is important for parents and children to talk about food, especially since children often only hear about products from advertisements, which gives them a one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb notes that the goal of advertising is still to persuade viewers to make purchases, even if they do not directly say, "Tell your mom to buy this."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother mentions that she tries to be patient when discussing food with her children, but she feels uneasy about how she handles their shopping requests. She has talked to her son so much about advertisements that he now thinks they are not trustworthy. As a result, they have less conflict in the supermarket because he does not ask for things she does not want to buy.

Parents also recognize that they can be inconsistent in how they respond to their children's requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, admits that they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they believe they are unhealthy, while they themselves buy rich foods like double cream and chocolate. He finds it reasonable for children to want nice things, but he still feels annoyed by their requests. His willingness to say yes often depends on his mood and how well things are going in his life.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. While parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without constant demands from their kids could attract more customers, making up for any lost sales.

**Five-Star Luxury with Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin has been created after extensive research into what customers want and nearly two years of work converting four large 18th-century houses. This approach has allowed the hotel to include the latest technology for the benefit of both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses the hotel’s computer system to keep track of guests' preferences. This system helps the hotel provide special treatment for returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time because of its efficiency. For instance, if a guest requests specific music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests. The Merrion Hotel has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers are a significant part of the hotel’s clientele, making up about 65% of its business. To cater to their needs, the hotel has equipped each room with three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing facilities. The hotel has also prepared for future technological advancements by laying extra cables and renting televisions, so they can easily upgrade to newer models.

Despite all this modern equipment, MacCann emphasizes that they want guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed by technology. The hotel has 145 spacious and well-furnished bedrooms that are both cozy and inviting. Guests can also enjoy a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.

The food at the Merrion Hotel is of high quality, thanks to Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who moved his already Michelin-starred restaurant to the hotel. This move has allowed him to create a new, modern kitchen and improve parking facilities. For the hotel, having a successful restaurant on-site is a great advantage with minimal financial risk. With the help of technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is set to thrive.

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully to share how they find their energy.

A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "For me, excitement is key. I need challenges and new things to learn to feel energized. I also get energy from rhythm; right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing. Dance is expressive and uplifting. If I'm bored, I feel drained and like life has no purpose. Being effective, even in small ways, gives me energy."

B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it all. Work is not a burden for me. Enjoying what I do helps me feel good, even when I'm tired. I need enough sleep to feel my best. When I only get six hours, I feel sluggish. Exercise boosts my energy, but I sometimes struggle to find the motivation. I attend a yoga class weekly and try to work out at home. After exercising, my mood improves significantly. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it's good to have a snack then."

C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don't rely on healthy eating for energy; I think it's about having natural enthusiasm and a positive attitude. I dislike negativity. I believe we should enjoy life and seize the moment. Achieving goals is important, and I love my work. The last two years have been exciting, surrounded by lively young people. I enjoy being busy and social. I like taking photos, even if I'm not great at it, and I write lyrics for fun, which helps me relax while traveling."

D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in my work and being positive in life. I enjoy working with children because they are full of energy and resilience. Energy is like a natural spark that comes from connecting with others—just smile at someone and see how it feels when they smile back. It's much better than feeling sorry for yourself. I try to eat healthily and avoid smoking and drinking, but I don't have a strict exercise routine. I get my energy from playing with kids."

E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "What I love most is transforming a wasteland into a garden. I once turned a concrete area into a beautiful garden, which was more energizing than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing also gives me energy. I enjoy sneaking into nature, and if caught, I playfully say I didn't know it was private. I find joy in that childlike adventure."

F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I believe it's important to have an interest in and respect for what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don't want to do drains my energy. I used to be part of many committees, but I found their demands exhausting. You have limited energy, so focus it on what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones, which were used until iron skates appeared in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For the wealthy in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as elegant, but everything changed at the 1924 Winter Olympics when 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating very popular.

Today, skating combines art and athleticism, making it both beautiful and physically challenging. For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed will improve as you get better. Your body position is key to maintaining balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and your knees relaxed, leaning a bit forward. Relaxation is essential in skating, more than in many other sports.

To start skating, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outward. Push off with your back foot while making a small movement with the other foot. It’s not too hard! If you practice this, you can gradually make longer movements as you gain confidence. Learning how to fall safely is one of the first skills a skater should master. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall without getting hurt, stay relaxed to reduce the impact with the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel and then stand up.

Once you feel comfortable on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance to help you learn the basic moves, and soon you can practice turns, jumps, and spins in freestyle.

If you watch skilled skaters, you will notice how relaxed and fluid their movements are. To achieve this, it’s important to follow a regular exercise routine. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should focus on your legs, back, shoulders, and especially your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also boosts heart and lung health and strengthens your body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it creates an excellent fitness program for overall health.

**Trills and Bills**

Seeing a talented child receive a medal can bring tears of joy. Julia Gregson spoke to three young achievers and their mothers about the joys and challenges they face.

A. **Annika Reeder**, 15, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She dreams of becoming a physiotherapist and competing in the next Olympics. "Training is very hard right now. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I take it one day at a time. When I’m really tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can’t take too many days off, or you get stiff."

B. **Annika's mother** says, "From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I’ve seen other parents push their kids, but it doesn’t work. To perform at Annika’s level requires a lot of time and energy, and she has to want it herself. People often say we, as parents, have sacrificed a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from around the world and gained confidence through her success."

C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at age ten and has since won the British National Championship. "It’s great that my parents enjoy show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love the excitement and fun of show-jumping. Even if my parents weren’t involved, I would still do it because I’m determined. I’m happy when they are proud of my wins, but I’m not doing it for them. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team, and my big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. **Sarah's mother** shares, "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age one, I knew she had found her passion. When she was five, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the living quarters of our horse box. Sarah is very organized and feels completely happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed in something they love is an incredible feeling."

E. **Jane McShane**, 10, is Britain’s Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t focus as much as I should; I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about becoming arrogant, and I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like feeling embarrassed."

F. **Jane's mother** explains, "Jane played her first game at age five. My father suggested we see if she liked it. He had tried to teach me when I was young, but I found it boring. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age six, she was beating adults. I’m proud when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I wouldn’t stop her. I also don’t want to discourage her because she is exceptional. If she has this talent, I want her to reach her full potential."

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall at that age. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a new super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors looked. According to palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer, we are starting to reach our true potential, similar to the Cro-Magnons who lived 40,000 years ago.

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many natural areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

Research in Ohio showed that when healthy hunter-gatherers started farming corn, they became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be a blessing, some anthropologists see it as a health disaster. Still, agriculture spread because one piece of farmland could support many more people than hunting could.

Today, many people who rely on farming are poorly nourished. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive trend, but it comes with challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Legroom in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing manufacturers are constantly adjusting their sizes. The question is: how tall can we grow? 

According to Robert Fogel from the University, we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, scientists warn that while individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate has warmed, we have become thinner and shorter, even with good nutrition. If global warming continues, we might shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by climate change.

**Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be part of an audience when a television show is being filmed? Cosmo Landesman explored this question. Like technical problems, studio audiences are a common part of television, but many of us find them mysterious. When we see people getting excited on game shows, we often wonder who they are. 

Studio audiences are often seen as the least important type of audience. Some people in the television industry even look down on them, comparing them to cattle. I used to think that studio audiences were made up of silly people wanting a moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience; they come from various backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract different kinds of people for different programs.

Many of us who watch television at home don’t understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit through hours of boredom just to watch something they could see at home? One idea is that people hope to be seen on television. I didn’t believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said she came for a chance to appear on TV. Another reason people attend is out of curiosity to see how things work behind the scenes. However, the most common reason I heard was simply, "A friend gave me a ticket."

Most of us have never been in a studio audience, yet we think we know what it’s like. You sit close to strangers while someone holds up signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you respond accordingly. This might be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, "We always assume a show will be good enough not to need these signs."

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," while Charlotte enjoyed the feeling of being part of live television. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." I found that I missed seeing the live actors; I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were filmed far from my seat, so I ended up watching the show on a studio monitor.

Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch television, but that’s not what matters. For most audience members, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favorite Places**

**Bruce**  
I don't like wild landscapes that are untouched by people. The human aspect is important to me. This is also true when I travel abroad. I am drawn to charming villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England, and on Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling was a way to escape from school. I enjoyed exploring the bare hilltops, sheltered valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape both familiar and different, and I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my private diary, which was my first attempt at travel writing, a field in which I later became well-known.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway that runs from Hythe to Dungeness, operated by enthusiasts. I always choose first class because it doesn’t cost much more than the regular ticket. The scenery isn’t spectacular. The train travels across Romney Marsh with its sheep and alongside a canal. However, there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when the train takes a detour through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers get a glimpse into people’s lives as they make tea, wash dishes, or set up deckchairs. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage, looking into other people’s homes. It’s the simplicity of the landscape that attracts me. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. This makes me look more closely, searching for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and remote coastline. The beaches are hard to reach and filled with rocks, so there are not many crowds here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors prefer to admire the power of the sea. The coast, facing the Atlantic, is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks that you can combine with trips into lovely damp valleys filled with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family who owns property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There are not many people living there and not many visitors either. It’s a quiet and remote area, and I enjoy the feeling of space. I discovered this place by chance when I was a student, and since then, I have visited every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has changed very little since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits even more special. It makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. It was about finding peace and reconnecting with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is the house of my dreams. It is a magical, secluded, romantic place. You can only hear the sea, the wind, and the birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are a family that loves animals of all kinds. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she had found a beautiful pine snake. She asked, "Can we keep him?" I replied, "Yes, but only for one night." We had prepared a special tank for such visitors, allowing us to admire them and look them up in our natural history book.

I got home late and quickly started boiling water when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed to their bedroom. The chaos involved our cat, Domino, and a white mouse named Bianca, which I had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth, trying to escape while avoiding the children’s flailing arms.

In the midst of the confusion, I tripped and fell. As I considered how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake had escaped. It was slithering off the table and onto the floor. I crouched down as the snake moved closer, while the kids and the cat continued to jump around in a wild, noisy mess. The dog was barking, and the pot in the kitchen boiled over. I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the chaos with renewed energy. 

I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the small, wet mouse from his jaws. Interestingly, this same mouse was caught by Domino three more times during its life but eventually died of old age.

Feeling encouraged by my success with the cat, I examined the snake but found no weak points. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, rocking back and forth, hoping to calm it down. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body, though its eyes still looked suspicious. I carefully slid my hands under the snake and stood up, walking to the end of the garden. There, I pointed the snake towards a tree, giving it the chance to live happily in the wild.

When I finally let go of the snake's head, expecting it to strike, it instead wrapped around my shoulders like a colorful shawl, seeming to settle in for the winter. We stood together in the fading light, with my four children, me, and the snake. My eldest son, DJ, broke the silence with a scientific observation: "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't."

I asked the children to gently encourage the snake to move on. Slowly, it did, climbing up the wall and disappearing over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished from sight, my three-year-old son, Clay, sighed and said what we were all thinking: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

**Drop Me a Line!**

In our fast-paced world of phones, faxes, and computers, the traditional art of letter writing is in danger of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter brings a special joy that no other form of communication can match. There is excitement when a letter arrives, pleasure in seeing who it is from, and enjoyment in reading its contents.

Letter writing has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.

When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back to me. Sometimes my father would write long, funny letters, which I loved. Most of the letters from home shared everyday events about my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters the most.

I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we kept in touch through letters. Surprisingly, writing letters seemed to strengthen our relationships. I found it easier to express my feelings in writing than in conversation.

I enjoy letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. While short notes are nice, it’s even better to receive a full year’s worth of news! I especially love getting airmail letters with beautiful stamps. I have friends who write to me from different countries, like Mangala in Sri Lanka, a penfriend in Australia, and another in Vancouver. There’s also a woman from France who writes to me. We started talking in a restaurant after a holiday, and I asked for her address. If she hadn’t replied, we would have missed out on a wonderful friendship. Now, we write regularly, which helps me improve my French since she doesn’t speak English. We have visited each other’s homes twice.

My biggest success in letter writing happened this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that our friendship lasted so long, and the local newspaper even featured our story on the front page.

I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did for my mother. She and my son also have penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend.

I strongly encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Alpine Rock Art**

Many ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are slowly being destroyed. Scientists worry that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they may not last for future generations. The mountain, which was once a place for prayer and worship, has drawings that are about 4,000 years old. These include images of cows with horns, cultivated fields, and various gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and blurs the artwork. Some visitors even break off pieces to take home as souvenirs. "When people think they can't take a good enough photograph, they rub the drawings to get a clearer picture," he explains. "The drawings are naturally polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them well, they rub and scrape them to make them look fresher."

Other researchers have noticed that some people come with long sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the entire mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He warns that if this is not done, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be lost.

Clottes disagrees with de Lumley's strict proposal, saying, "While it is the most effective, it will certainly lead to protests from local residents." He emphasizes that the site was declared a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture years ago, and we must do everything possible to protect it.

David Lavergne, the regional architect, also prefers not to close the site. He states, "De Lumley's idea isn't ideal. Our department believes the best solution is to let people visit, but the area is so large that it's hard to stop visitors from causing damage. I would like everyone to see it, but the main issue is financial. We do not have enough money to hire the necessary number of guards. We may need to consider charging an entrance fee, as there seems to be no chance of government funding."

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has also researched the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to access—tourists can now avoid the three-and-a-half-hour walk by hiring vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She believes the only solution is to cordon off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't go ahead because there is no money," she argues. "That is not acceptable. Funding must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we do not take action, we will be responsible for losing these drawings for future generations."

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder." Her children want everything they see, whether it's the newest sugary cereal, a Disney video, or a comic book—often all three. She feels guilty when she buys them these things, but she also hates saying no all the time. This makes her feel frustrated before they even leave the house. Although she tries to avoid taking them shopping, she worries that she is not letting them learn how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are a key place where this advertising is effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot afford certain items, and arguments about the health risks of sugar are not convincing when faced with appealing advertisements.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says that most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, even if those ideas are not always correct. It is important for parents and children to talk about food, especially since children often only hear about products from TV ads, which gives them a limited view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb notes that the goal of advertising is still to persuade viewers to make purchases, even if they do not directly say, "Tell your mom to buy this."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to accept and which to deny. One mother mentions that she tries to be patient when discussing food with her children, but she feels uneasy about how she handles their requests. She has talked to her son about advertisements so much that he now thinks they are not trustworthy. As a result, they have less conflict in the supermarket because he does not ask for things she does not want to buy.

Parents also recognize that they can be inconsistent in how they respond to their children's requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, admits that they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they believe they are unhealthy, while they themselves buy rich foods like double cream and chocolate. He finds it enjoyable to buy nice things and understands why children want to share in that. However, he also feels annoyed by their requests, which can depend on his mood. If he is feeling good, he is more likely to say yes, making it hard to be consistent.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by moving sweets away from checkout areas or by providing supervised play areas. While parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without constant demands from their kids could attract more customers, making up for any lost sales.

**Going Up the Wall**

In the past, climbers would go to the mountains to climb. Now, people can enjoy climbing in many places, both indoors and outdoors. The audience watches in excitement as the French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by just two fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is better known for hosting the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common: The Wall. The ability to hold such events is thanks to new and rapidly advancing technology.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As the sport grew, it became important for top climbers to stay fit. Since they couldn’t use cliffs for much of the year, they started to train on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom from not climbing.

Soon, many sports centers began to build climbing walls specifically for training, using bricks with special edges for grip. One of the first climbing walls was created by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in the mid-1960s at Leeds University. He came up with the idea of embedding natural rock into concrete blocks to create climbing walls. Throughout the 1970s, many similar walls were built in sports halls across the country, but they had clear design issues. These walls could only be vertical, while real cliffs have features like overhangs and slanted rocks. Once built, the walls couldn’t be changed, and climbers would eventually get bored with the same routes, no matter how many holds they tried.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a new material that could be shaped like the holds found on cliffs. These holds could be attached to any existing wall and removed when climbers wanted a change. French manufacturers also started to experiment with panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for creating overhanging walls without significant construction, but steel frames could be built anywhere as free-standing structures. This system of interchangeable holds provided climbers with endless new challenges.

**So You Want to Be an Actor**

If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will likely mention that it is a risky career. Acting is indeed risky because there are many more actors than there are jobs for them. When you decide to pursue acting, some people you thought were your close friends might think you are making a mistake, while others may support you. Everyone will have different opinions, but this is a personal choice, and you are responsible for your own path and dreams.

There are no easy shortcuts to becoming an actor. There are no exams to pass, and even after training, there is no guarantee of success in the profession. Success often depends on a mix of luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and the profession can offer excitement, glamour, and sometimes financial rewards.

Many people ask what talent is. I believe talent is a combination of natural ability and imagination, with imagination being the hardest to measure. It also involves a person's courage and their belief in what they are doing. 

The desire to act can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform. When you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they often do not have a clear answer. They understand some things about their skills and techniques, but they do not take their success for granted. They know they are only as good as their last job, and their fame can be temporary.

Disappointment is a major challenge for actors. One month, you might be unemployed, working in a store or as a waitress. Then, you might get a chance to audition for a role. However, no matter how much you want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often avoid discussing their chances of success. They find ways to cope with the stress of competing for roles and the fear of rejection. No one enjoys being rejected, and this possibility exists from the moment you start auditioning professionally. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. Ultimately, if you do not care enough about your acting career, others may not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**

We are excited to share our carefully chosen selection of the best cookbooks available. 

A. When people think of a famous TV chef and author, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many different cultures and show her love for delicious food, as well as her understanding of what the average person can cook at home. The book that made her famous is *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, which is now a key reference for modern cooks. It offers clear guidance on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of exciting recipes. This recently updated book answers the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"

B. Raymond Blanc went from being an untrained chef to owning one of the most famous French restaurants in Britain in just 15 years. To go along with his first TV series, *Blanc Mange*, he has released a book with the same name. Raymond wants to help everyone become better cooks by explaining how and why certain ingredients behave in specific ways. He believes that cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book includes over 80 fantastic recipes that illustrate his points. It is a practical guide that also explains why some dishes might not turn out well and introduces basic food science to help clarify these ideas. Monsieur Blanc enjoys cooking for others, and this book shows that he is very skilled at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that represents the best in traditional French cooking. For the past 100 years, expert chefs at this renowned cooking school have trained students of all levels to achieve excellence. To celebrate its centenary, they have published the *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook*, featuring 100 of the school's most respected recipes. While these recipes are classic, they still feel fresh. Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking but has also adapted its recipes to be lighter and healthier. The book starts with basic kitchen techniques and includes sections on Appetizers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is accompanied by step-by-step illustrations and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have chosen their favorite recipes and shared their tips with readers.

D. Fast food? No way! Many people think that good food requires a lot of time and effort in the kitchen. However, Nigel Slater, the food editor of *The Observer*, disagrees. His new book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes that it is possible to make something tasty in the same time it takes to order a pizza. He has already written two successful books on this topic. In this new book, you will find many appealing recipes, each ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel shares over 200 recipes from around the world in his fun and engaging style. Just because he enjoys quick meals doesn’t mean he doesn’t value good food. If you doubt that fast food can be great, try his recipes—they are simply delicious!

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors looked. According to palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer, we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago. 

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many natural areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

Research in Ohio showed that when healthy hunter-gatherers started farming corn, they became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be a blessing, some anthropologists see it as a public health problem. Still, agriculture spread because one piece of farmland could support many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people are poorly nourished, but wealthier countries like those in Europe, the US, and Japan are starting to eat better again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive change, but it comes with challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Legroom in planes and trains seems to be getting smaller, and clothing companies are constantly adjusting their sizes. The question is: how tall can we get? 

According to Robert Fogel from the University, we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, scientists warn that while individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate has warmed, we have become thinner and shorter, even with good nutrition. If global warming continues, we might shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by climate change.

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City became boring—no one was enjoying it anymore. I didn’t plan to leave for another five or ten years, but then I was unexpectedly made redundant. I didn’t receive a great severance package, but it was enough to start my farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the best restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat through mail order. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. He explains, "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. Choosing to take redundancy and become an artist felt like the right choice. The career counselor I spoke to was very supportive. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for financial reasons. My wife and I married young, and our children are now independent, so we took a risk and moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but luckily, our friendships have lasted, and many visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. She shares, "Being a lawyer was enjoyable and well-paid, but the hours were awful. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even longer hours, so I decided to leave. Many people said I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to set deadlines. Since my business is related to fashion, I have collections and seasonal designs to manage, so there’s always a lot to do, and I keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and much less stressed. However, I miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a poor job, I am the one who faces the consequences. When you work for a company, you care, but when your name is on the promotional materials, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He says, "I was in financial markets from the age of 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I never found the work fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left voluntarily and traveled for a year. During that time, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms in the world and spoke to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then, I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future, which is the best part."

**A Winning Game**

Two brothers have discovered that their childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, bearded brothers in their forties, are at their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, enjoying their past. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing pichenotte, an ancient game they believe is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, every weekend and holiday, the family played together, and as Dave says, "having the best time ever." 

Later, the family moved to New Mexico, but they kept playing with their grandfather's pichenotte board, made from old wooden crates. When visitors came over, they were often intrigued because the game was unknown in the southern USA. Three years ago, Dave noticed how worn out the old board was and decided to make a new one. It turned out beautifully. A relative saw it and wanted one, then a friend wanted one too. Curious about the interest, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. "People started to watch," Dave recalls, "and said, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' But soon they were sitting down, and you couldn't get them up from the table!"

When people asked about the game's origins, Dave researched it. He found that the game likely started in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' exists. This was adapted into a game called 'squails' played in British pubs, and British immigrants brought it to Canada. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec. The game can be played by two to four people and requires skill. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks' that they flick across a wheel-like board using their middle or index finger. Getting a puck into a small hole earns 20 points, while three rings around the hole are worth 15, 10, and 5 points. There are also eight small posts that act as obstacles. The game usually lasts about two minutes.

Seeing the game's popularity at the Santa Fe bar, the Lagasses made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money was exchanged, and the game's popularity increased. Championships began, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly, and the brothers decided to start a pichenotte business full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and began making boards. So far, they have produced over 450 boards, made of birchwood and mahogany, each weighing 12 kg and 1 cm thick. Norm explains, "They're very durable, as they have to withstand a lot of use." They sell for $595 each on the brothers' website.
