Currently, there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage to create pichenotte stars. However, the day may come when the brothers' garage will hold a luxury Mercedes instead of tools and wood. Until then, they enjoy their free time playing the game they hope will bring them success.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first arrive at the Model Village, it is hard to believe that just a few years ago, this area was an empty, overgrown piece of land. For a long time, it was seen as useless. However, through careful planning and hard work by one man, with the support of his wife, this land has been transformed into the beautiful site you see today.

During the construction of the village, many thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the shaped landscape you see now. While machines like bulldozers helped with this transformation, a lot of manual labor was also involved. Once the land was shaped, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rockeries. 

In building the Model Village, hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted. These plants were carefully chosen to survive in the salty air near the sea and to withstand strong winter winds. Most of the plants came from local garden centers, but some were imported from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.

The entire village was designed by Colin Sims, who created over 100 models over nine years after the village opened in 1972. The models are made from various materials, including stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics, to endure different weather conditions. Initially, Colin needed help from experts to understand how different materials would last over time, but he quickly became skilled himself.

You will notice that a consistent scale has been used, and great attention has been given to even the smallest details of the models. This was achieved through patience and the development of unique building techniques. The Model Village has become a popular attraction, known for its high-quality craftsmanship and upkeep. The methods used to create these realistic models have been adopted in other model villages across England and have even been included in college courses on modeling.

All the buildings in the village represent traditional British architectural styles and are not based on any specific place. One of the most impressive structures is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, inspired by manor houses found in the West Country. As you explore the village, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini-golf course, which is the newest addition.

We kindly ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch any of the models, as any damage can take hours to repair. You are welcome to take photos from the pathways only, and dogs are allowed on a short lead.

To enhance your experience, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Pressing these buttons will make the models operate. At the end of your visit, we would appreciate any feedback you have. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more diverse and interesting display. We also want to know if there are any models that you think need improvement. We are constantly updating the models and need your input on which ones require attention.

We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Please tell your friends about us!

Text: 

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and violate the editors' code of practice. While some pop stars do pose for paparazzi sometimes, this is not common. More often, serious harm is done to public figures when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people report these issues to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle such problems. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has previously complained about long-lens photos, and since she was in a hotel—a place where people expect privacy—she had a valid reason to complain, but she did not take action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation on its own. It should also look into the recent shocking story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take the lead on this and other disgraceful stories?

At first glance, this seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers, which would be reported by their competitors and shown on TV and radio. The public would not support such behavior, and editors would have to stop publishing this kind of material. Photographers would also be affected, as they would no longer be able to afford to hide behind trees to take pictures of unsuspecting celebrities. If the PCC decided to act as a 'police officer', it would face several challenges. How would it decide whether to start an investigation? Should it contact the victim and encourage them to file a complaint? And if the person still refused to act, should the PCC proceed anyway? Additionally, celebrities and royals might expect that any story about them would be investigated, and they could be upset if it wasn’t.

Moreover, the PCC's role would be too vast. How could it realistically monitor all of the British press, including national, regional, and magazine publications? There is also the issue of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy has been violated, would they want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Most likely, they just want to move on with their lives. Some may have other reasons for staying quiet, such as a worse story they want to keep hidden from the press, knowing that complaining could bring it to light. In this way, the PCC could become an enemy.

One British comedian faced problems with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He did not complain then, nor did he when he and his family were photographed during a holiday. His reason was fear that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his anger, claiming they thought it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he would have a sense of humor about it. This fear is understandable. People believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is difficult to find a simple solution to this serious issue.

Many college graduates receive advice when starting their first job. This article focuses on what to consider when moving to a second job. We will not discuss those looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those who leave a job they dislike within a few weeks. Instead, we will talk about those of you who are ready to take a significant step in your career. You have gained some experience and skills and have a clearer idea of your career goals.

What kind of job should you seek? It largely depends on your long-term goals. Ask yourself if you want to specialize in a certain area, aim for higher responsibilities, or explore a broader field. Whatever you choose, it is important to select your second job carefully, as you should plan to stay in it for two to three years. Future employers will closely examine this job when you apply for your next position. It should demonstrate that you have thought seriously about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow, develop your skills, and increase your responsibilities.

If you feel the urge to travel, now might be a good time to do so. You can take temporary work when you return and then find your second job. Employers will appreciate that you have satisfied your desire to travel and are less likely to leave again soon.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after graduating from St. Aldate's College working for three solicitors. It was a great first job because they were supportive, and she learned how to navigate an office and improve her word processing skills. However, there was no opportunity for advancement. Eventually, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.

Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more capable, and my job has really evolved. From the start, my boss was eager to help me grow. My job title is the same as when I began, but my responsibilities have changed. I now handle most of the correspondence and budgets, and I deal with various inquiries, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own businesses. Brenda includes me in all her work and also assigns me specific projects and events to organize."

**Text: 'What is the Secret of Confident People?**

Confident people may seem like they were born that way, but many will say it is a skill they learned over time. Nina Hathway interviews five individuals to find out how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**  
When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At about twenty-five, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I was nervous but surprised myself by doing well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I felt very anxious, but my confidence grew over time, and I became more outgoing. Looking back, working at the school was a turning point in my life that helped everything else improve.

**B. Michaela**  
My journey began four years ago when my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became overly aggressive and impatient, thinking that was how confident people acted. Eventually, I learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work becomes too overwhelming, I don’t feel guilty about postponing some tasks. When facing challenges, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can destroy confidence, so I often have quiet conversations with myself to overcome those fears.

**C. Lisa**  
People see me as very confident, but the calmer I appear, the more scared I actually feel. I had to learn to look confident because it is essential in TV. Interviewing people made me realize that most of us feel tense in important situations, and we feel better when talking to someone friendly. The best advice I received was from my mother when I worried about my appearance as a teenager. She said, "Who’s looking at you? Everyone is too busy worrying about how they look." I remember this often. I also believe that facing your fears helps build confidence. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I would never be that scared again, and I haven’t been.

**D. Barbara**  
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I have built it up over the years. If you keep working and learn from your mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am well-liked in the restaurant, but I know that not everyone will like me. I don’t let that bother me. You must appreciate yourself for who you are, not try to meet others' expectations. My company offers many training courses, which have boosted my self-esteem. They also encourage us to set realistic goals. It is very helpful to see that you are achieving something, rather than aiming too high and ending up with nothing.

**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings, disagreeing with what was said but too scared to speak up. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I first entered politics, I had never spoken in public and would shake with nerves. I told myself, "Don’t be silly. People do this every day, so you can too." I also found it helpful to write down a few notes to refer to, like a comfort blanket! I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking publicly. The real secret to confidence is reminding yourself repeatedly, "Nothing is impossible."

**Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his torn kite. "You have to keep it," he said. "It's traditional—if the line breaks, the finder keeps it... and I have plenty more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat in the shade of the whispering conifer trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, looking out at Malaysia's largest kite festival. 

In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites, and a row of tense competitors waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites shot into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each participant entered four different designs, judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying efficiency. 

"Flying kites isn't too hard," Adnan said, "but making them requires real skill. Come visit me at home, and I'll show you how to do it." I received five invitations that day and decided to accept his. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large, polished room. As night fell, he asked me to return the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, through granite mountains covered in lush rainforest. 

I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road suddenly ended at a river. A narrow boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my attention. It pointed up a footpath into the forest and read: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before starting my hike, it would have been helpful to know that most of the distance was steep and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man named Baba waiting with a flask of tea. He managed a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects crawling under my thin foam mattress. 

The night was completely dark, filled with various sounds. A nearby waterfall roared, and thousands of creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, I enjoyed a stunning view of five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First came the wind, then lightning struck the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. As I slid downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the heavy raindrops. I also worried about my car being washed away (which sometimes happens) and the risk of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. 

In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But their curiosity was friendly. While Kelantan is famous for its kites, I will always remember it for the kindness of its people.

What kind of shopper are you? Whether you love it or hate it, shopping is something we all do. There are different types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? Abby Edwards asked several people about their shopping habits:

A. Melanie, 22, dancer  
"I'm addicted to shopping! When I have money, I go out and it makes me happy. I can't resist sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often go shopping together. We're a couple of shopaholics!"

B. Brenda, 40, office manager  
"I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the grocery shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don’t spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter shopping, but it’s hard because we all have different tastes. I don’t often buy things for myself, so when I do, I feel guilty and usually tell my husband I spent less than I really did because the real price seems shocking."

C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager  
"I only shop for essentials. I dislike shopping and only go when I have to. When I do shop, I know exactly what I want and won’t settle for anything else. Shopping is tiring, and I’d rather be doing something else."

D. Anita, 35, TV producer  
"I enjoy browsing sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and try to get in and out quickly. However, I do have some items in my wardrobe that I regret buying, so maybe I’m a careful shopper who occasionally makes mistakes."

E. Lizzie, 41, secretary  
"I really dislike shopping. I find it hard to find clothes I like or anyone to help me. The shops are noisy and messy, which makes it a nightmare for me. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often since I usually receive them as gifts. For food shopping, I go to the supermarket once a week and get it done quickly."

F. Lisa, 22, actress  
"I’m probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out with my friends just to look around, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I’ll buy it."

G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant  
"I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy much. I usually know what I want and don’t go overboard. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I often regret spending too much."

H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker  
"I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too crowded. I consider myself a careful shopper. I usually have a good idea of what I want and don’t rush into buying things. I like to check other shops to find better deals, which takes me a long time!"

I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager  
"I’m an unwilling shopper. Since I work in the city center, shopping has lost its appeal for me. When I have to shop, I go reluctantly and don’t bother trying things on because it’s too much effort. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t mind too much. I’d rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of time in shops."

NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE

The Open University offers degrees just like any other university, but you can study without leaving your job. This can lead to many new interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the exciting experience of learning new things. You will also meet a diverse group of people. Additionally, your degree may open doors to new career paths.

At the Open University, you do not attend traditional lectures. Instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer programs. If you want, you can go to one class a month at an Open University center. Like any university, there are exams to complete.

If you want to learn more, just fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about surprises. Free quiz sheets are available at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will explore 14 surprising paintings and answer various questions about them. The quiz sheets can be picked up from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

**New Artwork**  
The Gallery now features a beautiful still life by the Dutch painter Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings of this kind in the Gallery. The artwork is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for artists to date their work in two years because they wait for specific flowers to bloom in different seasons. This painting was generously donated to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. It is currently displayed in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition titled "Painting in Spain during the Late 18th Century" opened in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery has recently acquired works by three Spanish painters from this period: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus of the exhibition. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists who worked in Spain during this time: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition will be open until 31 May.

**Lecture Series**  
The series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will discuss Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will talk about Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will focus on Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often tell stories through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is pleased to announce that the restaurant has improved and expanded its services. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers a wide variety of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Visitor Information**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours highlight some of the Gallery's greatest artworks and showcase a wide range of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where kids can have fun and learn to make delicious food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to eat the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I was happy at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to cook for themselves when they leave home."

**Outdoor Centre Fees**  
The fees for the Outdoor Centre are based on a car with four people. If there are extra people, it costs 50p each. Payments should be made at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organization that aims to provide outdoor sports and recreation for everyone. Groups are asked to let the centre know in advance about their visit.

**Windsurfing - One-Day Course**  
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays when the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable, and the thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Boards with small sails are provided for beginners. The course fee is £32.50, which includes all the necessary equipment.

**One-Day Adventure Course**  
This is a great chance to try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is designed to introduce outdoor activities to adults in a fun and relaxed way. You do not need to be very fit or have any previous experience; just bring your interest. The course fee is £22.50.

**Play Park**  
The Play Park is for children aged two to ten years. It is one of the best parks of its kind in the country, featuring sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

**Group Day and Residential Courses**  
We also offer day and weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups often visit us. There are three large rooms, each with twelve beds, available for groups of up to 36 people (with a minimum of 12).

**Summer Adventure Holidays (for ages 8-14)**  
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are fully trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We ensure that all children participate in activities that are suitable for their age and physical abilities. For this program, children must be able to swim 25 meters and be in good health.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN LAST A LIFETIME**

Many people of all ages find joy in stamp collecting, a hobby that is both enjoyable and engaging. Each year, more individuals begin their own stamp collections and discover a passion that can last throughout their lives. 

Starting a collection is simple because stamps are easy to find. You can collect stamps from holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends around the world. Once you become serious about collecting, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club, which helps collectors obtain new British stamps. 

As a member of the Club, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. There are three ways to receive them: 
1. A complete set of stamps can be mailed to you in an envelope.
2. You can receive the stamps in a colorful information pack filled with interesting facts.
3. Alternatively, you can get individual stamps to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has around 70,000 members, and you can join for just £5 for a two-year membership. If you join with a group, you may even get a discount. This is a great deal! When you join, the Club will send you a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This pack includes 100 stamps to kickstart your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You will also receive a helpful 4-page guide with tips on how to grow your collection and a list of shops that sell stamps.

Every two months, you will receive the Club magazine, which is full of competitions and quizzes, and gives you the opportunity to exchange stamps with members from around the world. 

Why not start this exciting adventure that can bring you years of enjoyment? You will spend many happy hours admiring the diverse stamps in your collection or searching for rare ones that are waiting to be discovered. 

Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and experience the fun of stamp collecting! To become a member, simply fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days of your application.

**MONEY**

What is money? The pound, the dollar, and the franc are similar to a gram or a kilometer. The main difference is that you can trade money for goods or services. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a large bag of sweets, or a few cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce.

Thousands of years ago, people did not have money like we do today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, a farmer, would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own forms of money, known as 'currencies,' to make trading easier. Eventually, different currencies began to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.

**Write a Winning Story!**

You have a chance to win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in *Keep Writing* magazine. Ten other winners will receive £100 each. We are looking for people who can write great stories. The judges include novelist Mary Littlejohn, television reporter Michael Brown, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of *Keep Writing*. They want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story.

You can write about anything, but here are some tips to help you get started:

1. **Write About What You Know**: This is important advice for every writer. Last year, many stories focused on love, family, and friendship problems. However, you should make ordinary situations interesting so that readers want to read more. Try to present everyday topics in a new and surprising way.

2. **Get Your Facts Right**: If you describe a place or explain something technical, make sure your information is correct. Only write about things you are sure about.

3. **Hold the Reader's Attention**: Start your story in an engaging way and end it with a surprise. A weak ending can ruin a good story. Develop your plot carefully and think of something unexpected for the conclusion.

4. **Think About the Characters**: Make your characters feel real by using descriptive language. Help the reader connect with them.

Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, typed, double-spaced, and printed on one side of each page. We cannot accept stories sent by fax or email, even if you are close to the deadline. You must include the application form with your story. Unfortunately, we cannot return your story or discuss our decisions.

You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, as per a new rule. Your story must not have been published in any form, including on radio or TV, anywhere in the world. 

The entry fee is £5, which goes to the Writers' Association. Please make your cheque payable to *Keep Writing* and send it with your application form and story to us. The closing date is July 30, and we will notify the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.

**THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST**

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist recognized in history. Her father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that she received the best education possible. This was rare, as most women at that time had limited chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and began teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her understanding of new ideas. Although we do not have any of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and created several scientific tools to assist her work. During her time, many rulers feared science, and those involved in it were often in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is twelve kilometers long and runs through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in Peterborough and ends at Wansford, which is near the A1 main road. There is also a two-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to the peaceful area of Yarwell, the current western end of the line.  
**Fares:**  
- Adult: £10.00  
- Child: £5.00  
- Family Fare (up to 2 adults and 3 children): £25.00  
Special prices may be available on public holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park offers golf courses and a large Caravan Club site, making it a great place for a family day out. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station features a unique collection of historic trains from various parts of Europe. This includes the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, which is the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can see these engines all year, regardless of whether the Nene Valley Railway is operating. However, the buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open when the trains are running. There is a site entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**  
Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. A notable example is its appearance in the James Bond movie "Octopussy." Come and see where it was filmed!

**Services for Schools**  
From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups to visit and for teachers to set projects. Students can work on projects while at the railway or in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, school groups can hire the 'Teddy Bear' train with up to 3 carriages on non-service days, but they need to book one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. For more information, call 01780 784444.

**Private Hire of Trains**  
The Railway is a great place for special family events or company visits. It can provide a unique setting for an interesting afternoon or evening. Special programs can be arranged to include a buffet, bar, entertainment, and more. For further details, please contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

**Grass**

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 different types of grasses, and they can be found in every part of the earth. Grass is unique because it can grow in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way.

One of the remarkable features of grass is its ability to recover quickly after being cut or damaged. Unlike many other plants, grass grows new leaves from below the soil rather than from the top. This allows many animals to live together in the same area. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, providing a fresh food source.

Kal Kaur Rai, the Young Achiever of the Year, has always loved fashion and recently won this title at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who run a supermarket, about her dream of making fashion her career. She believed they wanted her to pursue a more traditional job, so she studied management at university.

After finishing her studies, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. Although she had to attend industry events, she couldn't afford the designer clothes she admired. To solve this, she began making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends noticed her creations, they asked her to make clothes for them too. This led her to find a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. Her clothes became very popular, and nothing was returned, which motivated her to leave her advertising job. She took out a £20,000 loan to start her own womenswear brand.

Kal's parents were supportive of her decision to change careers, which made her very happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal feels grateful for her success, saying, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

**Sunningdale Hotel**

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has provided excellent service to guests from around the world, welcoming people of all ages and nationalities. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed at Sunningdale.

The hotel is located on a main road that leads to the town center. It is about a 20-minute bus ride from the center, and buses to various parts of the town stop right outside the hotel. Guests should avoid buses with a blue "Express" sign, as they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are located at the end of each corridor. The hotel also features a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are eight pianos available for guests to use. Parking spaces for cars are available in the hotel driveway. Daily newspapers are provided for free, and stamps can be purchased at the office.

Guests staying for long periods must pay for their accommodation weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms.

Meal times are as follows: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. For those studying or working late during the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by signing the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices available for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires of any kind (for cooking or heating) are allowed, and guests are asked to respect the comfort of others. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise to a minimum, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. Guests arriving by train are advised to take a taxi to the hotel, as it is some distance from the main railway station.

**Tom Cruise**

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in film history. However, his life has not always been easy. As a child, Tom was shy and found it hard to make friends, even though he loved participating in school plays. After finishing high school, he moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter while also taking drama classes. In 1980, the film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he had become so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each film. Today, Tom continues to act in films and remains very popular with his many fans around the world.

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had traveled over 500 kilometers. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. He gave her some milk and started to ask questions. He called his last customers, but they had not lost a cat. As it was getting late, he took Bo home for the night and the next morning took her to an animal hospital. Bo's owner had also been looking for her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he recalled the name of the company. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned to him.'

**The Ghan Train**

Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in northern Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train travels across the Australian continent, from the warm northern coast through vast deserts to the cooler Southern Ocean. It is often called the "famous Ghan," which is a bit unfortunate because it is mostly known for being late.

The idea of a train link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs. However, serious flooding often made it hard for trains to run. A new line was finished just a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds of up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is very good. The railway was originally built to transport goods, not passengers. It was believed that sending goods from Europe to Australia’s southern cities via Darwin and the train would save time and money compared to shipping around the continent.

It is rare to complete a transcontinental railway, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south railway. As I waited to board the Ghan, I noticed that everyone was excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners, and they were especially eager to get on the train. Our first stop was Katherine, where the Ghan stayed for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip up the gorge. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged anymore, and few people do it. Our group walked around the rock and enjoyed the beautiful sunset.

From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers stop their journey there. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting; there is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. However, at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was coming to an end, and although the train did not meet all the promises made in advertisements, it had taken me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

**Climbing to the Top of Britain**

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is located in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt shares his experience of climbing Ben Nevis for the first time.

It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We chose a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is six hundred meters high, making it probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are large bowl-shaped areas cut into the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. These spikes are necessary because the snow can be so hard that it feels like walking on ice. 

Even though some members of our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, including lights to signal for help, hard hats, and extra clothing. Although the weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, we still felt nervous when we started our climb. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge.

The path quickly became steep, and my legs felt heavy. As the weakest member of the group, I needed to take more breaks. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I arrived, they would start climbing again. I promised myself that I would train better before my next climb.

After climbing 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the top of Ben Nevis. This path is only a meter and a half wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on both sides. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we finally reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometers away. Unfortunately, we were not so lucky because a mist had come down.

Getting back down to camp can be just as difficult as climbing up. You need to read a map carefully because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns reading the map. That first time, I only felt I truly enjoyed the experience when I was safely in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

**Anna's New School**

This week has been very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is a wonderful place. The builders used wood for the entire structure, similar to our old school, but this one is also designed to be environmentally friendly. The construction took several months, and we watched it all happen. It was thrilling to see the builders clear the land, even though it meant some beautiful open space was lost. The noise from the construction machines was very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to worry that the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms that are huge—much larger than those in our old school, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town for meetings and other events. There is also a nursery, a lovely dining room, and large changing rooms that we are excited to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice that there are no heaters! Instead, the warmth comes from everyone inside—the students, teachers, and the computers we use. The building is designed so well that it keeps all the heat inside. It also keeps the sound in, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting feature is that the school roof has a tree on top! The builders placed it there after finishing the roof because it is a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for our lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so large that it can be seen from far away! We took some pictures that we plan to put on our website.

Even though we are already using the school, some parts are still being completed. For example, we are currently preparing a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to perform it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now that we are here!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever considered joining a book club and receiving new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many members already buy books from us this way.

**How to Join:**
To become a member, simply send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate Benefits:**
As a special offer, you can choose any reduced-price books from our new members' list, up to a total value of £6 (plus postage and packing). This means you will save money compared to the publishers' prices. You can also tick a box on your form to receive a free watch. If you respond within seven days, we will send you another free gift selected from our book list by our staff. You can order a DVD from our selection at half the recommended retail price.

**After Joining:**
As a member, you will enjoy discounts of 30% to 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, and they will be delivered directly to your home. You will receive a free club magazine every month, which will keep you informed about the latest best-sellers. Each year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. You can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

**Being a Member:**
During your first year, we ask you to choose four books. After that, you can decide how many books you want to order. In each monthly magazine, our experienced staff will select a "Club Choice" book, which is a fiction or reference title they believe is especially worth buying, offered at a special price. If you do not want this book, just let us know on the form. If we do not hear from you, we will send the book automatically.

Please return your application form today, as this is a special offer. To apply, fill in the enclosed form and return it in the provided postage-paid envelope. Your books will arrive soon. Do not send any money now; we will send you a bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. After that, you can either return them or send your payment.

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never imagined that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place we stayed wasn't great, but it had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. 

On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn were with Amanda. We all came from different places and didn’t know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren’t sure how. Half of us went caving in the morning while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally made it out—covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.'

Letter to the Newport Evening News

On Saturday afternoon, I accidentally left my handbag on the bus. Inside were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I felt lost: I am 72 years old, far from home, and quite worried. I stood by the road and cried.

A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what had happened. He kindly gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I explained the situation to the bus driver, he told me I could keep the fare. I made it home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had found it and offered to bring it back to me.

I was amazed to get my handbag back, with everything inside still there. I want to express my gratitude to everyone who helped me that day. Their kindness and honesty meant a lot to me.

Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Sharks**

Sharks are among the most intimidating animals in our oceans. They are well adapted for hunting underwater because they have excellent vision and can sense movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous for smaller sea animals that they prey on. 

While sharks share some similarities with other fish, their bodies are quite different. For instance, most sharks must keep swimming constantly to breathe and survive, which means they hardly ever sleep. Additionally, if sharks are flipped onto their backs, they can become completely still. This is a useful method for researchers who need to study sharks, as it helps them learn more about these intriguing creatures.
