THE OSTRICH

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh over 90 kilograms. Most wild ostriches are found in southern Africa, but their numbers are decreasing. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them change direction while running. Ostriches can run very fast, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the same size as chickens and take around 3 years to grow into adults. They eat plants and can survive for many days without water.

Text: 'Victoria Jamieson, a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain, began snowboarding at the age of 20. She has won many competitions in this sport. We spoke to her last week at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland and asked why she started. She said, "I've always enjoyed sports, especially skiing, so it felt natural to try snowboarding. It’s easy to learn, and you can get really good in just a few months." 

When we asked about her practice routine, she replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains; it’s so beautiful. But free-riding, which is when you do what you want outside of competitions, is the best part for me." 

We also asked her what is important for beginners. She explained, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. Having the right clothes is also important to stay dry because, at first, you will fall a lot!"'

**Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people, from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man, have climbed it. There are several routes to the summit. The Marangu route, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest and takes about five days. It is very popular among tourists. However, only half of the climbers who attempt to reach the top succeed. This is often due to sudden changes in the weather. At the start of the climb, it can be hot and rainy, but at the summit, climbers encounter ice and snow, and temperatures can drop below 20 degrees Celsius. Therefore, climbers should bring both sunglasses and warm clothing!

**Otters**

Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes using small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. 

Twenty years ago, there were very few otters in Great Britain. The rivers were so polluted that many fish and insects died, leaving otters without food. However, today the rivers are clean again, and there is plenty of food for them.

**Buildings**

People have always created buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. Other buildings, like museums, are used to display beautiful items. 

Many people work together to construct a building. The architect decides how the building will look and creates drawings to share their ideas. Engineers ensure that the building is strong and safe. Finally, workers carefully build it.

The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building known for its beautiful roof. However, it is attractive from all angles, not just the top. Another notable building is the Olympic Stadium in Munich, which has a unique roof that resembles a glass tent.

The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in southern England that are close to each other. Between these towns, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large image of a man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. It is not clear when the Cerne Giant was created, but many believe it was a long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the image. If you visit on May 1st at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she plans to compete in the 10,000 metres and possibly the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was known for finishing second in major competitions. However, she always smiled and laughed, which made her popular in her hometown. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with an impressive time, the fastest of any British woman that year.

Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop due to an injury in his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail, but it’s not enjoyable for him when she runs ahead and he can't keep up. Gail trains hard, doing long runs in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. She always takes Sundays off from running. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

**Piano Players - Their Early Years**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six years old. At ten, he decided he wanted to write music and soon began working on his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he began taking lessons from a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano skills. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he began playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six years old. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef has always loved music, but he is also interested in physics and languages. Although he is very busy now, he hopes to write his own music one day.

**Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist before he became a writer of children's books at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me when she doesn't like something," says Bill. His ten grandchildren do not live nearby, but they also read his stories and give their opinions on them. This feedback has helped Bill understand what young children enjoy reading.

Bill writes about life in his village and the farms around it. His favorite book is his fifth one, called *The Sheepdog*, which tells the story of a farmer and the dog that helps him. "I have always liked animals," says Bill, "and dogs are very smart; they learn quickly." Last year, this book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The filmmakers used advanced computer technology to make it seem like the animals were talking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually feature images of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many individuals send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the images are often nicer than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century, and it showed a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards included images related to current events, such as accidents or visits from important people. People appreciated these postcards because newspapers at that time did not include pictures.

Dinosaurs

No one has ever seen a dinosaur because the last one died about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. The exact reason for their extinction is still unknown. Birds are the closest living relatives of dinosaurs. 

Dinosaurs were not all the same; there were over 5,000 different types. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was about twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was smaller but much stronger. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run quickly due to its long back legs.

**Bears**

Bears can be dangerous animals. An adult bear is very strong and can kill a person. They are skilled at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, bears do not see well, and like many animals, they use their sense of smell to find food. 

There are seven types of bears. The largest is the polar bear, which can grow to nearly three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other is found in Southeast Asia. Interestingly, not all black bears are actually black; they can be dark brown or reddish-brown. 

Many people love the black and white panda bear, which is native to China. Unfortunately, there are not many pandas left in the wild today because it is hard for them to find food.

CROCODILES

Crocodiles are found in tropical regions around the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually live in slow-moving water but can swim quickly and move fast on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat a variety of things, including fish, birds, and small animals, and sometimes they even attack larger animals or people.

There are more than ten different types of crocodiles, and all of them have very sharp teeth. Although they often lose teeth, they quickly grow new ones. Crocodiles typically measure about 3.5 meters in length, but some can be much larger. They also have a long lifespan; the oldest crocodile in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL

In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first powered airplane and flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Over the next thirty years, airplanes improved significantly. In the 1950s, airplanes became much faster because they were equipped with jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was developed in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger airplane in the world, capable of flying at 2,500 kilometers per hour, which means the trip from London to New York takes only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.

The Globe Theatre

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from today. The building was round and had no roof, so people would get cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, located by the River Thames, to watch the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors would eat, talk to their friends, walk around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre has been built in the same location near the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.
